It's really a disappointment to not see him do any other film adaptations of Mamet's work to date, clearly this is his best work and the best adaptation of Mamet's as well. What a shame there has been no more further films with this paring. The editing and soundtrack are also brilliant, giving us a rare treat, a masterpiece that stands up under repeated viewings and clearly will over the years to come. This is one of the best constructed films you will ever watch.

reviews.review_title: Why is this not up on the top Two Hundred,
reviews.content: Let alone the top ten? Glengarry Glen Ross is one of the best films ever made. A brilliant story played perfectly by probably the best cast ever assembled. It's a movie that I can never grow tired of. I've seen it nearly fifteen times and am still absorbed in it every second along the way. I strongly recommend that if you are a fan of this film,put your vote in to have it reach the two hundred. If not, go see it. You won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: The crook you are going to care about
reviews.content: "Glengarry Glen Ross" is a film about a seedy real estate agency selling people worthless pieces of land and robbing them of their savings. The seedy character is symbolized in the film by the fact that the agency keeps office in a poor part of town and that it always rains.There are three important characters in the movie. Blake (the manager) played by Alec Baldwin, Ricky Roma (the young upcoming sales) played by Al Pacino and Shelley Levene (the old sales in the downward phase of his career) played by Jack Lemmon.Blake is a typical American and in my opinion rather uninteresting character. In his opinion the value of a human being can be measured by his wealth or the revenue he generates (My watch is more expensive then your car). His role in this film is to trigger the competition between te sales. Because business is not going well for the agency, the sales with the lowest weakly revenue will be fired.The film is about the competition between the sales, and especially about the underdog sales Shelley Levene. His character (played brilliantly by Jack Lemmon) is the only one we that we get to know personally. The strange thing is that we even begin to care for him, although in fact he is a crook. The reasons are in the first place that he is the underdog and in the second place that he has a sick daughter to care for. Losing his job is losing his health insurance. So we hope he is not losing his job, even if his job is stealing the savings from innocent people. I recently reviewed "The insider" (1999, Michael Mann) and also in this film the risk of losing health insurance that is badly needed played a role in generating sympathy for the lead character.There is another remarkable fact in this film. Although most of the spectators will see the sales as scammers, that is not the way they look at themselves. In one of the best scenes of the movie Ricky Roma and Shelley Levene are evaluating a sales conversation they recently had. From the way they talk about it is clear that they view their profession nearly as an art form.The story is situated in the 80's. In my opinion it is however of all times. Replace "worthless peace of land" with "toxic financial derivative" and you do have the financial crisis at the beginning of the new century.
Watched this film maybe our economy would be better off instead of dealing with a bunch of whiny little gluten free, half caff, half-men that seem to dominate our culture today.

It's a barrage of words. If you like constant yelling and abuse between the boss and the employees then this movie may be for you. There are just too many things I didn't like about this film. It is very repetitive with a constant theme of "screw you" and "screw this job". None of the characters are likable – they are all shysters. The film drones on too negatively and there is very little humour.Also the subject is real estate sales where women have held a dominant position for decades now. Very strangely there is not one woman in this film! On the positive side the acting and performance by this all-star cast is first-rate, but it's just not sufficient to lift this story out of the doldrums..

Glengarry Glen Ross is based on the David Mamet play. I haven't seen it. This film is really a masculine film with no female characters in it all. Jack Lemmon's performance is heartbreaking as the desperate salesman trying to close a sale. It's an Oscar worthy performance in my opinion. Al Pacino is great as always. Jonathan Pryce is wonderful in the later scenes. The other salesmen read like the A-list of great actors, Oscar Nominee Ed Harris, Oscar Nominee Alec Baldwin, Oscar winner, Alan Arkin, and two-time Oscar winner, Kevin Spacey too. The story about real estate salesmen is brutal just like business. They are war with each other and the world. Unless they close their deals, they'll be fired by their bosses. I thought Jack Lemmon was the best performance of all. You loved him one minute, pitied him in another minute, and was rooting for him all the time.

reviews.review_title: One of the top dialogue driven stories
reviews.content: Like I mentioned in my summary, this movie is dialogue driven...Is it ever! And in my opinion, only good films, can be dialogue driven. And this isn't a good film...It's a GREAT and GRAND film! And I hope that no one else thinks otherwise. Along with the incredible dialogue, I also think that the cast is brilliant. Not for a second, am I thinking that these men are actors (Well, except for Alec Baldwin). And that is a good trait of a good actor.There's two particular characters that stick out the most in my mind: Jack Lemmon and Kevin Spacey. Boy, do these men ever play the roles well! I really admire some of the actors like Pacino and Harris, but I couldn't believe, when I finished the movie, what an amazing job Lemmon and Spacey did. And one last thing that I'd like to mention, that ties into both the dialogue and the acting...the setting. The reason this fits in with both dialogue and acting is because you're so involved with the characters interactions that you don't need any actions or change of scenery. It fits and works well. And perhaps if the setting had change it might of taken away from the scene. And as far as acting is concerned, I think that if you don't have good acting within the scene, you get bored and do focus on the facts (like setting), that you shouldn't.So, all these elements get thrown into one story, one film, that makes it both great and grand, and this work of art is known as "Glengarry Glen Ross".

I have actually met people who don't like this film, which i find staggering.Right from Alec Baldwins brutal opening speech, the whole film is top quality actors , doing what they do best.The dialogue and interaction is incredible, The pouring rain , drab office and Neon strip lights capture the mood brilliantly.Difficult to to say whose was the best performance, Spacey is brilliant but horrible as the manager who dishes out the leads, Pacino is magnificent as the archetypal salesman , " Top of the Board " but who still has time to listen to Jack Lemons sales stories of years gone by , who is brilliant as the aging salesman ( Very Death of a Salesman ) trying to hang on to former glory, but its obvious hes the only one who doesn't realise hes doomed, the way his voice changes on the phone when he clicks into sales mode , but knowing in his heart that the age old leads will never produce a sale and his desperate pleadings to Spacey for the Glengarry leads is brilliant but very sad.Truth is there are no bad performances in this film, easily in my top 10 of all time.

reviews.review_title: Some Of The Most Memorable Dialogue Ever.
reviews.content: If I were to roughly summarize Glengarry Glen Ross, I'd say it's a movie about a group of salesmen talking in an office for about an hour and forty minutes. Now, that's not far from the truth, but it's precisely in the talking where the beauty is.Ricky Roma (Al Pacino), Shelley "The Machine" Levene (Jack Lemmon), David Moss (Ed Harris), John Williamson (Kevin Spacey) and George Aaronow (Alan Arkin) are characters brilliantly written and masterfully played. I have to include Blake (Alec Baldwin) whose only scene in the movie is one of the most memorable and many people's favorite. Oh, and James Lingk (Jonathan Pryce) who also has a small but equally masterfully played role.Every actor gives a stellar performance playing these salesmen. Just to watch them walk around the office and sitting at their desks talking to each other and yelling at each other is a pleasure. It's amazing how much entertainment can be achieved with just words and a regular setting like an office.The story is good, but I'm gonna be honest, this film is all about the characters.The dialogue is top notch. Some of the best dialogue I've heard in any movie. Absolutely quotable not only because of the way it's written (by David Mamet) but also because of the way the actors say it. If you want perfect delivery and timing, this is the movie.Glengarry Glen Ross is one of my top ten films of all time. A film with characters that make a day in the office seem like the most entertaining thing.

reviews.review_title: A movie that went by way to fast
reviews.content: I got into Glengarry Glen Ross sort of knowing what it was about. I didn't, however, knew what to expect. And boy, was it a great surprise. The movie pulls you in, with smart dialogue and character development that happens while a lone man sits at a telephone, barely speaking. The plot gets going before you realize, going from an introduction to the characters to the main conflict of the movie smoothly, showing nuances of the same characters in a human and recurrent way.And then, it's over. It's not like it is a short movie: it's pretty standard feature length. But it pulls you in so strongly, it puts you in the shoes of desperate men in a way that makes the one and a half hour feel like a couple of minutes. It isn't a sit, it is a passing moment, just like the night of the movie for the characters. It is a masterclass about storytelling, even a arguably boring one.

This unimaginative film is pointless, tedious, pretentious rubbish from start to finish. It has neither plot nor story and the characters are universally objectionable. Lacking any entertainment value, this depressing, predictable, pompous drivel, masquerading as serious social commentary, lacks any real depth or insight: its nauseating self-importance is just too much.So many whom I respect like this film that I've watched it through again just to satisfy myself that it really is every bit as much a depressing snore-fest as I first thought. Jack Lemmon hams it up with over-acting ("The leads! The leads!"), with Al Pacino bellowing along --- these are the performances considered award-worthy!What a load of crap.

One of my favourite films of all time. Brilliant all round acting (Jack Lemmon is incredible). The cast is impeccable and brilliant. The story is simple yet amazingly deep. As for Alec Baldwin....geeez,how does one steal the show with one scene? For me arguably one of the greatest films ever made. I could go on and on. A must see for all movie enthusiasts.

This movie is raw drama. You get to witness the most realistic acting probably ever. Jack lemmon even at that age gave a mindblowing performance. Pacino is as usual perfect. The storyline is unbelievably gripping( given how simple the the theme is). This movie hugely underrated.

One of the greatest cons of all time is the sale. Convincing someone to buy a product, even if they are just looking or vaguely interested. The art of the sale. I admire my Son cause he has the gift of selling. Starting out as a young car salesman in Rhode Island My son learned his trade by studying body gestures and facial expressions. Went to seminars just to learn how to win over someone's confidence implementing empathy with the customer, staying focused on your goals with a certain responsibility supplementing persistence and optimism despite the numerous rejections. Many intricate parts to the art of the sale but what it takes to sell real estate? "BRASS BALLS". Glengarry Glen Ross is such a picture as it takes a look at the underbelly world of sales, Following the lives of four real estate salesmen. Unscrupulous, cunning and crafty but reaching a dead end with empty leads dispensed by the office manager Williamson (Kevin Spacey). The story draws the initial attention to a slumping,over the hill salesman Shelley Levene (Jack Lemmon) who is on the phone discussing a medical issue about his ailing daughter. Shelley's daughter's illness never goes any further in detail but Shelly needs to close an account for her medical care. Now, in his early Sixties, Shelley Levene was once a dominant force in the real estate game. Shelly, has fallen on hard times and Williamson lets him know it. A meeting is held in the home office as a brash well dressed man enters the Room as he see Shelly pouring coffee and orders him to put the coffee down. "Coffee is for closer!" exhorts the tall stranger who's name is Blake (Alec Baldwin). This scene is worth watching as the revolting Blake tells the dyer realities of not closing a customer with the consequences of losing their jobs. Blake continues his sermon to these frustrated salesmen telling them either they sell these properties and use the leads you already have.Alec Baldwin gives a speech that reminds me of the movie Patton starring George C, Scott with strength and conviction yet arrogant to his audience as Dave Moss (Ed Harris) questions why he wastes his time preaching how great salesman he is to us losers. Blake's brash reply, "Cause Mitch and Murray,(The owners) asks me to." In Blake's hands are the New Leads but he indicates you don't get them. Shelley insists the existing leads are a dead end. Blake drives into high gear as he tells them their wimps and that he could close them himself and make $15,000 dollars tonight on those leads. Meanwhile Rick Roma (Al Pacino) is in a local restaurant/bar trying to sell properties to an unsure, indecisive buyer James Lingk (Jonathan Pryce). Roma does a fine job playing on Lingk's insecurities. Making the sale sound like more of an opportunity than a purchase and done quite eloquently. Shelley desperate due to his daughter's health tries to meet with Williamson to get the new leads Bribing Williamson with money he doesn't have. Williamson tells Shelly forget it; no chance as he leaves Shelley in the rain. In an another car Moss meets with another salesman George Aaronow (Alan Arkin) who seems a bit inexperienced at this sales job as Moss has a plan to have George break in the office and steel the new leads and sells them to a competitor. George wants no part of that scheme. We follow Shelley to one of his potential sales but the persons isn't interested in buying. I felt that scene was important to show the frustration and hopeless downward spiral salesmanship can become. The authenticity of the scene shows a last ditch effort for a sale vanquish in failure. Poor over-the- hill Shelley wearing his Fishing hat and raincoat gives you empathy in the Shelley character as the next morning's events will show. Desperation can drive a man to do anything. Alan Arkin's Character shows a believable lack of confidence and tremendous helpings of paranoia. Pacino and Lemmon work well together in the office scenes as authorities close in on the suspect. Spoiler Alert!!! but worth seeing The climactic ending. Lemmon is verbally pounding Spacey against the ropes and this leads to a dramatic turnabout as the Levene character incriminates himself and Spacey has the upper hand. Shelley breaks down in shame would make Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman look minor by comparison. I felt that Spacey had the best lines in the movie among this all-star cast. This reminds me of the Ray Charles song entitled "BUSTED" as one of the lines was ,"I am no thief but a man could go wrong when he's busted. Shelley's desperation lead him down the wrong path as his best years are behind him in many ways . Sorry realistic commentary by screen writer David Mamet.I give this classic movie 7 sets of steak knives.

reviews.review_title: A picture is worth a thousand words; this film deserves every one!
reviews.content: Welcome to the wonderful world of real estate, where the golden rule is "A.B.C., Always Be Closing (Glengarry Glen Ross)." This means lie, cheat, steal and do whatever it takes to "get them to sign on the line which is dotted (Glengarry Glen Ross)." A highly competitive group of real estate salesmen struggle to close deals in a tough market with weak leads. In an effort to motivate the team, corporate bigwigs raise the stakes of the monthly sales contest. Blake (Alec Baldwin), the corporate henchman on a mission to enforce the rules, announces the prize: "First prize is a Cadillac Eldorado. Second prize is a set of steak knives. Third prize is you're fired (Glengarry Glen Ross)." The intense ultimatum is music to the ears of Ricky Roma (Al Pacino) who is the office superstar. However, rivalries erupt under pressure and the office becomes a breeding ground of anxiety, tension and desperation. Shelly Levine (Jack Lemon) clings to his faded glory while the other agents, Dave Moss (Ed Harris) and George Aaronow (Alan Arkin) concoct a profitable scheme to get them back on their feet. When John Williamson (Kevin Spacey), the snide office manager, announces the good leads were taken during a robbery, everyone is a suspect.Glengarry Glen Ross is a splendid film adaptation of David Mamet's 1984 Broadway play, directed by James Foley. This is an exceptionally well-written script with a phenomenal cast that transforms material, which is not inherently cinematic, into an interesting and intriguing film. The film does not rely on special effects to hold the attention of the audience; it achieves this with a natural dialogue that realistically portrays multi-dimensional characters. The characters are complicated with a mix of good and bad in each of them. They banter back and forth, interrupt each other and at times it's hard to tell who's right and who's wrong. These conversations add interest and enhance the reality of the film.Glengarry Glen Ross is not what anyone would consider a feel-good movie, but there is appeal in the testosterone driven behavior of these characters that use memorable lines like razor ribbon to cut each other down. I find it interesting that some have claimed Glengarry Glen Ross is about the "evils of the free-enterprise system." I feel it is more about basic human evolution and survival of the fittest in a cut-throat world. This is evident in the fact that Ricky evolves to be the top-dog and consequently leads his mentor, Shelly, into proverbial extinction. They are all like animals struggling to survive in their environment.David Mamet contributes greatly to the film's success with an exquisite script. However, the attention to detail within the set design is noteworthy because it adds irony and reality to the film. A majority of the film is set within the walls of a drab, depressing office which is filled with inspirational wall hangings containing messages that seem to daunt more than inspire. Additionally, a picture of Shelly Levine's daughter sits on his desk in serene contrast to the all-male cast and surrounding chaos. The irony continues throughout the film and enhances the empathic feeling at the end.Although some feel the performances of Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon stand out among the cast of equals, I disagree. I feel each performance stands out individually without overshadowing the other and allows us to view into each of the character's psyche. Some characters have more time on screen and are more likable than others which may influence opinions. Oddly enough my favorite character is Blake. Blake does not appear in the play, but was added by David Mamet in the film adaptation. He is a heartless narcissist who takes great pleasure in his nefarious behavior and even goes so far as to show everyone his "brass balls". Even though Blake is a man I love to hate, he has some of the most memorable lines in the movie which I have been quoting for years. As I reach for a cup of coffee, I can hear Blake's voice saying: "Coffee is for closers (Glengarry Glen Ross)." The collaborative effort of David Mamet and James Foley produced a film which successfully transitioned a theatrical performance to the screen without losing any of its integrity. The effective use of close-ups keeps the focus on the dialog which is the quintessential element of the film's success.Glengarry Glen Ross. Dir. James Foley. Perf. Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey and Jonathan Pryce. New Line Cinema: 1992, Film.

I am a huge fan of David Mamet. He was required reading way back before he came to the silver screen.This is probably his finest work. What better way to bring it to the movies than with this all-star cast? Pacino, Lemmon, Spacey, Arkin, Ed Harris, and Alec Baldwin! Fabulous.The dialogue, and that's what makes this, is compelling. Sure, cursing is prominent, but the realism is needed to parse this tale of ethics in the business world.For an office story, the action is quick. The story moves. Like all mysteries (if you are unfamiliar with the story), the characters are all suspects.

I've been working in and around phone rooms for several years... if you have any sales experience, you will probably enjoy this movie.It's a cold-hearted, no-frills, no-excuses, and very accurate portrayal of an industry that shocked the hell out of me when I first got into it. This film shows you some of the darkly humorous parts of it: Representatives flat-out lying to customers to make sales, coworkers and management impersonating all sorts of company officials and high-rollers, leads being recycled ad nauseum... the list goes on.Perhaps the funniest part is that the whole premise of this movie -- the reps' utter obsession with leads -- is, unfortunately, the one people who haven't worked in the industry aren't going to fully grasp. It really... is... that... bad.One thing to watch for that's understated a bit is the whole idea of 'defection' from one office to another. They don't spend much time on it here, but it really does happen exactly the way it's described in the movie; I've seen it more than once.If you enjoy a lot of interesting dialogue, if you love to watch a really well-acted play, if you know how it is to work (REALLY work) in sales, or if you've ever been pitched by an overly enthusiastic telemarketer, you'll find something in this movie to enjoy.

Some tips for anyone who had difficulty with this film (from a guy who gained an appreciation for it after his first viewing):Don't go into it expecting a traditional three-act structure with rising/falling action and a resounding conclusion. This is more of a "show about nothing" a la Seinfeld (and even Catcher in the Rye). We're basically just following these quirky characters to see what crazy thing they'll do next.Another lens through which you can view this film: I suspect that Mamet penned this story as a form of therapy. It just seems "too real" to be pure fiction. I think it was cathartic for him to write it, and could potentially be therapeutic for anyone else who's had an awful, high-pressure, job.

The single greatest cameo scene in cinema history only sets up the desperation of career land salesmen and their holding on for that next great sale. The art, the manliness, the accumulated hardened toughness of sales is on display for common folk to suffer through. Not only does the all star cast perform like all stars (every one of them) but their on screen persona's get deeper with each studied viewing. There really is no action to speak of in this adapted play, but tons of brilliant drama, braggadocio salesmanship, old school war stories and an arsenal of f-bombs are deployed to keep you on edge. Put that coffee down! Coffee is for closers!

reviews.review_title: Sensational acting but the plot leaves something to be desired
reviews.content: Anyone who has ever worked in a sales office, in particular a real estate sales office (as I have), we'll really appreciate this movie. The cut-throat competitive dog-eat-dog environment, the pompous slick-tongued swindling salespeople, the tense atmosphere, the wise-ass barbs being heaved back and forth.. it's all so over-the-top, but it's all so real. You can point to every single individual in this movie and say 'hey, I know I guy like that!'. From the smooth-talking salesman who would say anything to get a deal, to the once-successful burnt out guy trying to maintain his job and his sanity, to the inept no-so-bright kind who doesn't really belong in the business to begin with, to the goody-goody kiss-ass office manager, to the arrogant schmuck of a boss... it is all so perfectly placed.The acting in this film is right-on, not overacted and not underacted, and it has the feel of a real sales office, and how ugly things can get after something has gone awry. When everyone is trying to save their own skin, all of a sudden, old allegiances become murky, all the dirty laundry is aired, and people will say or do almost anything to get themselves out of trouble.But in the end, it is really the incredible performances of this star-studded cast that save this film, which has a great script but a very weak plot. This is very much a character-driven piece, with superb scenes created out of great dialouges and confrontations, skillfully acted out with subtle body language. This is definitely not an action-driven piece, and as mentioned, not much of a story per se. But the realistic and oh-so-ugly depiction of what happens to a business in which everyone's chasing the mighty buck with no concern for good-old fashioned ethics and loyalty, makes this movie quite a worthwhile piece of entertainment.

reviews.review_title: By far the best Mamet movie out there
reviews.content: David Mamet is a brilliant writer.  His movies are always intense and funny, cool and dramatic.  Although, I have to say, when I heard that this was a movie about selling real estate I thought it'd be a boring, uninteresting film.  I was wrong."Glengarry Glen Ross" starts with the loud, obnoxious Blake (Alec Baldwin) arriving at Williamson's (Kevin Spacey) firm and telling the sellers (Lemmon, Pacino, Harris and Arkin) about a new contest.  Whoever of the four sells the most real estate in the next week will get the "new leads", the leads that will almost certainly sell.  The next morning they find that the leads are stolen and they must find out who did it.First off, the acting in this film is perfect.  Baldwin may only be in the film for ten minutes, but he steals the show (and your attention) for every frame that he is on screen.  Lemmon's "Shelley Levene" is sadly pathetic, you really feel sorry for him.  Pacino's Ricky Roma is an interesting character, and Harris and Arkin play off each other perfectly.Best Mamet thriller out there, 9/10.

.......essentially one of those live '50's TV dramas on the big screen. You have to put up w/ the play conventions-lotttttts of longwinded dramatics, not much action, verbal jousting, and the Mamet specialty-a  four-letter word barrage.All this is forgiven. This was one of the best casts I have ever seen-Pacino, Spacey, Lemmon, Arkin, Harris, fine 5 minute blast of Alec Baldwin, heck even the baddie from 'Ronin' and all those Infiniti ads-Pryce-shows up. I don't have much to add to the other comments here-I think it could have been a little better plot-wise, sure-but the acting/stars involved, were great. Don't forget Alan Arkin here-quite good in his under-stated way.***1/2 outta ****

reviews.review_title: Even when you aren't in sales, you should give this movie a try
reviews.content: Being a salesman myself, I was very interested in this movie. It doesn't happen every day that you get to see a movie about your own profession (except for when you are a drugs dealer, a spy or a lawyer of course) and I really wanted to see how Hollywood sees it and what they make of it. But "Glengarry Glen Ross" is more than just a movie about salesmen, it's also a movie about deception, theft, anxiety, rage,... for every human feeling, except perhaps for love, there is place in this movie.Business isn't going well at John Williamson's real estate office. The sales numbers are too low and the salesmen aren't very motivated, because they believe they haven't received any good leads (the addresses of potential buyers). But than Blake comes in, one of the founders of the firm, and he has a proposition to make. He'll give an incentive to succeed in a sales contest that will last for only one week. The first price is a luxurious car and the "golden" Glengarry leads that he brought in with him, the second price a set of steak knives, the third or fourth price means that you'll get fired. Because there is no place for losers and because only the man who is able to close the most deals will get better leads, the competition and the tension raise to a boiling point. Immediately after Blake has left the office, propositions for deals and robbery arise, but all behind Ricky Roma's back, the very best salesman in the office. When the next morning the four employees show up at the firm, they find out that the Glengarry leads have been stolen. Williamson is desperate to find out who did it and now all salesmen face even more tension and difficulties...Even though this isn't always exactly the way how life as a salesman is (at least not where I work, but I admit that there are places where it does get very close to the situations in the movie), this movie gives an excellent idea of the stress and the tension that we have to go through from time to time. Especially at the end of the month when you haven't reached your target yet, life can be pretty hectic. And the incentive program is common practice as well, although I've never heard of a place where the third or the fourth would get fired.But those are just minor details, what is more important is the fact that this is a very suspenseful drama with some powerful acting. That's exactly what everybody expects with a cast like this one of course, but it isn't automatically true that when you have people like Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin in your cast, that everything will work out perfectly. In this case it did, but that's also thanks to the story that has been well-written. David Mamet sure knows how to build up tension, how to give enough depth to the different characters and how to keep the viewer's attention.Even when you aren't in sales, I think this movie deserves a try. If it isn't for the fine story, than you should definitely give it a try for the top cast that gives away a very good performance. I give this movie a 7.5/10.

It was so bad, I turned it off after 43 minutes. I tried, I really tried to watch it, but it just sucked. Great actors YES! Great acting, maybe? Great movie, no... horrible movie.P. S. I've watched literally thousands of movies in my life, and I probably turned off about 20 mid film... this was one of them. I usually give every movie a chance, and I gave this one 43 minutes. That was enough.

An exceptional cast of actors giving exceptional performances. Glengarry Glen Ross is a dialogue-heavy, exposition-light character focused, day in the life of a thoroughly seedy New York sales office. Desperation runs deep and is captured expertly as the characters navigate the power dynamics between each other and the sales company they all work for. The life of a salesman has never looked so grimy unappealing and unrewarded. The dialogue is snappy and hard and almost every exchange is loaded with bitterness and cynicism. There is a lot of humour but there is no hope to be seen anywhere except the futile dream of one day accessing the "good leads". Despite its bleak outlook it succeeds as a phenomenally well written and acted film that is immensely rewatchable.

People told me this movie was great.  I even knew that is was based off of a good play.  However, once the actually movie starts, the profanities start to fly.  Unfortunately this is the only memorable part of the movie (i forgot most of the plot).  The actors are so-so.  The storyline about competing salesman for a job is ok.  The most inane thing is the language, which is partially expected given the movies theme, but there are limits. The same content could have been said other ways, without relying on the profanities to convey the felling of the movie (and that is what they do).

Let's not forget that movies are supposed to entertain us.This film features an absolutely first-rate cast, with terrific acting by all involved.  Jack Lemmon, especially, stands out.  In addition, it creates a real atmosphere with the office and the constantly pouring rain.However, this is a film that has virtually no plot, a minimal story, and not much to make us care about any of the characters.  Alec Baldwin makes a drive-by appearance ... he's in and out in about three minutes.Overall, there's a lot to admire in terms of technical merit, but this is not a very enjoyable movie.

This is a great story that Mamet shows with his dialogue and the film makers retained some of the visual elements of the theater with a minimal change in sets. It is a tragic story of real estate salesmen struggling to close that deal. Mamet develops great characters with great performances by Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, and Alec Baldwin.

"Glengarry Glen Ross" is a film that might have taken home a lot of Oscars, but it came out the same year as "Unforgiven" and that Clint Eastwood movie ended up being the big winner.The story is based on a play by David Mamet and has an absolutely incredible cast. Imagine...the film features great actors like Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey, Ed Harris, Al Pacino, Alan Arkin, Jonathan Pryce and Alec Baldwin (in his best performance)!The story is mostly set in a sales office for some planned community. Apparently, the big bosses aren't happy with sales and have sent a hot shot salesman to try to motivate the sales staff. But Blake (Alec Baldwin) is an abusive monster and instead of encouraging them with positive reinforcement, he thinks fear and nastiness are the best motivators. He promises the sales staff a brand new Cadillac for the month's top salesman, a rinky dink prize for the second best...and termination for everyone else! He also manages to treat the employees like garbage at every opportunity and induces a climate of fear. What's next? See the story and see how each man reacts...and how they lie, cheat and steal in order to keep their miserable jobs."Glengarry Glen Ross" is NOT a film for everyone. First, the language is very crude...so it's probably not a film to show your kids or mother. Second, while the film is great showing human nature at its worst, the movie is NOT an action-packed one. In fact, most of the film is very talky...as you might expect from a film based on a play. Still, if you can look past these things, the movie is well worth seeing and features a bunch of fine actors in a fine tale.

reviews.review_title: Finally understood the real power when I got a job...
reviews.content: I remember seeing this film when I was about 15, I was drawn in by the cast and I recall thinking it was really cool,but for me there was something missing.Re-watching it again at the age of 30, having worked for a decade of my life, I finally understand what it was all about. Truly a film for ..."anyone who has ever worked for a living." The sniping, schmoozing, back biting, fragile allegiances, determination to be the best over colleagues, vulgarity, desperation, etc. all finally made sense. A stunning film from start to finish, dredging up memories of your own working life. The characters might be composites of your own experiences. Perhaps one day you are Pacino,top of the world and flying high, the next day Lemmon, confused and failing, the next day Ed Harris, frustrated and raging at the world. Spacey is only doing his job, maybe that's why at times he comes across so fragile and weak. And Alec Baldwin is the stuff of nightmares, the "brass balls" from downtown storming in to tell us how insecure our futures are.Brilliant.

It seems incredible to me given the cast, that this film could be as dull as it actually was. The primary reason for this was the plot, namely there wasn't one. In the last twenty minutes you hear something about a robbery but believe me, by then you will probably just be so desperate for the film to end.I had heard so much about the 'incredible script' and 'brilliant acting'. Well I don't know about you, but I don't consider shouting every line for two hours great acting. While the script consisted of about a million swear words, and if you can discern anything else from it you're a genius. The only people who say this is a great film are those who aspire to sounding intelligent and being 'academic'. To those people I say just be honest and admit that this film is terrible. The director was clearly trying to be arty by not having a plot and hoping that everyone would just assume that they didn't get it if they disliked it, well judging by the amount of positive reviews here it worked. Take my advice, do not waste two hours of your life on this film, I did but you still have a chance to escape!

Film freaks, like myself, have their favorite actor, director, writer, etc. A few filmmakers have an instantly recognizable style that has defined them. David Mamet is one of them. Even to someone who has never seen a Mamet movie or play, it will most definitely be clear that there's something about the dialogue in this movie that separates it from everything else.While I certainly won't say that Mamet is a bad writer (in fact, he has a tremendous gift with the written word), I can't say that I am a fan. Particularly in this movie, he's very wordy, and that can make the story hard to follow. While the dialogue is crisp and poetic, the strands of dialogue are so long and colorful that it can make the plot hard to follow. I guess that many will find that okay since plot is really inconsequential in a movie like this.It's basically about a group of salesman who are trying to sell the most real estate to save their jobs. The bottom two salesmen by the end of the week will be fired. Immediately after the men find out about their predicament, the new leads, which are key to making a sale, have been stolen. Here it turns into a mixture of subtle whodunit and "Death of a Salesman." It's got to be amazing to see such a high profile cast in one movie where they all get to create new and original characters without having to resort to 90% of the roles being cameos (Alec Baldwin being an exception). While the acting is terrific (Jack Lemmon and Alan Arkin are especially good), it's not what it aspires to be. Still, I'm not going to stop someone from checking it out if they want to.

reviews.review_title: A ruthless and brilliantly acted ensemble piece
reviews.content: This is one of those rare films where it looks like the cast (all male in this case) are all at their best. Each one of the actors in this film is brilliant. The film focuses on a land and property sales office, and the various salesman and their problems. I think the most affecting and memorable performance is the one by Jack Lemmon. He plays Shelley 'The Machine' Levene, an arguing salesman in a bad streak, whose sales technique is slipping. He is desperate and needs good leads from his boss, Williamson (Kevin Spacey). Some of the scenes where he has to beg in the rain to him, and the final scene, make us feel sympathetic to him. The hot shot in the office is Ricky Roma, played by Al Pacino (who was Oscar nominated for his performance), he's a guy on a hot streak and can do no wrong, it seems. There's a great scene where Williamson reveals a secret to one of Roma's customers, then when the customer leaves the room Roma lets off one of the great tirades in cinema history. The other guys in the office are played by an acerbic Ed Harris as Dave Moss, who's in a bad streak, and laconic Alan Arkin as George. There is also a memorable motivative speech to all the guys from a ruthless Alec Baldwin, who tells them all to "Get Mad!". A brilliant piece of ensemble acting with many memorable scenes. One of the greats.

But it leaves you asking at the end "So what?" Really, so what? The acting was good, the cast was spectacular, and even the script was fine (even if it was loaded with too many curse words). I just feel that a film should never leave you thinking that question. A film should never ever ever do that to the viewer. Which to me is interesting only from the standpoint that any Mamet film I've ever watched has never done that. Not House of Games, not Heist, not even Spartan. So why this film? I suppose it's due to the fact that the audience wants some kind of justice for these dreary souls and they don't get any. Even Spacey's character, who is a jackass by the way, isn't taken down for his bad managing skills and complete lack of salesmanship knowledge. At least give us Baldwin's character's head or somebody halfway important. The feeling that all of these guys were monumental losers with the possible exception of Pacino's Romo just weighed you down and gave you a mixed feeling of disgust and shame. If this is what being a salesman is cracked up to be, then I'm relieved I have never been one.

I tried 3 times to watch this and each time I found it worse than before.It's such a lousy movie it's not worth reviewing.Lousy and lousy and lousy.The leads, the leads, the leads, the leads...who gives a rat's ass after 4 minutes in?A bland film that's worthy of nothing but putting people to sleep on the couch.

I recently took the time to watch GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS and remembered how when the movie came out in 1992, much was said about the constant profanity used in the film, especially the "F" word. I have read other sources and I would find it believable that in real life, people like the characters depicted would constantly be swearing. That aside, I found the movie to be very thought provoking as it basically shows what happens to people when they are desperate. For a little background, this film was originally a play by David Mamet and frankly, I essentially found this movie to be a play that was filmed. Also, this was an all-star cast with Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin among others. For those readers who have not seen the film, the basic premise is that Alec Baldwin plays a hotshot in the company who tells all the workers that if they don't begin to close any new deals soon, they will be out of a job. For the most part, the office workers find the new leads to be worthless. Therefore, they become desperate and will do whatever they can to get ahead even if it means lie, cheat and steal. What impressed me about the film is how it showed that nobody cares how much experience one might have; all that matters is "Can one get the results?" To show an example of this, Jack Lemmon played Shelley "The Machine" Levine who was an experienced sales man and had gotten results in the past. However, it did not seem to matter since he did not seem to be getting the same results now. Also, the film showed other "typical" type of workers that people could relate to such as Al Pacino's Ricky Roma who was the hotshot in the office and felt he was the one to win all the rewards. To me, Ed Harris's character came across to me as someone who was not really a bad person but turned to less than honest means because he was desperate. Kevin Spacey's character (the office manager John Williams) seemed to me like the person trying to keep order in the office and did not have too much sympathy towards anyone. Alec Baldwin's role was very effective as the big shot who wanted to scare everyone. Just about anyone can say they have had an employer at one point or another who acted that way. In conclusion, I might suggest that the viewer might want to watch this film a second time because even though it is not very long, there is a lot that goes on. Personally, I felt the movie made more sense to me on my second viewing of it.

reviews.review_title: "you never open your mouth 'till you know what the shot is"
reviews.content: This movie is so spectacular! i am speechless, i wouldn't know where to start if i wanted to praise it. Every single actor in this movie is amazing (and you can see what great titans we're talking about: Lemon, Pacino, Spacey, Harris). This masterpiece is not about sales, it's about the big players, the big game, about guts and maximum intelligence. This is what should be used for teaching in drama classes, this is pure art, real class and exquisite talent. If you watch closely you can see a hundred emotions per minute displayed on Lemon or Pacino's faces; you can do that just by observing their body language. Glengarry Glen Ross is my favorite movie right now and nobody should delay watching it, i mean nobody.

I accidentally stumbled across this movie when I was channel surfing and I am glad I did that. Luckily the start cast caught my eye and I was able to catch the movie from the beginning. What a powerful movie. I consider a movie powerful when you don't stop thinking about the movie for a long time after you have seen the movie and it moves you in a certain way.This movie made me think about the ruthlessness of the corporate world where anything goes as long as you achieve. Though this movie concentrates on selling real estate, I hope some one makes a movie how only 'connections' not the real talent can advance you in the corporate world. It also proves how you should be conscience free and should forget about your family if you want to really grow. Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris , Alec Baldwin all give a very powerful performance as conscience free salesmen and motivators. Alec Baldwin provides a very powerful performance of a ruthless motivator. On one hand whether you feel sorry for the plight of these salesmen. I almost yelled "common man quit the f***ing job" to Ed Harris during Alec Baldwin's motivating speech. Sorry for the profanity but you automatically get into that kind of language as you watch this movie. This is another example how powerful this movie is. On the other hand you feel angry the way they cheat common men of their hard earned money.I completely agree with other members comment that this should be in one of the top 200 films. This film reminds me of 12 Angry me which was another master piece solely dependent upon powerful acting, script and dialog delivery. Jonathan Pryce has turned in a very subtle but excellent performance as a hapless common man who fall prey to these aggressive sellers.Overall a very great movie that you should not miss.

reviews.review_title: A true cult movie... Supreme acting, just perfect
reviews.content: "Glengarry Glenn Ross" has to be one of the best independent projects I've ever seen (if not the best one). The plot is character based, and man, those characters, played by some of Hollywood's best actors, are fascinating. Al Pacino, Baldwin, Kevin Spacy and Jack Lemon just nail their parts, it's like they picked the perfect guys to play the perfect roles. Pacino is the charismatic, most successful real-estate salesman, who's had a good streak lately. Baldwin is the ruthless manager from the top office who comes for 10 minutes and attacks all the office staff in an offensive, yet very effective way. Jack Lemon is a veteran salesman, with his best days of sales behind him, desperate to make some very unlikely deals. And Kevin Spacey, well, he's just perfect as the indifferent, passive boss, who just doesn't care about anything but obeying orders from above. The story is not complicated, but it's very effective, and the supreme acting just blew me away. It's one of those rare films, that you'll remember for a long time. Some people complained about the use of profanity all throughout the film (a LOT of cursing), but I think that's what makes the scenes seem real - because the cursing, and harsh language emphasize the huge stress that all the salesmen are under 24/7.

Times are tough in a Chicago real-estate office. The salesmen are given a strong profane incentive by a Baldwin to succeed in a sales contest. The First prize is a Cadillac, second is a set of steak knives, third is as above. There is no room for losers in this world, and only "closers" will get the good sales leads. There is a lot of pressure to succeed, so a robbery is committed which has unforeseen consequences for all the characters.....Mamet has a wonderful,way of using profanity, so it goes unnoticed after a while, the amount of bad language being used by all and sundry. But it's an electric film, absolutely awe inspiring from beginning to end, and Mamet has captured the essence of every single kind of caricature you'd find in this sort of environment.The cast are as wonderful as you'd expect, and Baldwin really is that good. The tension rises and rises throughout, and you come to realise that these people who call you up all confident and full of buzzwords, are just running on empty, and are as desperate as anyone else.Even Baldwin, all mouth in his short scene, shows off about his salary, his watch, and his car, someone like that has self esteem issues.A brilliant portrayal of working life, and knowing when your time is up.

reviews.review_title: A primer in acting and playwriting
reviews.content: This movie defines the concept of ensemble acting. Not a word or gesture out of place. Everyone working at peak. In any just and fair world, "Glengarry" should have garnered every award they can throw at a motion picture. A superlative piece of film-making with fully realized characters and dead-on interplay. Perfectly paced and absolutely real. The casting is impeccable.If an actor's calling is the search for truth within the character then we've got your truth RIGHT HERE. Big, hairy, testosterone-laden back-stabbing red-meat TRUTH. Mamet's play is an American classic which should be taught in the syllabus along with "Death Of A Salesman". And this cast gives the play its due, and then some.

There are so many great actors in this film and they all do a fantastic job sucking you into their hectic, high-pressure sales world.I work with sales people ( In IT) and while we are not selling real estate, there are so many parallels from my day to day to this film. From the pressure, to the way one needs to manage their mouths around customers, this film nails it.Among all of the great actors in this film, Jack Lemmon stands out. He runs the full range of human emotions in this film and he is %100 believable. He is a legend.

The story unfolds almost entirely in the confines of a small dingy sales office. The goal: win the company sales contest. But this is no ordinary sales contest.  Management wants to cut back and weed out the underachievers.  The winners keep their jobs and just might get a new car to sweaten the deal.  The losers "hit the bricks" because "they're going down!".We're all familiar enough with being the victims of cold calls, poromotional junk mail, etc., but here, we see the pain of the other side and quickly become sympathetic to their plight.  Mamet lets us become so sympathetic he almost pulls us into each and every scene, making us cringe when a sale is blown or when a lead goes nowhere.I could go on and on about story details, the "coffee is for closers" scene, the awesome scene with Pacino trying to sell real estate to Pryce, etc., etc., but I'll just say this is one of the top films of the nineties and will surely be remembered as a great film in movie history.One other thing, the music by Wayne Shorter is as good as the acting and perfectly sets the mood for the film.  Sadly, the soundtrack is no longer available.

Some plays transferred to film lose a lot of the interpersonal play between characters and the fundamental nature of the story is changed. This is certainly not the case here. The scenes and character interactions could almost be transferred to a theatre with little to no change. This, in my opinion, is the only way to adapt a stage play to a movie.The story itself is a very gritty and tense interplay between a group of real estate salesmen who have been given an order by their boss "close a sale or your fired" (played wonderfully by Alec Baldwin). What happens next is a study in the worst of human traits.As I stated initially, the great thing about this movie is the interplay between the characters. It is a film that is basically about the dialogue and for the dialogue. One I would highly recommend.

For the acting ensemble alone this movie is a 10/10. Put together some of the best writing and fantastic editing, and you've got the formula of a winner.Each actor gets their chance to tear up the screen. But even while the actors interact on screen, none of them steals the show. Talk about an ensemble working together. The confidence and chemistry from shot to shot will bring a smile to your face.The writing is fierce and fast. You want to see a movie where even curse words carry meaning? This is it. Alec Baldwin is in the film for maybe seven minutes, but the writing in those seven minutes chews up the set. On top of everything, the set makeup is amazing. The whole film takes place in three locales and yet not once does it become static.This is vastly underrated movie because it doesn't appeal to your average movie fan. But if you have good taste, you will like this movie, guaranteed.

reviews.review_title: They can make 'em like they used to, after a fashion.
reviews.content: In reading IMDd comments on the Sydney Lumet film "12 Angry Men," I saw a comment or two about how such films are not made much anymore.  This referred to films that are character-driven, plot-driven, require no special effects, and feature no heavy armament.  It occurred to me that "Glengarry Glen Ross," a recent favorite of mine, could be considered such a film. While the level of testosterone, vitriol, and profanity not only rivals, but outdoes the average modern action film, it is a completely different animal. I only knew the title from a rather old-fashioned friend of mine who had been to see the original play in Chicago.  His only reaction was to complain about the foul language.  I was not particularly interested in seeing this movie until I was in a video store and the clerk started playing it.  Just listening to (not even seeing) the scene with Alec Baldwin made it impossible for me to concentrate on browsing until the scene was over, and I immediately bought a copy of the video.  There's not much I can add to the other comments on how uniformly superb the cast is, but that brief performance by Baldwin (whom I've always been rather indifferent to) is really riveting, even shocking.  Every time I complain about my job I think of this scene, and try to put it in perspective.  Also, nobody is better than Jack Lemmon at playing desperate characters, and this performance is a knockout.  Is the foul language realistic?  I really don't know.  My experience in the business world is limited to zilch.  I don't care much for gratuitous profanity in films (for instance, I think Kathy Bates' character's frequent use of it in "Primary Colors" was a bit tiresome), but I don't mind it if it's valid, and in GGR it struck me as entirely believable.  This verbal violence is every bit as intense as the blood and guts you see splattered on the modern movie screen.  Whether or not it really happens in the business world, for me it rang true in the context of this film, and hasn't language always been manipulated and stylized in drama with the aim of achieving the right effect?  I doubt that the average Elizabethan age individual spoke in Shakespearean verse.

Great performance Jack lemmon
And it's a wonderful drama movie

This film based on a critically acclaimed play is one of the most real films I have ever seen. It shows the underbelly of who we are as people but do not want to admit. To see this film is to see the death of us all as we slowly degrade from smart ass young men into middle aged denial and finally , fossilized fools. Regardless of whether you are an actual 'used vacuum ' salesmen or we work in a hospital, we are all salespeople to someone and something. All of us play angles and shovel small talk each and every day. As we see the bull crap flying out of these guys mouths, we comfort ourselves that the vulgarity separates us from them and thus we aren't as bad as these guys. Its not about vulgarity or being a salesman. Its about stress. The film holds up a mirror of ourselves under enormous stress and we thank god we very rarely are. The plot in this script is the weakest part. Its too simplistic and shouldn't be able to carry an entire film. Its basically a bunch of guys in a lousy job whose life gets worse to the point of desperation. Each man deals with it in their own way. Just like each on of us deals with our own world , in our own version of heaven or hell, depending on how we view our lives.In this case, these men's lives are versions of hell. Each one is at loathe with themselves and therefore blames everyone and everything around them for their plight. One of them states he wont live in hell of earth, but even he disintegrates into a childish brat whose personal character is nothing like the image he tries to portray. The acting is the movie. It is unbelievably good. Both Alex Baldwin and Jack Lemmon give scenes that rival any they have had in their careers. Al Pacino has been so good in so many movies I cannot tell how good he was in this movie. He was good but by his standards I don't know. Alan Arkin drew the short straw when it came to casting. He had the part of a lovable loser who everyone likes but nobody respects. The most despicable character (besides Baldwin) belongs to Ed Harris. He is brilliant but a bit too loud as David Moss , who is ambitious , frustrated and fed up. But he is no fool. The lucky part goes to Kevin Spacey, who was jumping up and down with utter delight to be selected to be on the same screen as his hero Lemmon , and be considered at such a young age to be able to hold his own with some of the greatest character actors in Hollywood history. It must of rubbed off on young Spacey, as his mediocre performance in this film would springboard into academy award winning roles in several films after wards, making himself into an acting legend in his own right. Unlike most of Hollywood, this film has no hero, no real villain and no justice in the end. Its what we see every day. Ordinary people wishing they were somewhere else and someone else. Regular folks making bad decisions, and wallowing in the consequences. The movie left me feeling so much gratitude for the little integrity I was lucky enough to maintain in my own life.

Pressure cooker of a movie about four real-estate salesmen working out of an office in Sheepshed Bay Brooklyn trying to hang on to their jobs as their world starts to collapses on them. Lumpkin Mitch & Murray, the Wall Street real-estate conglomerate, is not too happy about the production of that branch and sends down one of their top honcho's Mr. Blake, Alic Baldwin, to motivate the men to get the ball rolling and start putting dollars on the blackboard.In a pep talk that leaves the crew panic-stricken Blake tells them if they don't start to sell real-estate and get the office out of debt only one of them will be left working for the firm by the end of the month, the one who has the most sales. Blake gives the manager of the office John Williamson, Kevin Spacey,a list of valuable live leads, people who are very likely to buy, and tells him to give them out to the most productive salesman who's on top of the blackboard, in money earned, by the end of the day. with that the men who are drowning see a lifeline and will do anything that they can, right or wrong, to grab it. Explosive performances all around with everyone in the cast giving it all they've got in a great movie about salesmen on par with "Death of a Salesman". Al Pacino, Ricky Roma, as the hot shot salesman of the office who ran into a stroke of luck and seemed to be coasting along until he found out that it takes more then talk and buying drinks for a client to get the check to clear. There's Jack Lemmon, Shelley Levene, the offices former #1 salesman who's hit on hard times and is up the creek with bills piling up and his sick daughter in danger of being discharged from the hospital because Shelley can't pay the expenses.There's Alan Arkin, George Aaronow, who's been so battered and beaten over the last few grueling weeks trying to sell real-estate over the phone that he's taken on a defeatist posture about the whole real-estate business and seems to be just waiting for the ax to fall. There's Ed Harris, Dave Moss, who's brash and aggressive and willing to do anything that he can to keep his job even if it's of the criminal nature. And last but not least, Kevin Stacey, John Williamson, the office manager who's in charge of those men but you won't know it by the abuse that he takes from them, especially Mr. Roma, and wounder why he would want a job like that in the first place. Intelligent baiting and realistic that doesn't let up for a moment with a stunning and heart wrenching ending that guarantees not to disappoint the audience. With the manager John Williamson showing those working for him, who have been taking him lightly as well as ruthlessly abusing and insulting him throughout the entire movie, who's the boss.

This movie seems to be a perfect illustration of what is wrong with contemporary "competitiveness" culture. A higher ranking salesmen, Blake, comes to a small real-estate office to motivate/terrorize salesmen of that office for a better performance. Blake is a nightmare of an office worker. A higher ranking salesmen that comes up with impossible demands and turns coworkers into enemies and their clients into preys. But Blake is not only a nightmare but also a dream, ego-ideal of every salesman. He is a nightmare as another and dream as oneself. As a perfect embodiment of corporate culture, Blake expresses a deep contradiction within that culture itself. Actors' performance is something that is definitely worth mentioning as an additional factor. Acting is nearly perfect.

I don't know if anyone can really define what makes a movie good. Or bad. Or great. We either like something or we don't. If there were a simple definition, then there would be a step-by-step formula to follow, and all movies would be great. Of course, they are not. But surely one commonality to all great movies is that we are able to forget that we are watching a movie at all. In Glengarry Glen Ross, we are able to do this very quickly. You are not watching some very big name actors playing pretend, reciting memorized lines from a script, taking direction from someone off screen. You are looking at and listening to road weary, flat footed, brow beaten salesmen. More than that even, you are living the life of a real-estate salesman with them. You're not in some crowded theater, staring up at a screen, your actually in that cramped little office, with a mean boss, a gnawing fear for the next dollar,and some intangible loneliness. Simple, subtle, superb, and sublime. After enjoying it once, watch it again just to see the master Jack Lemon putting on a clinic, and you'll see that Kevin Spacey was paying attention. What he learned, of course, culminating in "American Beauty". Hmmm, maybe there is a formula...

This is a truly enthralling drama. I'd never really cared much for Jack Lemmon, but in this film he is terrific, as are all the cast. Baldwin is only in the film 10 minutes, but it's far and away the best work he's done...heck, it's the only thing I remember him actually being in!David Mamet was in sparkling form when he wrote this.

Glengarry Glen Ross is simply one of the best films that I have ever seen. Other reviewers are 100% correct in their evaluations.  Jack Lemmon gives the performance of a lifetime, I felt that he should have at LEAST been nominated for an Oscar.  This is one of those movies that comes around very infrequently. There are no sex scenes, explosions, gunfights, or kung-fu(most of which I like to have in my movies).  Just wonderful dialogue and acting that is levels above most films that come out. Most movies that come out--no matter how good they may be, I will watch one time and don't care if I see them again.  GGR, I can watch again and again, it is that good!  10 out of 10 stars!

reviews.review_title: I don't see what everyone is so excited about
reviews.content: I just watched this on netflix the other day and I was not impressed at all. In fact, I found my self shaking my head the entire time thinking "yeah right." The movie is little more than overacting and a bunch of men calling each other names. I mean, really, is that how a typical office functions from day to day? I mean, maybe you'd see a little bit of this with real estate sales men, but this was just ridiculous. I understand that if you make many movies too realistic they can get a little boring, but this was just way over the top. If they wanted to hire the best actors and get some amazing performances out of everyone, at least make it in a setting where screaming insults back and fourth and people freaking the h*ll out is a little more realistic.I also found it interesting that there isn't a female character in the entire movie except perhaps "coat check girl" who I saw listed in the credits. This was obviously intended to be a man's movie.The only good thing about this movie is how they portray salesmen trying to get deals, lying to their clients and acting very desperate, etc. If it weren't for the fact that I found this movie to be so mediocre, I probably would have enjoyed the actual plot a little more. Jack Lemon did also do a pretty good job.

reviews.review_title: Glengarry Glen Ross - FInest Sales Film of All Time
reviews.content: There is no other film in the history of Hollywood that even remotely comes close to being the sales film that Glengarry Glen Ross is. Whenever I teach marketing and sales to my college students in China, I always make references to this film, and even assign it on occasion. As the Chinese real estate market is roughly four times more competitive than the US market (four times the population), anyone from my classes going into real estate must be ready for some rough bumps.The great ensemble cast here does a great job with the intense David Mamet dialogue. This is one of Mamet's three masterpieces for the screen; he did The Untouchables and House of Games as well. House of Games is my favorite, but this film is close behind. Remember that line ;"Third place is you're fired!"

In order to make a good movie or a gripping drama, it is not necessary to appeal fiction: reality is enough to get you stick to your seat.The point of the movie is how the sellers manage to close their sales. Depending on the character of each, we can see how they try to close a sale, and also the problems that brings this fact. Ultimately, it's about survival.This is one of the movies that i watched which is quite similar to a theater play. There are three different stages where the movie takes place: business office, bar, and street.The film is shot mostly by night ,and the soundtrack is an excellent jazz music by Wayne Shorter. Both features helps to create a dark atmosphere, along with the rain.The plot is simple, but includes some twists: there's a lot of dialog in the movie, and we must not lose sight on what the actors say. The script is one of the best i saw in a movie: superb.9/10

Glengarry Glen Ross is a masterful creation not to be missed by any film lover. This is an unique movie where the almost non existent plot and the limited scenery (almost every scene takes place either in an office or in a bar) are eclipsed by some of the most powerful acting one could ever experience in any film (credit goes, of course, to the immense cast that they managed to put together). Of course, anyone who has enjoyed films such as Dog Day Afternoon, Twelve Angry Men, or even Reservoir Dogs, will find this kind of play-based or resembling-to-a-play movie really entertaining, if not just plain brilliant. It's hard to understand why it's not sitting on the top with these other mentioned pictures. There's not a scene too long, there's not a scene too many. And it is believable. To sum up, if one can stand a movie without big explosions or eerily long Hollywood kisses, this film represents a high point in the late XX century's acting, and should be considered, in my opinion, in any "Top movies" list.

No, no and one more time no. Booooring, snoozy and pretentious 100 minute long rant about nothing.Just constant macho-swearing of a bunch of pri.cks, interminably arguing over non-important stuff without any wit, joy or point.Spare yourself the time on this one, go cook yourself a wholesome meal.

Combine Grade A dialog with an ensemble cast seen once in a generation, and you get "Glengarry Glen Ross." Al Pacino alone is worth watching for what he can do with a first rate script. Michael Corleone? Good. But this is the master class.

Seriously, awesome movie. It's all talk & drama but the director, James Foley, made it so incredibly intriguing, suspenseful, and deep, it's worth watching completely.Yes, Pacino steals the scenes he's in, but not too much, really.This is a great movie to watch anytime. Ya know, some movies can only be watched at night, say, on the weekends, and etc, but this puppy is good whenever you please.To make a good drama you NEED good actors and a perfect, and precise script which this movie had all of. If you've been in sales before, you can relate to a lot in this movie. You can relate and understand the incredible amount of tension and dis-belief sometimes that this movie exploits perfectly.Their is a good bit of language, which some say, "not worthwhile", but I think it fits in well. I mean, come on, you have to cuss when things are on this line so often. Great composing, nice jazzy feel in the background, I could not imagine better music for this movie. Just stop reading this and buy it.

Certainly a very particular film that teaches how even with a very sparse plot and no memorable scene you can still make a good film thanks above all to the masterful interpretations of all the actors. The film has the great advantage of entertaining the spectator without ever letting him take his eyes off the screen and does all this without anything striking to capture the attention but still captures it a lot. Also thanks to the very normal peculiarity of this plot, the film holds up very well by carrying on the story of several employees in complete despair given the events in their career and we see their reactions based on what they believe is right or wrong.

reviews.review_title: This Film Really Shows That A Great Cast Can Truly Bring A Film Which Is Boring On Paper To Cult Status
reviews.content: well, i am not much of an expert on screenplays,stage plays,adaptations and whatnot & i am what you would call of the 'scarface fantasy' generation.However,i was first inspired to watch this film after hearing funny mp3 playbacks of al pacinos profanity and memorable quotes from the film on sound boards.I then tracked down a copy of the special edition DVD (the normal version is atrocious with choppy borders).To My delight i discovered a movie which not only transformed my view of what makes a good film, but also made me appreciate much older actors of our time, in this case jack lemmon.The first time i watched this i was baffled by all the technical salesmen jargon, but after watching a few times i rated this movie heavily and understood everything.Alec Baldwin instantly draws the viewer in as the 'ironic' motivation speaker at the beginning of the film & it was then i knew i was watching a quality performance led movie. As many comments on IMDb state this film is totally led by pacino & lemmon who literally sucked me into there characters lives as did the other supporting character such as the cold mr. Williamson (played by Kevin spacey).This film is the most memorable pacino film I've ever seen & is highly underrated.I believe pacino was in his prime at the time he was filming this movie (he had that rugged gangster look but with a profane youthful mouth to go with it!) as well as jack lemmon (R.I.P).I don't know what else to say but don't be fooled by the slow, dark pace of the early part of this movie, it is meant to be that way with events taking place over one night & one morning. You will love the transition of pacino one night,from philosophical smoothe talking salesmen to the ruff around the edges, frustrated comedic salesmen that he is in the reality of the film.A true mens film that has you watching it over and over again with friends. All hail Jack Lemmon, i just realised what a true legend you really are!

reviews.review_title: David Mamet captures the world of sales very successfully.
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross (1992) is the perfect film about the world of sales and boiler room environments. A group of salesmen are given a choice. Either sell or hit the bricks. Three salesmen (Ed Harris, Jack Lemmon, Alan Arkin) and the company's hot shot seller are all involved in a shady land deal scheme. Their prize for making the most sales are a car, a set of steak knives and employment. To motivate the office, a "motivational" speaker (Alec Baldwin) is sent to their office to dangle new "leads" and to try and light a fire under their tails. Can the new leads and the speech revitalize the company or will desperate men do desperate things to stay ahead?A great film filled with a plethora of quotable lines and unforgettable characters (Lemmon and Baldwin's for example have been spoofed on the Simpsons, especially Shelly Levene). A highly underrated film featuring one of Al Pacino's last real acting performance. If you see this film on the rental shelves don't pass it by. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: I'd go for the steak knives myself
reviews.content: The next time your best friend whines about his job, slap on a DVD of "Glengarry Glen Ross." Believe me, he'll shut up fast.The script's stage origins are obvious (David Mamet wrote the play and adapted it for the movie), but nobody will mistake this for just a photographed stage play. It involves some of the sorriest real-estate salesmen in Chicago, fully embodied by Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, and Kevin Spacey as the office manager. In a bravura opening sequence, Alec Baldwin, the downtown higher-up, brusquely issues the latest sales challenge for the month. First prize gets a Cadillac, second prize gets a set of steak knives, and third prize gets a pink slip.As if that wasn't incentive enough, the sales guys are given "leads" (potential customers to call) that are like "I Love Lucy" reruns: decades old, and seen a thousand times before. With this minimum of exposition, we watch the guys at what could be called work--their suit coats dripping with flop sweat, varying their phone calls between telling loved ones that they'll be late again and pursuing old leads to share a "marvelous opportunity" with them.Compounding the frustration are the "good leads" that Spacey keeps locked in his office, "for the sellers." Suddenly it dawns on a couple of the guys: What if the office was burglarized and the good leads stolen? Of course, the stupidity of this situation could be argued in a second: Wouldn't anyone who made a sale from the good leads be caught red-handed? But then again, the leads, like the MacGuffin in Hitchcock movies, are beside the point. It's really an excuse for David Mamet to throw a bunch of frantic old men together like cattle heading for slaughter, each not listening to the other guy, but waiting for that other guy to stop talking so that he can be heard. None of them exhibits the slightest joy in life. Even Spacey, the office manager with a loving family at home and an office full of great leads, can't even find it in himself to wallow in his superiority.As simplistic as the movie's set-up is, it's some kind of career high point for everyone involved. (My only warning is to watch out for this R-rated movie's generous use of the F-word--when asked, Baldwin even claims it's his first name.) "Weepie" movies come with the advice to have your handkerchiefs ready. Anyone who watches "Glengarry Glen Ross" should be prepared with a good stiff drink in front of him.

I was captivated by the acting and script, so engaged that I lost track of time and when the movie ended I was like "what? it just started". anyone who worked as a salesman for a company or an office can relate to this story. the desperation to make a living, the strife to keep your job, the bloody competition are all part of your daily routine, and you have to get used to it and accept your destiny, otherwise don't bother going to work because you'll be replaced sooner than you think. I really liked Alec Baldwin's scene, it was the best in the movie. Not to mention Al Pacino's performance, everybody was real and convincing. if you appreciate real talent, it's a loss to miss such a performance. 10/10

A great ensemble! The story's a bit dry, but the performances keep you interested. Baldwin astounds in a role written for him in this screen adaptation of the multi award winning play from David Mamet. Arkin gives his best screen performance since "The Heart is a Lonely Hunter." Pacino got the Oscar nomination, but it's the entire cast who deserves nods for some of their best work on film.

Can't quite understand why Lemmon didn't get a nomination at the Oscars for his performance in this phenomenal but short film.  It relies on a superb script that makes something which we really couldn't be enthralled to see just by the circumstances the plot is immersed in (i mean, I wouldn't be that interested to see a movie on closers) but the actors pull us in, and the crafty script makes it just fantastic.  A great film, and if you ask me, Pacino could have done with his second Oscar of the year for his performance.Last but not least: Alec Baldwin's five minute performance is acting at it's VERY BEST.  That performance leaves an everlasting memory from the movie.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies for dialog
reviews.content: I was very entertained when I first watched this movie, and I have enjoyed it many times since. It is based on a play, so it is pretty much just men in an office talking. And the dialog is very profane. It thought it was extremely well written, and I liked the performances as well. If none of what I wrote sounds like something that would bother you, then I recommend this drama.

Spoilers below:I was surprised this movie was rated so highly. It disgusted me. This movie, in summary, involves a bunch of people trying to sell plots of land. I wish I could say there was more, but sadly there wasn't.There is a lot of swearing, but almost nothing else.
