The plot is so unbelievable, the acting feels fake, the scenery was the most boring to watch (either a rainy street, a dark phone booth, or an office where they can't turn on the lights), and the characters are as bland as they come....I kept watching to the end in the hopes that there would be some magnificent turn of events, or something to make watching this worth my while, but it never came. The movie ended abruptly.Now I know why people used to walk out of the movies back in the day.

As an expression of a great script, and the dialogue sizzles. Some of the best work of Pacino, Badwin, Harris, Spacey, and even the legend of Jack Lemmon, have ever done.An epic film that shows the "Dark side of Capitalism." Like an old wine it gets better with age.

You don't have to know a lot about selling real estate to enjoy "Glengarry Glen Ross," because screenwriter David Mamet and director James Foley plunge you into the shark tank of the daily lives of burned-out salesman with a completely three-dimensional feel.  The characters are jaded, despaired, angry, at the end of their rope...their dialogue is profanity-laden poison sprung from a well of desperation deep in their souls.  The performances in "Glengarry Glen Ross" are commanding, incredible--the respectable cast plays off each other quite well, and Mamet's dialogue keeps things going at a sensible pace.8/10

reviews.review_title: Fantastic film, extraordinary cast, terrific performances
reviews.content: IMDb 7.9/10 ROTTENTOMATOES 3.9/5 The intrigues in a real state business firm.I was quite skeptical before watching this film because I though the subject was boring, but it kept me interested from the first to the last minute.I can't believe this film is rated only 7.9/10. How can a movie this good be so underrated? This film shows how to make astonishing cinema without violence, without sex, without blood, without explosions, without easy gags....just talented actors perfectly directed and intelligent dialogues.Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon's performances are superb.

reviews.review_title: Bare light on the worst of human amorality. Genius, and heart-wrenching
reviews.content: You've read the synopsis. Slippery salesmen in a real estate office use every half-truth, bait-and-switch, and outright lie at their disposal to dupe hapless customers into buying worthless real estate.Each character in the sales office, Pacino, Arkin, Lemmon, Spacey, all show us unbelievable lack of morality, each in a different way: Pacino with the impunity of Satan, Arkin with the desperation of Willie Loman, Lemmon with the glad-handed deceit of a used car salesman, and Spacey with the cold-blooded self-preservation of a rattlesnake.I don't see this story as one about the "plight of the working man." These working men are not likable, respectable, or hard-working. They are willing to trade lies for income. They are willing to destroy and hoodwink unsuspecting and even mentally ill customers out of their money just to make a commission. No, this is no sad story about working men down on their luck. These men made a career out of selling junk and stealing peoples' life savings. The acting is spectacular from everyone. You can see, indirectly from their remarks, gestures (and of course, story-telling) that they KNOW what they are. For some of them (like Pacino), they don't care. For others, like Arkin or Lemmon, they've somehow convinced themselves that it's okay, that the sale is all that matters.The language is harsh at times, but always completely believable and appropriate. I deeply respect the work of all these actors, and to put them together in one film created magic. They never "compete" with each other on screen. Rather, they augment each other. Arkin plays wonderful scenes crying on the shoulder of Lemmon. Lemmon plays great boastful scenes, crowing like a rooster about what he once was to Pacino, who kowtows to him, while you can see that he doesn't really care or believe him and is only thinking about who he can fleece next.It's bitter, it's human, it's believable, and it is a GREAT film.

The central question posed by the film/play is whether one can compete for capital in the real world without selling his soul, and what a profound question it is. The director, James Foley, in the DVD commentary describes the film as "animalistic" and states that the characters are merely doing what it takes to survive. "Morality is a secondary issue." This is most certainly true in the world of Glengarry Glen Ross. We see the characters compete for money and the length they will go to to provide for themselves and their families. We do not, however, see the characters in their personal lives.The one glimpse we get of family is via Levene's reference to his daughter. After Blake leaves the office, the other salesmen leave. Levene stays to make more sales calls. He first, though, calls his family to let them know he will be working late. Not for love of money or career, but for necessity.Moss schemes, trying to sell his plan to the others in the office to steal the good leads. He suckers one of the salesmen into doing his dirty work for him.The acting is thrilling; the whodunit aspect is intriguing; the dialogue is intense. The underlying observation is lost on many viewers. What are we willing to do? Will we cross moral boundaries to further our careers? Is this okay, as long as it is only for money - to provide for our families? To what degree do our jobs define us? Can we morally compartmentalize our actions in our careers from our behavior in our private lives? Not easy questions to answer. Foley was right. We are animals competing to survive in a fierce world. What you are willing to do to that end is up to you.10/10 JEM

reviews.review_title: "A man IS his job...and you are ****ed at yours!"
reviews.content: I first saw this in an arthouse cinema in Cardiff, Wales. It was my first Mamet experience, and I didn't go with the flow of the writing. Over time this movie has grown on me, to the point that my wife won't let me watch it anymore, particularly if I've had a couple of coffees ("put that coffee DOWN"). At my workplace, I often confront officious co-workers with the classic Jack Lemmon line "What the hell are you? You're a ****ing secretary, **** you!". It's a wonder I still have a job. A classic, Alec Baldwin's best role, wonderful work from all involved. A real actor's showcase. Not one to rent for a romantic evening with anyone, though :)

reviews.review_title: 'Glengarry Glen Dumbbells' -- and a short list of its obvious flaws
reviews.content: Pretty cool movie written by one of my favorite writers, David Mamet.A group of untalented salesmen are pressured by their company to hike their production numbers or else lose their jobs. Somewhat unbelievable script, but solid acting all around.Here are some of the film's inconsistencies:1. 'Blake' (Alic Baldin) asks if all those required to be at the meeting are present. Office manager Williamson (Kevin Spacy) says one guy, Roma (Al Pastinko), is absent, but Roma is the top salesman and he does not need to be there. Still, Blake says "Well, I'm starting with the meeting anyway". Later, Moss (Ed Haris) questions Williamson, "Roma doesn't have to be here because he's the top man on the board?", to which Williamson answers, "That's correct!").2. 'Blake' boasts of being a great salesman, but the 'leads' (prospective clients) which he speaks highly of, are, in fact, worthless, as Williamson states later ("Those clients are insane.... would you like to see the memo from the main office?").3. Roma goes to the barfly's private home to meet the loser's wife. It makes sense that Roma would get the inebriated loser in the bar to sign a contract to buy unseen land, but the loser's wife is the smart one, as she sends the barfly to see Roma the next day to cancel the contract, therefore, why would the barfly's wife sign the contract, too?4. Roma accuses Williamson of losing him his bonus Cadillac for being 'Number 1' in sales for the month, and of ruining a deal Roma was working on which cost him his 10% cut from the deal, which is true... Roma would have lost that, but the bonus Cadillac Roma would get for being the top salesman in the office would still be his.5. How could the competition (developer Jerry Graff who works "across the street"), be so stupid as to risk his business reputation and personal welfare by purchasing the stolen 'Glengarry Leads'?Also featured is the competent Jack Lemon and Alan Arken portraying a down-trodden soul. If Al Pastinko had any balls, he would have wanted to play the part of the loser, Levine (Lemon's character), instead of the 'top salesman', Roma, who is 'respected' while he walks around with a wad of money in his pocket. And of course, Roma doesn't have to be around for Blake's caustic verbal tirade, which is part of the reason Pastinko opted to play Roma).One question over-rides the entire proceedings: Why would these idiots stay with this terrible excuse for a job in the first place?

reviews.review_title: a film for people who work for a living
reviews.content: Let me tell you downright, this is one of the best films that I have ever seen. Everybody in this cast is excellent. And I believe that it could have earned an Oscar nomination for Best Adapted Screenplay. David Mamet is a great dialogue writer. Some of his work that he puts on stage or film is great. All this film is about is the movers and shakers in the real estate business. There is this group of salesman who are in this sales pitch contest. And the first prize is a Cadillac, second is a set of steak knives, third prize is the sack. But, a robbery occurs and somebody is the prime suspect. I must say that Alec Baldwin's performance is excellent. We could have seen more of him. I mean, we only saw him in one scene. Most of the people will be put off because of the profanity in this film. i heard there is 137 "F" words in this film. Well, that's how it is in the real estate business. A must-see.

reviews.review_title: Excellent acting illuminates this great story about the real estate business.
reviews.content: Shelley, Dave, Ricky, and George are real estate salesmen who are under the gun to sell more real estate. They work at Consolidated Real Estate in Arizona. Their line manager is John; those above John brought in Blake to put a fire under these four. So the re-working of their work life consists of a contest. In two weeks, whoever comes in first in sales get a Cadillac. Who comes in second gets a set of steak knives. The other two get fired.The common complaint is the availability of leads; that is, connections to a likely real estate sales that is worth a lot of money. With Consolidated Real Estate, they get leads that are dubious and re-worked. Shelley appeals directly to John for the premium leads, the 'Glengarry' leads. He tries to construct a kickback scheme with John to get the Glengarry leads.Dave and George do a lot of complaining, then consider robbing the office to get the Glengarry leads directly, then sell then to a competitor. Ricky schmoozes James at length, and closes a deal.The robbery does occur, and there is a great deal of consternation at the office. The Detective is doing interviews. Contracts and some of the leads have been stolen. Ricky's deal with James got registered with the company and the bank, or at least that's what John tells Ricky. Shelley comes in a little late and is so happy to have sold 8 units in a development. Dave blows up and leaves after his interview with the Detective. George gets interviewed next. Ricky and Shelley swap war stories.James tries to get out of his deal with Ricky. Ricky and Shelley try to fast talk him out of this. Ricky manages some quality talking time while the Detective interviews Shelley. John manages to torpedo the deal. Ricky is not happy with John. Nobody does anything but abuse John.Will the thief be discovered? Will any of these four salesmen get their act together again? -----Scores-----Cinematography: 10/10 No problems. Nicely shot.Sound: 10/10 Well-miked actors; no problems understanding the dialog with the sound at a reasonable volume. Music is not a factor here, and the dialog is everything.Acting: 10/10 Great performances: Ed Harris, Al Pacino, Alan Arkin, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey, Alec Baldwin. The fine story is made better by the excellent acting.Screenplay: 10/10 Mamet's story is riveting with these actors executing brilliantly.

The acting in this movie is incredible. The script is outstanding. If you like car chases, shootouts, blood, gore and explosions, this is not your movie. There is no action in this film that resembles anything in the aforementioned list. However, it does involve a clash between egos and shows what men are capable of when oppressed and ridiculed. The story is set in the sales office of a time-share property company. The conflict is between management, portrayed by Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin, and the sales force played by Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Al Pacino and Alan Arkin. Sales are down and the executives are not happy in the least. Baldwin's character comes in to try to light a fire under the salesmen. He is brutal, unflinching and merciless. In a speech of around five to ten minutes he chews the men up and spits them out. He hurls expletives and inflammatories at them as if he has an endless supply. The scene takes place in the dingy, cramped quarters of the sales office. The staff is seated at their desks at various places around the room. Baldwin is on his feet and freely moves about. Much of the scene is shot from a low angle, emphasizing management's position over the workers. Also the fact that Baldwin is up and moving contrasts his position of freedom, power and control with the plight of the sales force which is anything but. They must produce or else be fired. This brilliant speech is some of Baldwin's best work ever. He is playing a cold-hearted son-of-a-bitch, and his "f--- this! f--- that! I don't give a f---!" tirade sets the tone for the whole movie. Baldwin's character has the fireworks, but the best performance - among all the great work by others - is by Jack Lemmon. He plays washed-up, over the hill, delusional and desperate salesman Shelley Levene. This character is so pitiful I found him difficult to watch at times. He begs and pleads with his sales manager (Spacey) for the good leads; even offers him a cut of the sales commission. He pretends to not hear the objections of potential clients, when the viewer can clearly see he has no chance to make a sale. Finally, he is pushed to his breaking point - and he breaks. In the end he is still pleading and deal-making; pitiful all the way to the finish. Director James Foley does a great job with the set and camera work, shooting in small cramped areas - car, phone booth, office, etc. - which symbolize the restrictive and oppressive atmosphere the men are trying to survive in. David Mamet wrote the play the movie is based upon, as well as the screenplay for the film. His words, delivered so flawlessly by this talented ensemble, are powerful and gripping.
This film is a true acting classic

reviews.review_title: "A Story For Everyone Who Works For A Living"
reviews.content: This has to be the best screen adaptation of a Mamet play, period. Everyone involved invested a lot of time and talent, and it shows. The performances are great all around (Pacino got a Supporting Actor nod; Lemmon and Harris should've also received nods). Mamet's trademark dialogue, which disgusts many, works to great effect here: these are weathered men, dealing with frustration, struggling to be closer. This is a must-see for all.

Wiki synopsis; The film depicts two days in the lives of four real estate salesmen who are supplied with names and phone numbers of leads (potential clients) and regularly use underhanded and dishonest tactics to make sales. Many of the leads rationed out by the office manager are impoverished individuals lacking either the money or the desire to actually invest in land.My synopsis; This is basically a movie about con artists in an exploitative consumer society. The reason it stands above the rest is the intricate language used by the characters. The stories they weave to make a sale. The hopes, ambitions and weaknesses thy prey upon. The strategies they employ. All are being fired at one another in a way reminiscent for me, of Pinter. In a way the salesman and the story teller are the same thing.

First and foremost, I think its important to aknowledge the fact that the plot of the movie is not quite as strong as the actor's performances. Highlights of the movie for me were monologues from Alec Baldwin and Al Pacino. Jack Lemmon also excelled at portraying a half-likable half-contemptable character. Though Dave Mamet deserves infinite credit for making a successful adaption of his play, one must confess that it wouldn't be nearly as effective/successful without the individual talent displayed by the actors who played his parts.

This movie has some of the greatest acting performances you are ever going to see, with some of the greatest actors in the history of the business. Jack Lemmon gives one of his most powerful performances as Shelly "the Machine" Levine. Shelly is a once great salesman that is slowly seeing his profession pass him by, moreover he has to deal with the financial burdens of having someone close to him very ill and in desperate need of medical (financial) help. You cannot help but feel both bad and angry at Lemmon, as he attempts to grift his way back up the "leader board" so he can reclaim his top spot and job. This film also has wonderful performances by Pacino (Ricky Roma),Kevin Spacey, Ed Harris , Alec Baldwin and Alan Arkin. If you want a realistic slice of the "kill or be killed" nature of the salesman game, this is it. Now mind you, these characters are not saints, but they are real and their actions are more understandable as we see the events that motivate their behaviors. One hell of a film!

This film is undoubtedly one of my favourites of all time and that's because of it's brilliant portrayal of salesmen, it's stellar, sorry interstellar cast and its driving plot.One thing I really liked about this film (and it's Pulitzer prize winning source) is its 100 minute run-time. In that short 100 minutes, the film expressed to me more about the sales business did than Wall Street did in 126 minutes.Unfamiliarity - In this film, we're given an unfamiliar situation. There's no other film like this, so this is the first time we're actually being placed in this sort of situation. That's what gets us intrigued.Familiarity - Majority of the film takes place in one room. That gives us familiarity in terms of setting. We feel like home in that room, in a sense that we know how the characters move inside. The same is with 12 Angry Men and Reservoir Dogs. If unfamiliarity got us started, familiarity keeps us going.Next, the performances. Can we change that Best Actor to Denzel Washington for Malcolm X and that Best Supporting Actor to Al Pacino for Glengarry Glen Ross? Al Pacino is fantastic in this film. Kevin Spacey's performance makes you sympathise with him and hate him at the same time. Jack Lemmon makes you love him. Alan Arkin and Ed Harris are equally great. Alec Baldwin really has "brass balls".On a last note, I cannot talk about this film without commenting on it's fantastic editing. The editing is just marvellous. We cut back and forth and back and forth really fast when the conversation keeps rambling. We feel the conversation's tension and its rhythm when the actors and editors do what they do best.

Actually, writing about this movie is not an easy task. As you may mix different aspects which are quiet different in value.The act is marvelous.It's beyond imagination. It's no surprise as there is half a dozen of the best actors in the last 20 years! All of the guys were legends before (Jack Lemmon), at the same time (Al Pacino)_ or a little bit later (Kevin Spacey). So it's no doubt full of energy and a masterpiece from acting point of view.The direction is unbelievably strong. Some ordinary subject, some losers and NO WOMAN!. And after all as it goes through you are tied to your chair harder. BUT....What's it all about? were's the moral? Isn't that necessary to obtain something from it? What you can obtain? That Jack Lemmon - the most positive character in all the movie - is the worst? That the cutest guy ( Al Pacino ) is a loser too? That Kevin Spacey is what ? Negative or positive? ANd after all .... so what?I do not think that putting the audience in some wrong idea and then give them a shock is always a good trick. You should think about the after wards and what will you give them after that...My best reason is IMDb itself. The movie which has about 7.2 points and many comments with 10 stars is not a favorite today (2007) at all!No one nowadays has heard about this movie and no one will. They just will be shocked when they see the list of actors and will try their best to watch this movie and enjoy during watching .... and finally feel sorry....just like me!

Wow! To get Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon and Kevin Spacey together. And then add Alec Baldwin, Ed Harris and Alan Arkin! All those actors give top-notch performances in this one. Great screenplay. You get to know the characters, they're miserable life. They need the leads! But they don't get them.Funny too. Steak knives for the runner-up! The door for the loser!A great movie!Out of 100, I gave it 83. That's *** out of **** stars.Seen at home, in Welland, on November 26th, 2001. For the 4th or 5th time. Never get tired of it!

Truly great performances by an extraordinary cast. It shows how the dog eat dog world of real estate works. Al Pacino in one of his best roles of all time. There are no friends in this business only enemies. It shows how far some people will go in order to make a little coin. Alec Baldwin in the best ten minutes of his career at the beginning of the movie. Though sometimes it is hard to believe that people would talk to each other like that. I know most people wouldn't take that stuff from anybody. When somebody has a good day they brag and they rub it in everybody's face and although they work together we get the feeling there is a certain underlying hate between all of them. Would recommend to family even distant cousins.

One of my favorite movies. Great cast and a great acting game. Al Pacino, even for the actor's work in the tape nominated for an Oscar, and Jack Lemmon was recognized as the best actor at the Venice Film Festival. It is important to note an interesting story. The film motivates you to act. The film makes you worry. For those who have a taste similar to mine, I recommend watching this movie 100%.

"A-always B-be C-closing. Always be closing! ALWAYS BE CLOSING!" Ah... full of memorable dialogue, this is such a wordy movie. Very much like a stage play, this still works well as a film. The cast is superb, the acting is good, and though it's not exactly the most dynamic film of all time, it still remains convincing and thoroughly watchable. Alec Baldwin's pep talk to the sales team is one of the finest movie moments ever. This is a movie full of bile, anger, frustrations and dreams. The language is flowery and it's rare to discover a purely character-driven movie that can grab you by the balls and keep you interested throughout. It stands up so well to repeated viewings too.

reviews.review_title: A small set of targets - but splits the bullseye every time.
reviews.content: A set of tricky-dicky land salesman are put under extra pressure to sell-sell-sell. To encourage them further a set of prizes are put on offer by the "down town" office. They are - in descending order - a car, a set of steak knives, being fired!Transferring plays to the screen has long been a staple of Hollywood. Stating the very obvious, sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. However when they don't work critics will often say "they didn't do enough to open it up."Well here they haven't sought to open up an obvious play and thank god they haven't because this is a mini-masterpiece and it could have been ruined. The sets may be limited, but there isn't a single scene that rings false or has no part in forwarding the story.What makes this extra special that there are no parts played by anything other than major acting talent: Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey, Alec Baldwin and Jonathon Price all together in one place at one time. (I am not being sexist - there really are no speaking parts for women!)Lemmon gives his swansong performance as an ageing salesman (Shelley "The Machine" Levene) that is going through a period of either "bad luck" or "bad leads." Thank heavens the bad language didn't cause he to turn down the role of a lifetime.We linger to see his crooked sales technique. Firstly he isn't selling anything, merely a man out to do another human being a favour out of the goodness of his heart! To the client he is not even a real salesman, but a fictional President (or other high-up) that just so happens to be passing through town and wants to drop by to discuss an "exciting opportunity."He is so hardened to the door-slam that he hardly notices it anymore - merely moving on to the next mark with the same zest and enthusiasm. The sight of a client signing the dotted line is his orgasm. Like real sexual conquest it is relished and described in blow-by-blow detail to whoever will listen.Al Pacino could have been a salesman or a con man (here the line is blurred) in real life. Although he has a script to work with he really does have that kind of brain and the ability to drag people in via attitude, voice and charisma: You have to be a raconteur, get people's attention, lure them, soften them up. Then without the client knowing a thing about it, in comes the "soft sell" sales pitch!Here a "closed" deal goes wrong and he goes from sleep mode to a 100 miles an hour in seconds: Playing for time, being confused by the obvious, trying to make for the door, trying the sales patter one more time, he tries every crooked trick in the book to keep his percentage. But he's a loser, because there are people that know a scam when they see one - if not the client themselves.(There may be "one born every minute", but they often marry the less gullible.)Kevin Spacey wasn't a star when this came out and paradoxically probably wouldn't have been cast had he been one. His character - while key - is background.He is the bookkeeper and the clerk and doesn't have to knock on doors and sell things on cold raining nights. He is free from the highs and lows of sales - a family man that puts up with the flack like the punch bag he undoubtedly is. But don't write him off too early - he has some of the best and most telling lines in the whole piece.What we have here is acting. Pure and simple. Nothing to hide behind bar a hat, a raincoat or a shinny suit. Writer Mamet has obviously been there and done it for real. Although some of the swearing and going from calm to frantic (and back again) is a bit over-the-top.The subject itself is an unexplored part of Western culture. People that are professional liars. People that say the truth only when it suits their cause - which means rarely. To win-at-all-cost means to sell-at-all-cost. Stop at nothing and let nothing stop you.There is a plot - of sorts - about golden sales leads that are being stored in the office. Through this we have the needed drama, revelation and downfall. In the end we see the professional gambler (I won't say which character) who has seen his last horse lose and has no more money left in his pocket and no more hope in his heart. The saddest sight in the whole world...

reviews.review_title: I probably should rate this higher but here's why not
reviews.content: as a film it was strongest in its acting, I probably have never seen a film where I was so amazed at the characters, and the depth in a story that takes place over night. this movie was an incredible film when it came to acting. I can't stress that anymore.. now as a film, sure i would watch it again, but I don't see it as those films you can go wow that was amazing I will watch that daily, (I would only do that if I was trying to work on my acting or something) but it is a story that is simple clear, concise, and just something that could probably have even been put as a play if it was not.. to put it simply if you want to learn the basics of acting watch this, but if your looking for entertainment, don't look here its not boring, but I can't see everyone enjoying it as much as I did, simply because I believe less and less people value strong acting anymore..

I remember I started watching this movie some ten years ago and I switched off after about 25 minutes or so because I just couldn't figure out the meaning of all that endless talk that was pouring out on me from the screen - well today I finally got to sit through the whole thing to figure out one thing, and one thing only: that a world of sales is ruthless and it sure ain't my cup of tea.Glengarry Glen Ross boasts a ton of charisma in the faces of Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin - that much talent on the screen could not have made a bad movie, and they didn't.The movie was made from the play and that's what it feels like the whole time: fast paced, handful of locations, smooth and jazzy soundtrack and the dialogues - oh the dialogues - they were either written so meticulously brilliant or just improvised on the spot; in any case the dialogues and the people who delivered them is what makes this movie so great.Too bad there's so much water and unnecessary exposition in them dialogues otherwise I would have enjoyed the movie even more. I know those empty dialogues are supposed to open the characters up a bit more, show us they're real people and they talk how we talk in real life but the thing is they don't actually have a lot of interesting stuff to say so you just get lost in all the nonsense the characters exchange back and forth.Jack Lemmon is the only main character because only he has got a background story for his character, all the rest are underdeveloped therefore are playing around him but to their own benefit as well. I especially liked Alec Baldwin's short but memorable performance and I'm sure his (mostly) monologue has influenced a lot of actors since then.Overall this is a good piece of theater played out on the screen, with fantastic cast where each actor delivered one of the best performances in their respective careers and a fine script to back them up but the movie has too many incoherent dialogues and lacks flesh and blood supporting characters but other than that Glengarry Glen Ross is near perfection.

reviews.review_title: What else can be said? Superb
reviews.content: I don't know what else I can add to the comments that hasn't already been said. This is genuinely one of the most under-rated films in the industry. The ensemble group played against each other so well it was as though we weren't actually seeing a movie but watching real people in a real profession. This is a stunningly great movie. I was in sales for many years so I could certainly sympathize with the characters. Lemmon, Pacino, Spacey, etc. pulled it off to perfection.This movie should be used as class-room material for young wannabe actors as an example of how it is supposed to be done.I gave it a 10 because it deserved it..if I could have given it an 11 or 12 I would have done so.

reviews.review_title: "You see pal, that's who I am, and you're nothing."
reviews.content: This movie is easily in my top 5 of all time. I can not describe the joy of watching this over and over and over. Every word of every sentence is absolute art. Every character is expertly played. The cinematography is so basic it's beautiful. All of these actors gave performances of a lifetime. The profanity flows thickly, so fair warning. But it has a purpose. Pacino, Lemon, Spacey...brilliant! OK, we know the sales gig is tough. No other movie shines a more intense light on the struggles of the common salesman than does this. Don't expect explosions, nude women, automatic weapons, etc. Their words are their weapons, and each character uses them with aplomb. Grab a beer. Grab some popcorn. Grab a seat. And enjoy a true masterpiece. Is it on blu-ray yet? If not, don't wait.

Adapted from his own stage play by David Mamet, Glengarry Glen Ross examines the tensions in an underperforming real estate office as the salesmen are handed an ultimatum; sell or hit the pavement. It has an all star cast despite two of the actors, Allen Arkin and Jack Lemmon being clearly too old for their roles. All sounds good on paper, right? Well yes and no. Maybe it's a very clever piece of casting but the actors are clearly competing with each other in the same way their characters are in the story. Instead of an ensemble piece we get a series of encounters where the actors attempt to out act each other. The dialogue is unrealistic, no one really speaks this way. It's like watching Shakespeare, you are always painfully aware the presentation is a piece of art rather than entertainment. Despite the stage play receiving a Pulitzer prize the movie didn't win many awards but was a critical hit. If all this sounds bad it isn't meant to be, it's still a good movie and definitely worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: No Women in This At All
reviews.content: Talk about a depressing piece of drivel! The people are depressing, the circumstances are full of despair, and worst of all, there is not one woman in the entire movie. Just a tad bizarre. But if you can put aside all that, there are some interesting visuals. The only reasons to sit through this are the acting: Kevin Spacey in an early, but memorable, role; Jack Lemmon...heck every man in it is interesting...but the one who truly jumps off the screen is Alec Baldwin. True evil. But then, that is what Mamet is good at, isn't it?

Greek Drama? outstanding? working man's life? are you taking the Michael?? we just sat through 1h40 of bad language and no story we could make out. I have never been s disappointed with such great actors, but than there may be a deeper meaning behind it that totally escaped me. Parents: The language is simply appalling and even though I have spent ten years of my working life in factories and the last 10 years in and with garages, none of the people I have met had similar manners. to try a summary of the plot is not easy, A group of pathetic liars try to sell dodgy real estate using a mix of waffle and trickery. the are themselves confronted with a working environment which makes the job of a loo attendant seem very desirable. Bt then again these men don't really work in the true sense of the word, they just try to coax people to sign contracts. Their methods become more desperate during the 24 hours shown in the story.. and that is more or less it. a waste of time.

All-star cast for an exceptionally boring film ... like a conversation that goes nowhere, and never ends.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
Sales and all of its twisting of words, truth, money, and signatures. Yes, it could be made into a decent film.But this story is practically 100% talking amongst salesmen about how unhappy they are ... in dark places.That's it.ACTING:
You'd expect good acting and the cast deliver, but! (yes, that sentence is not grammatically correct)But ... good acting for a poor story and script ... still, does not make good film.ENTERTAINMENT:
Low value here (for me there was almost zero value)TEMPO:
Do you like listening to the rain? It can be soothing. Here, it's like the drone of a bread making machine.That's the pace, the sound of an endless conversation and the rain.CINEMATOGRAPHY:
Darkness and rain, like the film "Identity" (2003). Watch the latter film; it's very good.DIRECTING / WRITING:
Director: This director should have stayed with TV, or just in it.Writers: Mamet wrote some decent stories > "The Untouchables" (1987), "Ronin" (1998), but he's also done quite
a bit of TV. Here, I'm speechless because this shouldn't have made it to film. Then again, maybe not written.Is it a good film? NoShould you watch this once? NoRating: 4.0 (just for the acting prowess)

reviews.review_title: A better casted, less interesting version of "Swimming with Sharks"
reviews.content:
I honestly found the film a bit tiresome with it's artsy direction, trite philosophical musings and, frankly, annoying subject matter. 
This film appears abuses the moviegoer in much the same way as "Swimming with Sharks" but without much of a payoff.  If you enjoying delighting in the suffering of others, you'll probably love this flick.  If you're expecting a life lesson or stellar performances from high caliber stars, you'll probably be disappointed.The only reason I gave it a 5 was that Pacino and Jack Lemmon WERE good in the film.  Most of the other characters were rather uninteresting. Including one of my favorite actors, Kevin Spacey.This just makes me want to go watch The Usual Suspects again.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films I've seen
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is one of the finest films I've seen. Trying to establish the extraordinary pressure the salesmen are under, Mamet specifically wrote the part for the character that Alec Baldwin plays.With an extraordinary cast, the film has a gravity few & far between! Jack Lemon excels as do Ed Harris, Al Pacino, Alan Arken & Kevin Spacey & they give the film real depth & meaning.I can recommend those film highly enough, if you appreciate brilliant acting, an evolving story and the genius of playwright, David Mamet

This might be the best "talky" film ever made. People criticize films that are filled with talking heads, but usually it's because the script sucks. Not this one, as Pulitzer-winning playright David Mamet provides the script for this superb story of 24 hours in the lives of rapacious real-estate agents fighting to keep their jobs when business has gone sour.No less than three Best Actor Academy Award winners are in the cast (Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Kevin Spacey), which means that the acting will be stellar. You'll be drawn into the story and plight of these fellows, who are in a battle royale to fend for themselves. All the actors deliver great performances; especially Lemmon, Pacino, Johnathan Pryce, and Alan Arkin. The best performance, though, is Alec Baldwin's, who in his small role comes in and kicks his troops' butts for their poor performances with the nastiest pep talk ever given in a film; indeed, it was his best work ever, and he should have been nominated for a Best Supporting Oscar (they gave one to Jack Palance for his short role in City Slickers). No need to say more, run to your video store and see this one, it's primo.

reviews.review_title: David Mamet's movie all the way
reviews.content: Intense movie experience i've had after a long time. The movie is about the tough game of survival, in a hostile world of sales, targets, commissions & leads. As can be expected by the fact that it is an adaption from a David Mamet's play, of the same name, the movie's main asset is its dialogue. And it seems it's one of the rare occasions when Movie is better than its source material. I am saying this because I found out that some of the most impressive scenes were added later for the screenplay. Besides the dialogues, the movie is also about characters. Among the impressive cast that includes the likes of Al Pacino, Kevin Spacy, Jonathan Pryce & Ed Harris, the surprising winner is Jack Lemmon. He plays his character to perfection. He lets the pathos of it to shine subtly through his performance. & About direction, the perceptive Roger Ebert made a wonderful observation that seemed to me very true in hindsight: 'The film was directed by James Foley ("At Close Range"), whose timing and camera help underline the humor; a line of dialogue will end with a reaction shot that mirrors our own reaction - surprised, blind-sided, maybe a little stunned, but entertained by the zing of anger and ego in the words.'

I was expecting a lot more from "Glengarry Glen Ross" because with names such as Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris it was a let down. Not only was this movie a let down to me, it was a let down to everyone who saw this film because their was no good plot defined in this movie.The best thing about this movie other than the fact that it ended was watching brilliant actors try to pull of a failing film. They all did their best but it was too late to save the film.I can't believe that "Glengarry Glen Ross" took place in one setting for most of the movie. A movie that has this element is guaranteed to be dull. I wanted to turn it off so much, but because it had an all star cast I gave it a chance. I expected to see something similar to "Wall Street," but I was sadly disappointed when I saw something different.

There was never a more excellent cast than this and to give all of these superb actors a chance to shine in individual scenes is quite a feat. Alec Baldwin starts out with a bravura speech that is the best he has ever done to this date, one that was specifically written for the movie by the way.Then there is Jack Lemmon who should have been nominated for an Academy Award because his nervous energy is visible in every scene he's in and check out his final scene where he finds out that he's been had. He just nails that moment. After being totally ecstatic for 10 minutes he becomes a complete blank. His character also has the best motivation to sell - he wants his wife to be proud of him and his downfall is therefore all the more poignant.Kevin Spacey, pre Oscar, is terrific. He is the pencil pusher that nobody likes but still remains somehow dignified and doesn't lose his cool at all. It is fun to see him take abuse without even flinching.There is a lot more to say about this excellent film but to those who are unfamiliar with the playwright, David Mamet, you can bet on hearing some of the most colorful dialog ever written and it is amazing that with a movie that is basically all talk and very little action, it is a most riveting experience. Just check out the later Kevin Spacey and Danny DeVito movie with the same basic theme and compare. That doesn't even come close to a 5 on my list of best but this is the triumphant filmed play and there are not many.

reviews.review_title: Top Cast & Script Makes For A Remarkable Film...
reviews.content: ...so here are my remarks, well-deserved & long overdue for this magnificent film. Too often film-makers blow their budgets on SFX then seem to penny pinch by employing students to write the script. Thankfully that is not the case here. It is based around the daily torments & dubious sales practices of a fictitious Real Estate sales company.This movie rests on the strength of its actors and the scripts crafted by excellent writers for their characters. With Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Ed Harris, Alec Baldwin & more there would be no excuse for turning out anything less than A class. I think it says a lot for the actors that they had the foresight to take roles in what must have at first look seemed like a low impact movie compared to much that is Hollywood.I loved Glengarry Glen Ross, even though at times it can be hard to watch because you empathise so strongly with the characters. It can make you squirm. As a former sometime Real Estate Agent here in Australia I'm glad to report that it in now way even slightly reflects the truth about most Real Estate Agents' techniques & ethics here. What it does do is dramatically show the tension of always being on the edge, of always needing the next sale to stay in the race. And it is a race. It isn't on Free-To-Air often even though here the strong language wouldn't cause any legal problems, unlike some other places. I strongly recommend it to pretty much anyone who considers themselves drawn to script based movies. 9/10 (PS: Why doesn't IMDb include Aust/UK/NZ etc spelling?)

reviews.review_title: Awful movie of an amazing play
reviews.content: I was completely underwhelmed and disappointed by this film version of one of the great plays of the last few decades. Two astonishingly bad directorial choices: Al Pacino's monologue (technically a dialogue with Jonathan Pryce) that caps Act I of the play, a piece of freeform jazz-like brilliance that wanders all over until circling back in for the kill - one of those pieces you read on paper and can't imagine how anyone could pull it off. Instead of letting Pacino's astonishing performance appear as one piece (as written) - the director chops it up, intercutting it with completely superfluous material from another scene. It's like listening to Coltrane's "My Favorite Things" in 52-second intervals intercut with 30-second snippets of beer commercials. I have been tempted too many times to get the DVD and recut the scene the way it should have appeared - one long incredible take.And speaking of one incredible take, the scene toward the end where Lemmon confesses...I'm sorry, but why in God's name does the director decide to dolly back, rather than in? The absolute dramatic climax of the piece, and rather than heightening the drama by pulling us in, he completely deflates it by pulling us away.The director has done a disservice to this great work. He should not be allowed to direct drama again.
I liked it. Scummy men doing morally questionable things. It's a very contained film.

reviews.review_title: Perfect cast makes a fantastic movie
reviews.content: I think this is one of the best cast ever in a movie. Additionally, they work pretty well together. You can stick on the screen from beginning to end, not wanting to leave, amazed by the quality of the lead actors. The plot is smart and the flow of the movie smooth, which makes it even more appreciable. Don't miss this movie.

by Dane YoussefWell-played, well-written look at the bottom rung on society--salesman. Real-estate, exactly.Yes, it's a "photographed play." Like just about every other play adaptation to the big screen... but it's so well done, you don't care. Like "The Odd Couple" or... "Lost In Yonkers..."The actors thankfully move outside the office a bit (outside the building, in cars, phone booths, restaurants... and at one point, over to someone's house)This could have been called "Life of A Salesman." Men who dedicate their lives to selling real estate. Land and so forth. Not as easy and as coast-worthy as it all seems.God, what a racket. These people are all so cynical, bitter and desperate. They're claustrophobic and turning on each other. Their whole source of income and life rely on these little cards. "Leads." Little cards with names, numbers and addresses of people who want to buy land. But some of them are so old...A red-hot salesman from downtown (Alec Baldwin, in a role written especially for him) comes down to motivate, drill and berate everyone into bringing their numbers up. When another salesman makes the mistake of protesting against all the abuse and calling Blake on his rant, Blake decides to put him in his place.He flashes his watch. He shows off his car. "I made $970,000 last year. How much you make? Mitch & Murray asked me to come down. To help get the numbers up. As a favor. I told them that the real favor would be to take my advice and fire you. Because a loser is a loser."Then Baldwin shows the 'Glengarry Glen' leads. He holds them and shows them off to the other salesman like he's holding the royal crown jewels. The hope diamond. The holiest of holy grails. Well, to these guys... they are. Baldwin remarks smugly, "These are the new leads. These are the Glengarry leads. To you, these are gold... and you don't get them. Why? Because to give them to you is just throwing them away." I like when Ed Harris starts to protest of this guy's dressing-down and Baldwin snaps back. He shows no mercy. Drills right through him. This is some of the best Baldwin has ever done."You see this watch? You see this watch? That watch costs more than you car. I made $970,000 last year. How much you make? You see pal, that's who I am, and you're nothing."Then he FINALLY drops the bombshell. "We're adding a little something to this month's sales contest. As you all know, first prize is a Cadillac Eldorado. Anybody want to see second prize? Second prize is a set of steak knives. Third prize is you're fired."And there are more than three salesman in the office. One way or another, a lot is going to be trimmed. Not necessarily fat. Just... trimmed. A lot. To save money.The characters are sharply drawn and in a story that is intertwined and sown together with skill and surprise. The all-star cast does the best with Mamet's angry, fierce and realistic speak (the adaptation is by Mamet himself, from his Pulitzer-Prize winning play). Pacino is (as always, blistering) as the star salesman who's landed the top of the board with his fresh catch James Linsk (Alan Arkin).Ed Harris as Dave Moss is good as an angry, self-righteous salesman who's just such a jerk. An arrogant S.O.B. A great moment is when someone finally deflates him. Pops the big bag of hot air. Shows him to be scared and insecure underneath it all. His repeated cries of "F-ck you!" just reveal how truly desperate and insecure he truly is...The buttoned-down office manager John Williamson (Kevin Spacey) who's "by the books to the core" and has never been out there, selling it, in the sh*t a day in his life. He's just a company man. "A secretary... and white bread" as some of the salesman in the office call him.But the true breadwinner is the touching elderly Jack Lemmon as Sheldon "The Machine" Levene. Once the office golden boy, he was ahead and selling big week after week after week... reigning the very top of the board. The owners used to say things like "That car, that trip to Bermuda... you bought that for me..." Now he just can't sell. He sounds so grandfatherly and princely on the phone... you want to trust him so much. He's like Santa Claus.But Shelley cannot find anyone who wants to buy. All the name and address cards ("leads," they're called) are older than Lemmon. Many have moved on and found better service elsewhere. The machine is longer up and running and Lemmon does a magnificent job of painting him a portrait of a burned-out star. A has-been. It's painful to look into those big sad dog-eyes of his...He at one point goes to the house of someone who just doesn't want to buy. That's understandable, isn't it? Hey, how many times have you met a salesman who just won't get it. But Shelley's desperate. He bargains. He pleads. He drops his price. No sale. His heart seems to be breaking when...There are many a great moment in "GGL." Where Baldwin drills the troops, when Harris is hoisted on his own petard, when Lemmon works his old time magic with potential customers... and when a salesman pulls a hustling con on a customer... all to have one misunderstanding--a split second blow the deal.It would be unfair to go on with how the rest plays out. Suffice to say that it is worth watching again and again and again. The whole movie. It's a hard-boiled classic. Look for it wherever you can. Ask for it by name: "Glengarry Glen Ross."--Personally Believing In The Mantra: "Always Be Closing," Dane Youssef

This movie is powered by two things; firstly there's the brilliant screenplay by David Mammet and secondly there's the cast of the decade. To see how these superb actors hold the movie together is an immense joy and privilege, but surprisingly I liked Alec Baldwin's performance the best. He was the essence of the message this movie was telling.In a capitalistic world where you don't get a second chance you have to be tough and in constant offense on your "enemies", be it (in this case)the buyers or your co-workers. A powerful movie that ran by me like a flash. 8/10

reviews.review_title: Glengarry Glen Ross is based on David Mamet's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about a group of struggling real estate salespeople who are under the gun.
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is based on David Mamet's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about a group of struggling real estate salespeople who are under the gun. They have to make significant headway closing sales on investment properties or be fired. The men scramble, and as time starts running out, they grow increasingly desperate, turning on each other and considering more drastic measures to break out of their situation.This is a movie about what happens to people trying to survive in a corporate environment that doesn't respect them or provide them opportunity to succeed. More specifically, it's about what happens to people — men in particular, here — in that situation. In other words, this movie is about angry, lying, arrogant, weak, small-minded people with loud voices that they use a lot with many, many swear words.True to its roots as a play, Glengarry Glen Ross is all talking. That might sound boring, but it's impossible to find lots of dialogue dull when it's written this well and delivered by a cast of Oscar winners or nominees — Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alan Arkin, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey, and Alec Baldwin. This may be one of the best acting ensembles in a movie ever. The actors all give tour-de-force performances that leave you unable to look away. It's a reminder that energetic, action-packed dialogue can be just as thrilling as the most elaborate special effects.The actors let you, at various points, sympathize with the real estate characters, dislike them, or laugh at them. (This is in a lot of ways a very black comedy.) That's because the characters are always shifting, as are the power dynamics between them as they reach the end of their strings — with their company, with each other, and with themselves. And the result is that by the end of the film, you realize these are people you'd never want to meet in real life.In other words, none of these characters is a particularly nice representation of real estate people. That's partially the point of the film, but it'd be easy to imagine someone watching this movie and developing all sorts of bad impressions about the real estate business and its agents. They don't care about each other as a team, nor do the salespeople in Glengarry Glen Ross care about the people they're selling to. They aren't looking to help customers find their dream homes — they're just looking to meet their quota. They're interested in the money they get from people, not the people themselves. As Alec Baldwin says in his infamous, scorching monologue, their goal is simply to "always be closing."The men of Glengarry Glen Ross don't care about making a difference in someone's life. They only care about the difference peoples' money will make in their own lives.That's all not to say I don't recommend the film. Glengarry Glen Ross is a fantastic, thrilling film with breathtaking performance and great dialogue.http://juliekinnear.com/blogs/glengarry-glen-ross

reviews.review_title: One of the finest collections of actors ever gathered on film!
reviews.content: GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS (5 outta 5 stars)Phenomenal cast of great actors at their peak... spouting some of David Mamet's best dialogue.  Al Pacino! "What you're hired for is to help us... is that clear to you?  To HELP US... not to F*** US UP!"  Jack Lemmon! "What the hell are you? You're a f***ing secretary!  F*** you!"  Kevin Spacey! "Go to lunch! Will you GO to LUNCH?"  Ed Harris!  "The place gets robbed, they're gonna come looking for me.  Why?  because I probably did it."  Alan Arkin!  "Speaking about it as an idea?  We're not actually talking about it?"  Alec Baldwin! "First prize is a Cadillac El Dorado.  Anybody want to see second prize?  Second prize is a set of steak knives.  Third prize is you're fired."  Compelling story about real estate agents/con men who are desperately trying to sell worthless land to rich suckers.  Pacino deserved an Oscar for this one... but the Academy gave it to him for "Scent of a Woman" instead.  I'm sorry, but his performance here just blows his "Hoo Wah" out of the water.  And this was probably Jack Lemmon's last truly great performance... as good or better than anything he's ever done.  Alec Baldwin's "pep talk" would be the highlight of a lesser movie... but this movie is full of highlights!  Every second is mesmerizing!

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies from the 90's!
reviews.content: "Glengarry Glen Ross" is an excellent movie, especially for those who value acting over action. With such a talented cast of Alec Baldwin, Al Pacino, Kevin Spacey, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin and Jonathan Pryce, it's no surprise that the acting really shines in this movie.  Equally wonderful is the plot: everyone vies against each other to sell the most real estate and whoever loses gets the unfortunate runner-up prize of being fired!  While technically not a comedy, it has some funny moments with Alec Baldwin verbally abusing everyone else in the office and Al Pacino telling off Kevin Spacey for ruining his real estate deal.  My only gripe with the movie is that it seems to end too early.  An epilogue would have been cool..."Glengarry Glen Ross" has quite a bit of caustic language which may readily offend some people, but aside from that, this is clearly one of the best movies from the 90's!  And it doesn't even rely on explosions, special effects, and mindless bloodshed to excel as a movie...

I recently re-visited this picture and I was surprised how fresh the experience felt. It's been a long time since I watched it last, but man, what a near-perfect film.The story is the perfect canvas for quality acting and let me tell you! The acting is tremendous, perfect, awesome, fantastic - anymore superlatives?Like Alec Guinness who is one of the greats, Jack Lemmon joins him and why not, Al Pacino is awesome as well. The others are fantastic too.I love the character study, Mamet's script is wonderful and clever. The characters are written in such away that you don't love them, but you hate them either, well except for one.The direction is tight, no room to breathe, perfection!The wide-screen frame is used very well, do not watch this in pan and scan!Overall, a stunning picture, enjoy!

Sometimes you watch a movie that everybody tells you is awesome. And it has performances (from, let's say, Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino and others, in blistering form) that you can see are pitch perfect. And it has a great script, with endlessly quotable lines and a well constructed premise. And, in fact, the whole thing reeks of class and quality and all of that good stuff. And it still, somehowjust, sort of leaves you cold. I'm sure that Glengarry Glen Ross is great  that many critics must be right, but it really didn't do much for me. I watched the new Knight Rider pilot this morning, and enjoyed it more. Maybe I'm just a philistine, but the fact that I feel guilty about it suggests that maybe I just don't care about salesmen but do quite like talking cars.

The plight of the salesman has been a recurrent theme in American drama (Death of a Salesman, The Iceman Cometh-- ). Suspended in the feeding chain between the insatiable material lusts of the American dream and the voracious appetite for profit of  American industry, his predicament as martinet and professional huckster seems custom made to produce exploited and tragically deluded individuals, preyed on and preying on others. They can become  constructs out of touch with any grace or meaning in their roles and their lives.Into this pathos-laden environment David Mamet's Glengarry Glen Ross places a coterie of superb actors in a brilliant bit of melodrama. The context of the planning of a robbery to get the 'leads', reserved for 'closers', provides a touch of mystery that  works to alleviate the atmosphere of exhausted purpose and the claustrophobic entanglement of the characters with a manipulative sales promotion. The sales group is  forced into a bitter struggle for survival at the behest of some anonymous corporation whose only face is that of their top salesman, a vicious, sneering, greasy character played with cool malevolence by Alec Baldwin. Juxtaposed against this is the human element of these small fish in this small pond, afflicted with personal aspirations and tragedies.It is this dialogue between the all too  human and the inhuman,  among and within all of the players,  that gives this movie its force. Jack Lemon and Baldwin  are outstanding representing the opposing ideals.  Kevin Spacey as the cynical go between sales manager and  Al Pacino as the one salesman who seems destined to succeed by rejecting all ethical standards are also great. Ed Harris, Alan Arkin and  Jonathan Pryce play their character parts to perfection. I doubt you could have made this film work at this depth and to this effect without this ensemble of some of the finest actors in today's cinema. It's tough to class this as entertainment, but quite easy to categorize it as excellent, gut wrenching and thought-provoking drama.

reviews.review_title: One of the best acted movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: "Glengarry Glen Ross" is a movie that seems to get better and better as years go on.  Made 5 or 6 years before telemarketing call centers begun littering practically every urban center in North America, the film is actually much more relevant today than it was in 1992.The film is about a seedy, underlying real estate branch-office in a bad end of Chicago during a period of slow sales and salesmen that work there. After the honcho's at the head office decide that this particular branch was not performing up to expectations, they send one of their guys down to the office to tell them, in no uncertain terms, that only the two top salesmen this month will be kept, while the rest will be fired.  The big problem here though is that the particular salesmen caught in a rut at the moment are running on "leads" (an industry term for cards with the names, addresses, telephone numbers and personal information of people whom are potential sales) that are tremendously outdated (meaning they've been used at least once before) and the coveted new leads (newer, better leads almost assure you better sales) are given to those only who have made enough recent sales to qualify.While this film (and the David Mamet play) was made in relation to that particular form of real estate sales, anyone who has ever worked a job in the telemarketing industry will be able to easily relate to this movie.  As a student, I did telemarketing for 6 months for 2 different companies and saw this film a few months later and was shocked at how much unintentional relevance this film had on telemarketing viewed in the later stages of the 90's.  The system of leads, sales pitches and corporate policy is nearly identical to what I saw when I worked as a telemarketing sales rep.  You had the seedy, conning sales pitch that we all had to memorize and act out on a daily basis, the office managers who circled around the call center, hammering on people with slow sales with their only form of motivation being for you to win the monthly "office prize", you had the first class sales people, who got all of the golden leads, naturally, and then you had guys like me, people clamming onto stale, outdated leads, lucky enough to make one sale for every 200 calls we made, all while trying to score some of the Golden leads that the so-called top sales people were only allowed to land. Like the tagline of this film says:  "Lie, Cheat, Steal:  All in a day's work".The acting itself in the film is what gives it it's bite, though.  Jack Lemmon gives easily the best performance in his entire career as aging, former top-flight salesman stuck in a prolonged rut.  Alec Baldwin's highly praised performance in this film as the ruthless mouthpiece of the head-office is among the best of his career as well, but the real gem of this film in a film with a lot of gem performances comes from Al Pacino, in my opinion.  Pacino plays the current top-sales guy at the office and the speech he gives to a client he's trying desperately not to lose nearing the end of the film is one of the most utterly believable and real performances I have ever seen captured on film.  I was blown away.All in all, one of the best and most underrated films of the 90's.  I give it a 10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Dark, bleak, and deeply sarcastic take on the life of a real estate rep.
reviews.content: Dark, bleak, and deeply sarcastic take on the life of a real estate representative in "Glengarry Glen Ross", based on a play by the always reliable David Mamet ("The Untouchables") and wonderfully directed by James Foley ("At Close Range").The story takes place in a real estate firm, where three out of the four salesmen are forced by a big-mouth hot-shot into taking part in a sales contest to sell a worthless plot of land to the highest bidder in two weeks just to save their jobs.As for the cast here, which consists of Al Pacino, the late Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey, Alan Arkin, Jonathan Pryce, and Alec Baldwin. You couldn't have asked for a better performance from each one - especially Lemmon and Pacino.Until I saw this movie, I thought working in a cheese factory was crazy enough, but now I might reconsider that opinion.

reviews.review_title: One hour & 40 minutes I'll never get back
reviews.content: I am stunned with how utterly abysmal this film was.With an immense cast and a dialogue heavy premise, I was all in with my high expectations of excellence, but urgh.Alec Baldwin and Al Pacino were solid, as they so often are, but the others were infuriating and hammy. I have no earthly idea how this has become a must-watch classic, but I can't recommend it to you in good conscience.By all means give it 20 minutes, but if it doesn't have you by then, it's not going to ever. Good luck.

reviews.review_title: The Best Kept Secret in Cinema
reviews.content: This movie is so good that you may not realize it even after you see it twice.  I cannot think of one other movie with better acting all around, or even better dialogue.  Even with a subject as drab as the life of real-estate salesmen, David Mamet injects it with an energy unrivaled in any of today's action movies.It also gives you a lot of food for thought.  Like 2001, if you sit and think about the character's motives, what their lives must be like, and so forth, you get a pretty complex puzzle.  Does Williamson really know what he was doing when he made up the story?  Could the check really be good?  Why did Williamson give Shelley a bad lead when he knew it was bad?  When did Shelly talk to Moss about the robbery?  How did Roma get the Jim Lingk lead?  What could Shelley have said to John to save himself?  How does John get away with all his broken deals ("If you tell me who you sold them to, I won't turn you in")?  All these questions and more... heck I'm going to go pop my copy in the VCR right now and watch it again!

I did not rate this film highly because of one glaring fault: it is suppose to be a ruthlessly honest film but it is dishonest. No office, no group of people working together, are that frank, that open with their hostility to each other. Quite the contrary, some people can work together for years and never know they hate each other.It is honest in that salesmen, to be good, must be amoral predators. But they are also professional phonies. This is where the film fails, for salesmen are phony with everyone, even each other. The frank, unvarnished honesty these men displayed to each other, the naked hatred and contempt, is the part I don't buy. Any group of men who worked together like that would soon kill each other.No, this script would have been far more superb if it had found someway to reveal all the hostility behind all the phony masks we wear. As it was, it is only half honest, so it is only half successful.The great cast and performances redeem it.

I was expecting a lot more from "Glengarry Glen Ross" because with names such as Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris it was a let down. Not only was this movie a let down to me I think it was a let down to everyone who saw this film because their was no good plot defined in this movie.The best thing about this movie other than the fact that it ended was watching brilliant actors try to pull of a failing film. They all did their best but it was too late to save the film.I can't believe that this setting took had one setting for most of the movie. This movie was so dull I wanted to turn it off but because it had an all star cast I gave it a chance. I expected to see something like"Wall Street," but I saw something completely different.

reviews.review_title: A Classic Death Of Four Salesmen
reviews.content: Very much a film adapted from the theatre but don't let that put you off for this is an excellent film from start to finish and the top notch actors seem to be enjoying themselves hugely in this male-only, testerone-filled screenplay.I can't say I'm much of a David Mamet fan. He is a very tedious and lazy author when it comes to adding more than the basic one dimension to a character or scene. And this isn't helped by his lack of imagination on the intellectual front, often resorting to vulgar language & confrontation.Having said that Director James Foley fleshes out the characters on Mament's behalf, although to be fair the casting for this film is exceptional when one considers the high quality of acting made available to him and thus making his job far more easier in the rather constrained & shallow Mamet screenplay.Foley really didn't have to get his message across too hard with people like Pacino, Lemmon, Arkin, Baldwin, Harris & Kevin Spacey at  his service. Most of these actors learnt their trade walking the boards in their pre-Hollywood days, so this film often a gentle return to the confines of a pseudo-theatre environment.The tension & claustrophobia that eminates from this film is really evident and only makes the story even more finely tuned & edgy. You almost feel as if you're watching some kind of reality-show or docudrama as these men fight for their lives getting people to buy their real estate and sign on the dotted line and finish king of the castle at the expense of his colleagues.Lemmon is the old hand, who more or less invented the art of cold-calling and knows all the scams like the back of his hand. And yet for all his success in the past it means nothing now, as he finds himself deeply in debt with medical bills, a more cynical public who are no longer interested in what he as got to sell, coupled with a more brutal and hardnosed management team that don't really care for his personal problems & frailties but demand more from him in better sales revenue.Pacino is the relatively young turk in the sales tea: succesful, cocky, self assured, confident, crafty and a person with an experienced eye & gift of the gab at spotting vulnerable members of the public in getting them to sign on the dotted line of a real estate contract the mug never really wanted in the first place.Ed Harris as the arrogant and scheming salesman, who feels very aggrieved at having to work for other people. He doesn't like the idea of his bosses taking away huge slices of his commission for themselves while he works himself into an early grave. He doesn't have many friends in the office and remain aloof & vulgar in his speech. He is frustrated, childish and ever closer to his first heart attack.Spacey as the young, relatively inexperienced, sales manager. He is clearly out of his depth at trying to "marshall" his sales force. Lemmon & Pacino in particular ridicule him & show him little or no respect because he has never done the kind of footwork they did when he was younger.And then there is the cameo from Alec Baldwin, as the champion salesman invited by  the chairmen of the company to give the office a bit of a shakedown and reality check in the arts of being a good salesman and getting people to sign those contracts.The story is excellent, the acting right across the board is a treat, although it could be argued that Pacino went a little over the top during times of anger and resorted back to his usual Pacino traits of lots of swearing, barging and confrontation but don't let that put you off.A very rewarding & absorbing film, that comes highly recommended*****/*****

reviews.review_title: A gem every time I see it.
reviews.content: I just watched this again (probably the fifth time) and each time it gets better. This is truly what great acting will do. If there was ever a "guy" movie that had no shooting, explosions, exotic women, or car chases, then this is it because the tension is thick the whole way through. I think anyone studying to be an actor needs to look at this, and start rehearsing becase watching a movie like this should motivate any thespian. The scene with Alec Baldwin is the kind that will have you pumping your fist at just how tough he is. Pacino is great, with a delivery that is just masterful. Ed Harris as the high pressured guy about to snap, and Alan Arkin as the neurotic type who can't get a word in edgewise put in fine performances. And the desperation portrayed by Jack Lemmon as a the salesman who's seen his better days is the center of the film. Kevin Spacey also shows, in a low key way, where he was heading as an actor. The most amazing thing is that these guys practically say NOTHING. Words come out of their mouths that are strung together so haphazardly that any lesser actor would fail miserably. But these guys find it, go in the zone, and do it. Bravo!

Glengarry Glen Ross is from a stage play, and one never escapes that feeling. The depressing, and I'd have to say, turgid script never aims near simple dignity. The protagonists never convincingly earn our sympathies. Ok, they're hard driven salespeople trying to sell by any means necessary. They remind me of the kind of people, who would attempt to lighten the burden of a holiday bell ringers charity kettle.   The acting is top-notch, and manages to generate interest in the story, as one would expect with the amount of star power concerned. Alec Baldwin chews up the scenery with his five minute on-screen role. To see these neutered men quiver in their patent-leather shoes at the abuse that's thrown at them; has got to be one of the most affecting, unpleasant and memorable butt-chewings on film. This is, alas, the high point of the movie. The rest lulls around the depressing task of watching these dignity-deficient, desperate men sink even lower into the abyss.

reviews.review_title: Simply one of the greatest pictures ever made
reviews.content: This movie contains some of the greatest acting ever committed to  film. The screenplay, written by David Mamet and based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, concerns a group of real estate hustlers desperate for a sale. The all-star cast is nothing short of brilliant. Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon stand above the rest, but the rest are no slouches either...Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey, Jonathan Pryce and Alec Baldwin (in a scene-stealing role that's the best thing he's ever done) are all wonderful. The film has a limited amount of sets and is largely dialogue-driven -- it's basically a filmed play -- but that's what makes it so great. It's raw, no-holds-barred acting, full of Mamet's usual over-the-top yelling and screaming (and I mean this in the best way). The soundtrack is moody and gorgeous. The film captures perfectly the feeling of desperation that drives these salesmen. The fact that Al Pacino did not win the Oscar for this role (he instead received the award for his hammy overacting in "Scent of a Woman") and the fact that Jack Lemmon was not even NOMINATED are both nothing short of criminal. Ignore the Academy -- give this film the attention it deserves.

reviews.review_title: Lemmon and Pacino make this movie a classic
reviews.content: At first, I was hesitant to buy this movie, but I always heard good things about it, so I bought it. At first, it's confusing for some minutes until you figure out the real estate lingo, but once you get past the ordinary phrases used by the businessmen, you love it. Basically the movie takes place in a real estate company on its last leg. During the night, someone breaks into the building to steal the Glengarry Leads. The good leads.Lemmon as Shelly gives an emotional and stirring performance. His facial expressions and his movements add to the whole effect of his character and it showed he could still act in major motion pictures.Arkin as George may have the hardest character to play as he plays a shaky and often on-his-toes salesmen, a good performance.Harris as Moss gets to do most of the screaming in the movie and that's always easy for Harris, he always does a good job.Baldwin as Blake has a short scene but makes an impact and it lasts. You just listen and stay attentive when Baldwin is speaking. It's that good.Spacey as Williamson has to play an embarrassed and often ridiculed office manager but Spacey's performances are always electric.Finally, the Oscar nominated performance of Al Pacino as Ricky Roma is quite possibly my favorite movie character ever. Pacino's usual swagger is there but this time it's there with an attitude. His screen impact is matched by no one in this movie and you'll love this character. With the exception of possibly Serpico, this is Pacino's best performance of his career and should've won the Oscar and probably would've if he didn't win for Best Actor that year.If you don't mind STRONG language and you love pure acting and dialouge and possibly the greatest cast ever assembled, you'll love this movie. If you like explosions every 10 minutes, leave this one on the shelf at the store. I give my recommendation to anyone who likes Lemmon, Pacino or just fantastic acting in general. This movie should be considered one of the greatest ever but it always gets passed up. Watch it and you'll see why you shouldn't have ever passed it up.10/10

I was expecting a lot more from "Glengarry Glen Ross" because with names such as Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris it was a let down. Not only was this movie a let down to me, it was a let down to everyone who saw this film because their was no good plot defined in this movie.The best thing about this movie other than the fact that it ended was watching brilliant actors try to pull of a failing film. They all did their best but it was too late to save the film.I can't believe that "Glengarry Glen Ross" took place in one setting for most of the movie. A movie that has this element is guaranteed to be dull. I wanted to turn it off so much, but because it had an all star cast I gave it a chance. I expected to see something similar to "Wall Street," but I was sadly disappointed when I saw something different.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever
reviews.content: This is, without a doubt, one of my all-time favorite films. I defy you to find a better-written, better-acted film than this one.If you want an example of great dialogue, this is it. David Mamet is a master wordsmith and this is probably his greatest work. If one wants to study the art of dialogue, they should start with "Glengarry Glen Ross."On top of the great script, is great performances by some of the best actors.
