Jack Lemmon is outstanding as the salesman at the end of his rope. Al Pacino is masterful, as usual, in his role as the shrewd and cocky Ricky Roma. Alan Arkin... absolutely fantastic. Even Kevin Spacey, who wasn't a household name at the time, puts in a great performance, which is underrated do to the other stars. And Alec Baldwin really should have been nominated for an Oscar for his performance. It's just one scene, but it's one of the most spectacular acting performances ever put to film.Some people may complain that this is really just a play, caught on film, but director James Foley does an excellent job of giving us a sense of place and tone. There's a bit of noir influence in some of his scenes, and the film is directed economically, so it doesn't feel like "just a play."It's hard to believe that this film wasn't nominated for an Oscar. Al Pacino won an Academy Award that year, but it was for the wrong film ("Scent of a Woman"). Any one of these actors deserved it...

You never know what's going to happen when you put 10 great actors in one setting and give them a great script, but when I saw Glengarry Glen Ross, I was pleasently surprised and it blew me away.David Mammet has created a masterpiece and not because he used explosions, sex, and violence, but becuase he wrote something that everyone can relate to. It reminded me a lot of Quentin Tarintino's writing. Although Tarintino does use violence, he also uses wonderful dialouge to get his point across, just as Mammet did.I don't think any other actors could've pulled off such great roles and I believe that these roles were created for Pacino, Lemon, and the others. This movie only takes place in limited settings, yet, due to the wonderful acting, I felt myself drawn into it so much, that I didn't even care that it took place mainly in the Real Estate Office.My favorite part of the whole movie though, and I don't think I'm alone here, is when Alec Baldwin gives his wonderful monolouge. It was so powerful that I felt myself afraid of this man.I give Glengarry Glen Ross a 10/10 and I recommend it to all people who love both Film and theater.

An exceptional ensemble piece, with remarkable performances from some of the finest actors working today.A movie about desperate, scrambling, down-on-their-luck real estate salesmen - why should we care about this? Well, we do care about it, as we are drawn into this seedy world by characters that you come to care about.The dialogue is fantastic, and delivered by actors absolutely on top of their game. Jack Lemmon's sad, pathetic Shelly Levine character is stop-you-in-your-tracks good. A legendary salesman, now broke, insecure and still clinging to outdated sales techniques that used to work for him; powerless to help a daughter in need of extensive medical care; you can feel the sad, defeated rage from Lemmon as he desperately scrambles to convince his out-of-his-element boss (Kevin Spacey) how important he used to be, and how relevant he still is. These are fascinating and emotional scenes.The movie moves along well, as these guys scheme and schmooze their way through whatever life puts in front of them. Utter and classic B.S. artists who know they have spent their lives lying and rationalizing themselves, but resigned to not knowing any other way.The only purely honest, human conversations these guys have is with each other, complaining about each other and the conditions that they must work in. Everything else is "closing".

Glengarry Glen Ross(1992) David Mamets profanity laced Pulitzer Prize-winning play that takes place in a 24 hour period about real estate salesmen who are desperate to make that closing sale.A stellar cast including Jack Lemmon, Alan Arkin, Al Pacino and Ed Harris are all first rate in their performances, particularly Lemmon. The similarities between Lemmons character, Shelley Levene and the late Paul Brennan from the classic documentary "Salesman" are striking. Alec Baldwins ten minute appearance as a profane corporate motivator is just fantastic to watch and maybe the best performance of his acting career. A truly intelligent, enjoyable movie experience.

the f word is overused in this film but it is one of my all time favorites. Thats because I sold computers for about a year and a half so I can vouch for the anguish these men have when confronted with the new incentive: cadillac, steak knives or the door.Im not sure if the foul language was really necessary but perhaps the boiler room operations that foist Florida real estate are like that. The state is festooned with storefront hawkers the last time I was there. Selling, you guessed it, condominium lots.I liked all the actors in this film and they all had exactly proportionate air time needed to flesh out their character and contribute to the story. I was really surprised at the end when you find out who stole the precious leads. I first thought it might be an outside job or Alan Arkin's character but then found out it was .....Kevin Spacey was excellent as the office manager. His expression and reaction when he blows the deal for Al Pacino the hot shot makes it for his part. The desperation, anguish, fear, hope and exhilaration the men experience really does happen people. If you think of going into sales or are curious what sales is all about then see this movie. That axe hanging over your head called QUOTA is there at the beginning of the day, week, month, quarter and if you last that long, fiscal year.Im glad Im out of sales finally and into construction where I know exactly how to earn a living without having to make those godawful cold calls. Or trying to interpret body language. Yech. Thats why I left sales.

reviews.review_title: This is what it is really about
reviews.content: Yes, this is a great film and dialogue and character development is superb but the reason this film works and is so memorable is because it explores human frailties so well. Everybody in this film is a 'good' person just doing their utmost to make a living and provide for their family and the film is about how business in general and their jobs in particular turn them into self absorbed odious social lepers no one would wish to spend more than five seconds with without running like hell or wrapping a big heavy piece of wood round their head.This film could have been made, and probably was, for no reason other than to show how, if we're not careful, we can be both lovable and truly despicable at the same time. For different reasons we are drawn to these characters and we like some more than others - we admire them, hate them and feel sorry for them in equal measure.A pseudo film reviewer (that'll be me then) might say this film shows 'black and white' to be varying shades of grey so subtly that most viewers get it (deep down) without realising it. Masterpiece.Budding film makers should watch films like this at least once every 22 seconds.

Great cast and outstanding performances all round. Not much of a story to be found though. Much like lawyers and traffic wardens, salesmen/conmen don't particularly rank high on my empathy or amnesty radar, but still I enjoyed the dialogue and high calibre acting from some terrific talent here. Entertaining for what it was but not as gripping as I'd hoped.

reviews.review_title: You arnt a salesperson until you watch this
reviews.content: This is a drama from an award winning play which was then made into a movie. Think about how much pressure the actors were under to go beyond the 5 star reviews and precedents already set by the play. Somehow and someway they had to find a way to go beyond excellence and make a movie out of this thing. That they did, and it is so well done that you will find yourself in shock.Now one may think, well you can edit a movie and re shoot all these scenes and splice sentences together to achieve perfection. And to a degree this is done, but NEVER did this movie leave its roots behind as a play. most scenes are shot all at once without stops or gaps (read up on the movie)... and perhaps if one were to compile the most brilliant moments of movie history you would find the speech that Alex Baldwin made in this movie which is like 10 minutes long as Alex Baldwin takes the stage and tears everybody else into shreds (I think thats why Pachino was gone from that scene because Pachino's character would have tried to take the stage from alex baldwin-- think about it.) I am a salesperson a lot of my friends are salespeople and entrepreneurs. In my social network if you cant hold your own in a face to face then you don't eat. time and time again I've watched this movie with my co-workers during lunch and not only does it tend to pump us up, but we quote this movie all day long to each other."Put..the coffee down! Coffee is for closers only."

...I kissed the $4 to rent through my cable provider good-bye. What a stupid movie. Hideously boring so that I didn't finish it. I wanted to see it because I am admittedly late to the party in realizing what a phenomenal actor Ed Harris is. So late that I just recently watched Apollo 13 for the first time. I've been wanting to see more of his movies, and this flick was in his top 10 best. As we know there's no accounting for taste ,so if you like it that's great. I thought it stunk. Two stars because Harris was in it.

I have never seen this work on stage, although it is one of Mamet's better known plays, but I was keen to see the movie as it has been heaped with such praise.A fine movie it is too, well acted.  The scenes between Al Pacino and Jonathan Pryce are especially strong, particularly the denouement scene between the two of them is magic.  Pacino is often singled out for praise (he won the Oscar for this performance), but Jonathan Pryce played his (smaller) role magnificently and is equally good.The other key pairing, Jack Lemmon and Kevin Spacey, didn't reach those giddy heights for me.  Well acted, granted, but somehow Lemmon just isn't a Shelley Levene to me and Kevin Spacey isn't the sinister but dim jobsworth Williamson.  Those two could work brilliantly together. I saw them play opposite each other in Long Day's Journey Into The Night (James and James Junior respectively, London circa 1986) and they were dynamite in that.  
The language in this film is ripe; you probably won't learn any new words but you will hear the phrase "f*** you" deployed in every conceivable tone of voice.  Janie and I have been rehearsing the cannon ever since we saw the film, for fun.I digress.  This is a truly powerful drama and well worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: desperate needs lead to desperate deeds
reviews.content: This is perhaps a very misunderstood film.  Maybe there are more salesmen in America than in Europe and that could be why many people think this film is about 'anyone' who works for a living.  It is NOT about working men (as the tagline might suggest erroneously, read: commercially), it's about slick tricks and misdemeanors by some guys who are in a tight spot and just happen to be salesmen.  The story is not about real estate that has to be sold, but about the behaviour of people in severe competition.  In order to create such a convincing characterstudy you need a good cast and that's what you'll find here!  Every word and every movement by any of the actors is important and creates an opportunistic hell that you might expect from guys in a tight spot.  The only performance in this film that I feel was only interesting because it was HIS best, was from Baldwin.  Fortunately, he has only five minutes of screentime.  The rest of the cast are stunningly subtle and contribute brilliantly to a tense mood.  Cinematographer Juan Ruiz Anchia (Liebestraum, At Close Range) created a film-noir look that adds to that tense mood.  After seeing it I had the feeling that competition must have always been like this and will never change, because people will always try anything to sell anything to anyone.  Oh, and, yeah, don't pay attention to the terrible cheapo cover: it's not representative for the content.  This must be Foley/Mamet's masterpiece so far.10 points out of 10 :-)

This film is quite frankly one of the best you will ever see.I watched it purely because of the cast, thinking that it would be a bit arty farty and probably boring. By the end I was ready to rewind and watch it again.Al Pacino, Jack Lemon and Kevin Spacey prove to the audience that they are indeed members of a very elite group of outstanding actors. These three get a special mention but the rest of the cast were also fantastic.A true masterpiece that shows you don't need CGI, stunts and explosions to make a great film. Acting is still an important factor!

What this film does not have:
Special effects
Explosions
Sex
Violence
Car chases
Action
A love story
Comedy
Yet just brilliant screen writing and acting. One of my all time favorite movies.

In creating a collection of absolute flawless acting to watch and study, this movie would certainly be in it. I don't think there's one scene wasted or one scene where you can see them acting. Lemmon, Pacino, Arkin, Harris play their roles to perfection. Alec Baldwin is so incredibly good as Blake, the brutally honest sales motivator. The tension is thick as tree sap, and Lemmon's depiction of a salesman desperate for a sale comes through the screen like 3D emotion. Each captures nuances of salesman I have dealt with in my life. Lemmon reminds me of the salesman in The Simpsons with his folksy, but anxious attitude. (It's very surprising to hear him swear, which he does, alot). This movie isn't perfect. I didn't think Spacey's character was totally consistent (although I think he played it flawlessly, as they all did) and some scenes had a feeling of lag. But the acting is on a couple levels higher than just good acting. It's a movie that absorbs you and can watch over and over without it becomming tired. The acting is the real lure of the movie and it does not disappoint. 9/10

reviews.review_title: A cinematic masterpiece with the perfect cast
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross has to have the greatest cast that I have ever seen in a film. Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Alec Baldwin, Kevin Spacey, and Jonathan Pryce all give brilliantly riveting performances. Seven of some of the greatest actors of our time.This film has some of the greatest acting I have ever seen, you'll swear you'ld think the characters are real if you didn't know any better. You can't pray for a better cast, or a better screenplay, based on David Mamet's own Pulitzer Prize winning Broadway stage play. Glengarry Glen Ross is also one of my top 20 favorite films of all time. I've seen this film numerous times and it never seems boring at all. This is certainly a film that deserved a lot of recognition at the Academy Awards, but like most of the other good films of the year, it didn't. This certainly deserved to be named the best film of 1992, it was so far superior to Unforgiven, and it mystifies me as to why this is not on the top films list.Another added bonus is a cool musical score by James Newton Howard. It seems to blend perfectly with the nighttime drama in the film. Wayne Shorter's sax solo during the credits is also a plus.Also, it is the little things in the film which make it all the more excellent, such as an el train roaring by each time one of the characters start to explode, the effect of the phone conversations which truly show the desperation of the men trying to improve their sales figures before they get bounced out of a job. After all of this praise, I won't go into the plot, but it is one of the most powerful screenplays that I have ever seen, which pits every man for himself against the harsh world of real estate. There is so much hatred and angst against the characters, which also contains excessive amounts of the f-word. This is probably why I love this film so much. To be honest, I would not have seen this film at all if it were not for its all star cast, but I'm certainly glad I did. I agree with most of you who said that all of the profanity made this film tough to watch, but each and every actor put so much life into their characters that it made me forget about that roughness and just enjoy this film. Glengarry Glen Ross deserves a 5-star rating. You have to see this film.

Although this film is primarily set in just 2 locations, its an absolute belter. Superb performances from the best line-up of actors I've ever seen in one movie along with a compelling script. Alec Baldwin's speech is arguably the best thing I have ever witnessed on screen. If you like dialogue filled Tarantino scenes, check this film out asap!

reviews.review_title: See it, and LISTEN HARD to one of the 10 best of the 90s
reviews.content:
I just saw Glengarry Glen Ross for the 3rd time in 3 years last night. Screw American Beauty!  Anybody who wants a film about what it's really like to struggle for dignity in the 90s, to deal with a ruthless, senseless capitalist system run by clockwatchers, and, instead of sympathizing with Annette Bening, to REALLY discover what a mindjob it is to work in real estate, look no further than Mamet's brilliantly adapted stage play."These are the new leads.  These are the Glengarry leads. To you they're gold, and you...don't get them. Why?  Because giving them to you would just be throwing them away...They're for closers."
With these lines, Baldwin's no-name hatchet-man intimidates, infuriates, and inspires three down-on-their luck salesmen (Lemmon, Harris, and Arkin) to desperate measures in order to insure their future as salesmen.  Pacino stands apart from these losers as master salesman Ricky Roma, a master after a mouse of a client (Jonathan Price), whose life perhaps seems redeemable in the chance to buy property from Roma.  The plot is tight, the editing and cinematography in your-face (and good enough not to draw attention), the direction and acting superb, and the words...
Sometimes, I wonder which is more marvelous in this picture- the monologues or the silences.  Of course, Baldwin is a friggin' miracle in his ten minutes, Pacino is by turns both philosophical and furious when his time comes, and Harris is able to use the English language like a noose in convincing Arkin.  However, it is Arkin and Lemmon's sad-sack faces that really hit me- Arkin's look of utter loss, vain frustration, and pain as he realizes at the end that no one respects or even hears him is truly precious, and Lemmon's reactions throughout the film, whether to Pacino's admiration, Baldwin's intimidation, or Kevin Spacey's menace are a gift to the art of the close-up.
How can you say American Beauty's the best film of the decade?  C'mon, people, look in your video stores and see the real deal! "Stocks, bonds, pieces of real estate, objects of art.  What are they?  An opportunity.  To what?  To gain money?  Perhaps.  To LOSE money?  Perhaps. To LEARN about and INDULGE ourselves.  Perhaps.  So...So what?  They're an opportunity- that's all they are."  In the case of Glengarry Glen Ross, I highly disagree- this particular object is a wonder and a rare gift to cinema.

reviews.review_title: Yes, it is a great movie, but...
reviews.content: Superb acting and script from a stellar cast. But 2 things: I agree with one of the comments below saying that it is like a movie of a stage play. The other criticism I have is that I hope when you watch this film you do not think all real estate agents do such nasty strong arm things as portrayed. I sold real estate for a year and almost all of our staff for nearly all of the time acted very responsibly and honestly; I know many other real estate people also are good honest people. Yes there are a few bad ones - like in any other business or job - but the nasty ones just do not get referrals.

After seeing the good votes for this movie I decided to rent and watch it, but it clearly was a mistake. I was very close to stop watching it when after 45 or 50 minutes still nothing really had happened, but I forced myself, still having the hope that the movie might actually turn out to have content.I was mistaken.Except for maybe the last 20 minutes, when there got SOME life into the movie (after the office was robbed), the sorry flow of the flick kept on boring me - this movie has nothing to offer except for some good acting but without a story.

reviews.review_title: Foul Mouth Real Estate Crooks Get Angry
reviews.content: The title uv my review iz my review, but they want at least 600 karakterz. GREAT movie! I've woct it at least 20 timez. All the actorz do an outstanding job. The direction iz perfect.After i'd seen it around 8 timez I started to realize that it must hav been based on a play. Peepl go into the manajer'z offis and its like they've disappeared completely. A nesusery device for the staje, but a litl cheezy for a movie that's trying to be a portrayl uv real life. But fixing it woud need to chanje too much, so it duznt bug me even tho I'v seen it so many timez. I'm not going to Limpkin about it.This movie iz a jewel: perfectly wut it iz, despite any overcritical flawz sumwun mite think up.

reviews.review_title: 2nd prize is a set of steak knives
reviews.content: dark dark dark.....dog v. dog.  if, for some reason, you ever doubted jack lemmon's talent (why would you?), this role, stands as one of his best.  he is the true tragic hero, led to destruction by his own misguided hand. however, he has an office full of help.  i know i have worked with each and every one of these characters, from alec baldwin to alan arkin.  mamet's dialogue is delivered very well, instead of stilted, (e.g. Oleanna, American Buffalo).  if you've ever tried to read a Mamet play as it is written, you'll understand how difficult that is.  it is a movie that puts a knot in your stomach from start to close.  it's a good knot though.

One of the best films of the decade.  The direction is (unavoidably) stagy, but the performances and the writing made my jaw drop open.  Since it was released I've seen it a dozen times, and I'll recommend it to anyone who'll listen--but especially to aspiring writers and actors.  It's David Mamet's best, and Al Pacino tops a terrific cast with his landmark performance. Wonderful.

This is a movie about a group of salesman that are competing against one another and it's a dog eat dog, survival of the fittest kind of affair. This movie boasts a star studded cast that includes Al Pacino, Alec Baldwin, Jack Lemmon and Kevin Spacey. Unfortunately, all of them are under par in this movie and it's nobody's strongest performance by a long stretch. I think that it's the lack of quality in the script that lets them down. The profanity is relentless! It contains every cuss word under the sun and it just spoils it. A great cast like that deserves a lot better.Overall, it's a decent portrayal of what life is like for a real life sales team and their pressures to succeed. I did enjoy this movie and it does have some great quotes. It's just a shame about the constant profanities and I did find that to be very distracting.

reviews.review_title: Non sales people generally do not like this movie
reviews.content: First, I love this movie. I have been in sales most of my adult life and think this is a must see for anyone in sales, or thinking about entering the sales arena...Now, is the Glengary/Glen Ross office a typical sales environment? Of course not. Is Alec Balwin typical of a main stream Vice President of Sales? No. My gosh, it would be near impossible to keep anyone of quality in such an environment.But what the movie does is make you appreciate what you have. Whenever the "boss" gets on your case about a bad sales month, think about Alec Baldwin and you will quickly realize he/she is not such an unreasonable boss after all.And when sales get tough, and they inevitably do from time to time, think about how tough they were for Jack Lemmon ALL the time: selling a bad product to unsuspecting people inside their home at 8pm. Ouch, talk about a tough way to make a buck.This movie keeps you grounded, that's for sure. But what I have noticed with this movie is non-salespeople typically cannot appreciate the film's greatness. They do not know the thrill of making a sale or the rejection one feels when they lose one, so they cannot relate. And that's fine, because unless you have been in the trenches, fighting it out against the competition, this movie probably cannot be comprehended.But for a sales veteran like myself, this movie is like an old friend.

reviews.review_title: I was bored out of my mind
reviews.content: I hear so much about this movie but I was bored out of my freakin' mind. I almost slipped into a coma and had to fast forward through the whole second half. It was a waste of time I'll never get back.

reviews.review_title: Marvellous Performance from a marvellous cast.
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Rose, for one thing, is a movie with a marvellous cast who put out a marvellous performance that is worth watching for its own sake. The movie casts Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey (who won 2 Academy Awards in the following years), Ed Harris, Alec Baldwin and Alan Arkin all of whom put out impeccable performances that literally blaze across the screen. The story takes place in a real estate sales office where the salesmen face the fact that they are going to have to close more deals to reach their targets or they will lose their job after given a lecture by the tough top executive, Blake (Alec Baldwin). The problem is that they believe the leads given to them are no good, meaning that the customer list delivered to them to make the deals is dead-ends. One thing they know though is that John Williamson (Kevin Spacey), the manager of the office, has the leads to famous Glengarry Leads, which is a list of customers who are much more potential than the ones they currently have. However John is only allowed -by the company policy- to give the Glengarry leads to the salesmen who succeed in closing the deals. Next thing you know all the salesmen are thinking of ways to get their hands on the Glengarry leads, except for Ricky Roma (Al Pacino) who is not so concerned because he is the best salesman in the office anyways. This is a must see for all the movie lovers, a chance for them to appreciate the actors like Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris. The story takes place in one or two locations and revolve around only a couple of characters almost to the point of making the movie look like as it would have better been a play but the performances of the actors are so splendid that this drawback is redeemed easily. All of the actors here -not just Al Pacino-could have been nominated for an Oscar very easily, including Jonathan Pryce, who plays Roma's client, Mr. Lingk; even though his time is very short, his acting is splendid. For reminder, Al Pacino was nominated for a "The Best Supporting Actor" for his performance in this movie in the same year he won "The Best Leading Actor" award for his performance in "Scent Of Woman".

reviews.review_title: Woo! I'm a good director. Woo! We're good actors.
reviews.content: And the purpose of this film was? I suppose, if you've never experienced this part of American culture, it is a learning experience: a very accurate depiction on the bs reality that many sales-people immerse themselves in. I know. Baldwin's character was so real, it was scary. But did I have to sit through 100 minutes of this? I felt constantly like the director was simply using this vehicle to impress viewers? whoever? with his cinematic style (sorry -- this style was worn out in the 60's/70's). O.K., maybe that was all this film was about: Style. But 100 minutes worth? Sure the actors must have had a ball working with each other, but audience in mind: a 30 minute film would have said everything this film had to say. Woo! Deep! NOT!

This movie makes me thank god I am an engineer and not a sales person. It was so painful watching how these people interact and live - just too painful. Even the most cold-blooded operations person cannot help having a twinge of sympathy for the sales guy - and wonder why anybody would do that job.Although I have never worked in real estate, I knew every one of the actors in this movie. I work with them at some level every day of the week, and although I've been in the work force for over 30 years I could never understand what made the sales guy tick. This movie brought me into the minds of several sales persons, and I actually started understanding their motivations and frustrations. Oddly, after watching this movie, I started treating sales people with more respect.

Well played drama. Very very American, where people are measured by the size of their wallet. Superb acting by Al Pacino and an aged Jack Lemmon. The film as a whole is perhaps a little confined, if you understand what I mean. Otherwise, it's good and well-done.8/10

If you have ever been in hardcore, high pressure sales like I have, you will really appreciate this movie. It should be required viewing for all salespeople or prospective salespeople. This movie captures the intense sales environment and wimpy sales manager to a "T". I've never seen a more stellar cast and better performances in any movie. "Put that coffee down!" You'll find yourself saying this at every opportunity. Jack Lemmon's portrayal of a once mighty salesman whose best days are behind him is outstanding. Pacino's performance is second-to-none. All of the other characters will remind you of people you have worked with before. Every actor's performance in this movie is unforgettable. Do yourself a favor and watch this movie immediately. This classic is one for the ages. The Alec Baldwin scene is one you'll remember forever.

WARNING:  Spoiler below.From the get go this movie doesn't give the *ucking audience a break anymore than that $hit-in-a-suit Blake (Alec Baldwins's finest performance) gives these salesmen.  With the desperation of four men thrown out after one parachute they snarl Mamet's philosophy of life and work right in your face. That is, when they're not *ucking over their customers in the truest form of salesmanship.  The ending perfectly ties up the whole *ucking story. There isn't an actor miscast unless you count Jack Lemmon saying "mother*ucker."Hey, *uck it.  Watch it and it'll open your eyes whether you want them opened or not (and your ears, too!)

I was hesitant to see this film because I had read the play and did not see what all the fuss was about. You really do have to see it to understand why Glengarry Glen Ross is as gripping and tense as an excellent film noir. I could not take my eyes off the whole time, and could feel my high blood pressure after it ended. Do not be turned off by the idea that this is a movie about real-estate salesmen. It's about survival in the business world in general, and how its cutthroat nature drives men to deception. I had loved Oleanna's ability to hold an audience's attention with a dialogue-driven script, and this holds true for Glengarry Glen Ross. The performances are high-energy and suit the parts well, as expected from such a high-caliber group of actors, although some are better than others. Alec Baldwin, for example, steals the show and sets the tone in his brief appearance, whereas I found Kevin Spacey's performance a bit one-note. Still, each actor commands attention and gives a master class in monologue delivery.This is a captivating, satisfying thriller that, like a skilled salesman, knows how to hold your interest without overstaying its welcome.

I remember the first time I saw the movie,that that's what they want me to be like:"Put that coffee down"
"Coffee's for closers only"
"Do you call yourself a Salesman?"And I thought to myself:That guy is a jerk!
That guy is absolutely horrible!
Who in the world would want to be like him?It just kind of floored me that that was being held up to us
as the way to do sales.

reviews.review_title: A brilliant display of frustration and dark comedy in the workplace
reviews.content: I find value in this film by how it reflects some of the realities of our current work culture. Capitalism provides opportunities, but when taken too far, workers become victims of undue stress and abuse. And you feel that pressure when you watch. The characters' desperation is palpable throughout the film. You don't just watch it, you live it with them.The film's script provides a perfect setting for the actors to showcase their talents, and they certainly deliver. No need for car chases, guns, explosions or sex. That would only distract viewers. The Decalogue is pure gold.

reviews.review_title: Goes to show the importance of actors..
reviews.content: I saw this tonight on IFC and couldn't believe I hadn't seen this for so long! It's one terrific movie, with great characters enacted by some of the best actors in film. Not to mention the razor sharp dialog with some of the finest lines ever written!The film begins with a scene on one rainy night, when some real estate salesmen are subjected to a very harsh speech by Blake (Alec Baldwin) on how to make the right sales. They have to work much harder now (for which he announces three prizes), or they lose their jobs (that's the third prize!)! The film catches on from there, and we immediately start relating to the desperate situation these guys are in.Al Pacino had an Oscar nomination, and he was great, but I think Jack Lemmon deserves kudos for his portrayal of Shelley Levene. He breathes so much life in his character, it just goes to show the amount of importance there is to casting the right man to portray the right character! An all-male cast, the choice of actors is perfect: Kevin Spacey, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Al Pacino, Alan Arkin....Alec Baldwin makes a brief appearance but he practically rules the screen in that one scene. His dialog with the others present in the office is priceless!Even Jonathan Pryce appears very convincing in his short role.This one is highly recommended. Do watch this film at least once!

A film that is both realistic, and amazing.A stella cast that don't overact to make the film 'theirs' and a story penned by David Mamet. This film focuses on the lives of a bunch of real estate salesmen facing tough times.We have: Jack Lemmon, a fast talking salesman on a losing streak. Desperate to make a sale to feed his family, he tries everything he can to get the loot. Visiting a potential customer late at night. Trying to bribe the office manager to give him some good leads. And eventually robbery.Ed Harris, a sharp-tongued loud-mouthed yob of a salesman who's at the end of his tether and ready to jump ship, with the leads in hand.Alan Arkin, another moaning salesman trying to quietly make himself some money. The most sombre of the group, but still obviously frustrated by the whole sorry state of affairs.Al Pacino as the hotshot salesman on a good streak. Trying to close a deal with a client he has dug his claws into.Jonathan Pryce as Pacino's client, who's dubious about buying.Kevin Spacey (amazing performance) as the manager, who doesn't quite no the score.and Alec Baldwin, as the company exec. who's getting tough on his salesman to get them to do their job."Make a sale, or you hit the bricks..." --- Basically the story is a follow round. We just watch these men go about their business, and it's so well done you think you're shadowing them or something, for real.The acting talent is obviously good, and the story is even better.On the hot night, themes of desperation, egotism and ruthlessness comes to hand as these men try to make the sales, and then resort to more dangerous means of survival.It's hard to find a film quite like it, a slick moving tale that is absolutely amazing. And one of the best films of the nineties. I recommend this highly. It is fantastic.

As a longtime Educated consumer of cinema, I can say with some authority that this is truly an outstanding picture. Each member of the amazing ensemble delivers a remarkable, authentic performance rivaling the very best that have been committed to this medium. David Mamet's dialouge is rich and real the brilliant work of a man who intimately knows both his subject matter and his craft. The mystery is not why this film is so highly rated by users of this forum but rather why its cumulative score is not approaching the Excellent mark of 10. Perhaps some mechanism could be established within this forum to test the intelligence quota and film knowledge of those providing ratings and comments and assign an appropriate weighting to the scores and comments provided. Just a thought.In any case, this is truly an amazing picture and stands out as one of the great films ever made.

Pressure is the theme of this movie. All of the characters receive pressure from somebody. The lucky ones give more pressure than they receive. There is heavy use of profanity and I think it is appropriate to convey the levels of pressure caused by disrespect.This movie gave me an opportunity to evaluate my own limits of tolerance for overbearing management. I thought this movie was great because the dialog was unpredictable, the characters were emotionally squeezed and I felt their pain. I really had a new appreciation for the life I was living. Nothing compares to the speech by Alec Baldwin. I would compare the drama and pain to Cuckoo's Nest and Reservoir Dogs. This is one of my top 10 dramas and I gave it a 9.
Great adaptation of a play, some parts didn't work that well in a movie though.

A somewhat uneven film, it is still worth the rental price for the five minutes that Alec Baldwin spends on screen.  In a blistering performance, a company motivator utterly degrades some hapless salesmen with the most painful dialogue I have ever heard in a movie.  Acting is top-notch throughout, as some of the give-and-take between Spacey and Lemmon almost made me squirm.  A must-see.

reviews.review_title: What is the draw to this movie?
reviews.content: Never have I been so bored watching a movie... I was "this close" to shutting it off but thought "Something interesting has to happen soon; this movie is so highly rated." So I trudged on, constantly checking the counter to see when this horrible thing would end.Jack Lemmon's character was whiny, imbecilic, annoying and definitely slap-worthy.DeNiro's character was pompous to the Nth degree; he's the type of person who would con your grandmother out of her life savings just so he could get a freaking car.Ed Harris's character was a complete idiot; I nearly fast forwarded through all of his lines... he just wouldn't SHUT UP. The more he talked, the more annoyed I got with him.Arkin's character was a doofus plain and simple. If he was any dumber, it would have been illegal.Kevin Spacey's character.... what a reprehensible idiot.The movie lacked direction; it just seemed like it was made up on the spot without any regard to a plot. All it was was a bunch of middle aged men cussing at each other and calling each other names. How utterly boring!!!!! What a waste of a Sunday afternoon.

reviews.review_title: Didn't enjoy it, don't believe the hype
reviews.content: After seeing glowing reviews and being referenced in the Boiler Room I decided to see this movie. I didn't enjoy the experience, which makes me wish I saw the play instead.Overall, the movie was balancing on the borderline of boredom the whole time. The plot (if there is one to be found) is rather difficult to follow, as everything is scripted into the dialog, which itself is unbelievably repetitive ("we can't work with these leads," "yes we can't," "we need the good leads" and again again). I even resorted to read a wikipedia transcript of the plot in order to see whether I was missing something.-MINOR SPOILERS- Actually, the movie felt like it was deliberately made with the intent to throw the viewer into the movie and expect him/her to pick up details from the dialog. I appreciate the fact that it is based on a Broadway play, but as a movie, some background to the characters and main plot points would have made it easier to digest. For instance, how was I supposed to know the property they were selling was worthless? I wasn't mentioned anywhere, so how was I supposed to feel sympathetic to the buyers? No, I don't need a narrator to walk me through the problem holding my hand, no just one line somewhere would have done the trick.Also, I didn't understand the hostility of the salesman towards their branch manager. If they were such good salesmen, and hated their branch/manager/product/leads so much, why didn't they just pack their stuff and move on to another company? Their constant nagging and complaining made up 80% of the screen time.On the upside, the acting was really good and intense, and as a result it represents three out of my four stars. Check it out, if you feel like watching a handful of angry men argue for two hours, you won't miss out much if you don't.

There are so many good words about this film that I shall add just a perspective comment. I spent 2 years in sales with IBM and another 12 with my father's consulting company - and still have to sell myself as a consultant today. When I saw this film, freshly out of IBM when AKERS damn near drove the firm into the ground, it was horrific for me. I remember the Akers "water cooler" memo, that all the salesman were standing AROUND THE WATER COOLER. "PUT THAT COFFEE DOWN" had real effect and, watching it again, it still is -to anybody in sales- a horror film of the first order. Monster? Blake fills that role perfectly. It is the group sales meeting from hell, and the rest of the film is watching elderly salesmen, every one a WILLY LOMHMAN have a pity party. It strikes FEAR into anybody who has summed up monthly quotas, justified meetings. A unique horror film indeed. 10 out of 10 IF you can stand it and NOT get some coffee during the show.

To put it simply, this is one of the best movies ever, not only because of its incredible cast. The plotline is sharp and the pace is very good as well.Just listing the actors involved you get impressed (Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin). The latter, in spite of his brief appearance as the mean Blake, turns on a stellar performance.
I don't think the rat-race has ever been better described than in this film. The real world in most jobs is like we see here. If you don't make it to the top, you're just fired and that's it for you.Too bad that movies like these (Realistic, to say the least) are not generally very accepted by the bulk of the public.10/10.

Don't waste your time. Just a bunch of poor salesman complaining that they're getting bad leads. I was in sales my whole life, you can't depend on the company for leads. This is so unrealistic and poorly acted it's pitiful.

When first viewing GLENGARRY...., I couldn't help but think of Thoreau's line "The mass of men live lives of quiet desperation." Except, in this version, it's more like loud desperation.    The theme of the movie is real simple and potent, all human power grows out of a person's ability to make money now. Who you were, who you know, how long you been doing it don't matter much.    There are no women in the movie, and the only woman mentioned is Lemmon's daughter, who's dying in the hospital. So, the maternal life force of creation is ripped away, leaving only the death force of men destroying one another.    Jack Lemmon's character is a guy who would like to believe that he was more like Al Pacino, a man he admires and not like Moss, the loud mouth loser. But, Pacino can make a sale in a bar to a total stranger, and doesn't have to show up to meetings, while Lemmon is stuck begging for lead cards.   They say that the saleman is drama's most tragic character, because their jobs are so intertwined with their human worth. As someone who occasionally worked in cold sales, there's nothing greater than that feeling of conquering a lead. But, if you fail, your soul is emptier than your wallet.   Favorite piece of dialogue: "What's your name?" "F**k you, that's my name! You drove a Hundai to get to work! I drove an $80,000 BMW! That's my name!"

reviews.review_title: An excellently written and acted masterpiece.
reviews.content: David Mamet is one of my absolute favorite playwrights and exceeds with screenwriting as well.  Mamet and the director have assembled one of the greatest collaboration of actors in film history.  The film is rather talky but the performances were so great, I wanted the film to go longer because the characters were developed so well.

reviews.review_title: Starts off slow but picks up later on.
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is a movie with all dialogue and No action. So if you're expecting another die hard or scarface, you will be disappointed. But if you like to watch a movies with mostly dialogue and some humour along the way, this might tickle your fancy.Since i don't work in the business field, or work at all, i was unsure of what the people in this business were trying to sell and why they were competing against each other. But i'm sure everyone else will. :) None the less, this all male cast movie was okay and i think the director did himself good by casting Al Pacino, because the first 20-30 mins of the movie wasn't so engaging and that's probably due to Al Pacino's absence, who comes into the movie around half an hour later.The non draining length, big actors and some memorable quotes, make this movie worth seeing once. 7/10.

reviews.review_title: A movie where actors truly get to excel in their craft.
reviews.content: I watched this movie about a week and a half ago kind of having an idea of what it was about and then not really at the same time. I did know that it was based on a play though. I thoroughly enjoyed it, I will say. I thought all of the performances from all of the actors in this film were uniformly excellent. I do want to highlight Alec Baldwin though, because he gets one scene early on in this and it is used to tremendous effect. It packs a wallop. It really is an "Actors' movie" where actors truly get a chance to shine and perform at length. This movie is entirely 100% dialogue, so if that's not your thing then you may not like this movie but I honestly did not have an issue with that. It's described as kind of a black comedy but it's mostly serious. I can definitely say that I would not want to be in this business at all. The pressure these guys were under to close deals is just too much.

I once saw David Mamet on a Dick Cavett show perhaps in the 70's and I was impressed with his wit and overall charm. I wrote him a short letter attesting to his performance and amazing as it may seem, he sent me a postcard from San Francisco thanking me for my interest. I was a resident of that wonderful city at the time. Why am I writing this? To let him know if he reads this that I think he is an incredible writer. Glengary Glen Ross is totally absorbing in the verbal exchange between the characters. It is so true to life. You end up despising all of the real estate salesmen because they toy and play with the truth and are all downright dishonest. Each has a price. At the end when Spacey says to Lemmon 'I despise you, always have', I only wish Lemmon had said the same about him. They all were despicable and so alluring in their lives of lies. I give the movie a 10 out of 10.

This movie is intense almost from the start, you're pulled straight in and can almost feel the pressure of the characters to make sales.There's some very memorable scenes and quotes and all the actors do a brilliant job with their characters. I'm a huge Pacino fan and am disappointed with myself that I've never seen this before because this is one of his greatest.

When it comes to theatre scripts being adapted into movies, the one very hard thing to do for a director and a screenwriter, is finding a key point to the situation on which they can fix a sequence of shots. In the theatre, the setting includes the whole scene, with the keypoints all moving along simultaneously without needing to switch from one to the other. When it comes to a film, the director and screenwriter have to be able to reverse engineer the script, in order to find all the key points, give them the structure of sequential shots and edit them together in order to create the feel of the scene progressing. Very few have done it so brilliantly as Glengarry Glen Ross. Performances aside, the very best thing about the movie, for sure has to be the script. Entirely revolved around dialogue, it manages to suck in the audience and keeps them on point right untill the end. There is barely one moment throughout the movie where one can stop and collect one's thoughts.
The primary subject is the working class in a land ruled by capitalism, pushed to the bone and always sharp and focused when it comes to the job. What happens when they're backed into a corner? They have no choice but to fight in order to keep their job and sure as one can be they will fight, for no matter how much they argue and critique the capitalistic system, they are a product of it. And being a product of it, they have a sense of how to move in it and turn it's tables.
Just as the movie shows, friendships do not last long in such a society, for they are all dealt with in machiavellian fashion: if need be they are formed, but as soon as the task at hand is accomplished, they are erased before they can backfire. All that being said, Glengarry Glen Ross is a truly wonderful movie, not only is it gifted with wonderful performances, it works around the subject of the victims of capitalism, a subject not easily portrayable in a realistic and convincing fashion.

One of the greatest movies ever made, yet so underrated by the public.A fabulous ensemble cast in Lemmon,Pacino,Baldwin ( the first time I ever enjoyed his acting)and Kevin Spacey.Pacino was nominated for an Oscar as best supporting actor. He should have won. His performance as hot shot salesman Ricky Roma is sensational as is Jack Lemmon's performance as a former top salesman now on the skids.Anyone contemplating becoming an actor should keep this movie in your favorites and study it for techniques in acting,directing,photography, and brilliant writing.I love this movie, and have watched it on numerous occasions and always found something new it had to offer.It almost makes a person never want to join the world of real estate.

Big fan, screenplay and cast (6 Oscars). Watched it many times. Keep wondering about things that detract from the denouement, the two big surprises at the end:Why give as lead people the company know are insane?When did Roma bring Lingk's contract to the office? Was Williamson there? So, let's say Williamson came back from his home under the pouring rain and met Roma at the office sometime before midnight (let's say Roma convinced Lingk to sign sometime after 9 or 10 pm, going to his home and meeting his wife (who later somehow retracted blaming his husband?)), then he didn't take the contracts home so he could spend some time with the kids, when, at midnight?Doesn't make much sense.BTW, since Williamson usually took the contracts from the office to his home for filing at the bank, how exactly was this filing made?

This is a horrible movie. This is what happens when you act and direct like it's a play, but film it. It's a waist of the medium of film. It was painfully annoying and boring to watch and I won't stand for it.

Competently shot, and you can hear what the actors are saying. This came out within a certain year. There certainly was a lot of G's in the title. Fastforward until today and you can see why no one remembers it. So that's something.

reviews.review_title: Fear and Loathing in Real Estate
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is a movie based on a play about real estate by David Mamit. The office where the men work is the unhappiest place on earth, not one minute passes by in the movie where the characters don't insult each other with vulgar language, and it's perfect! Jack Lemmon is a down on his luck real estate agent who will be fired unless he closes some houses within the next two weeks. Lemmon can't close though because he has nothing good to work with, he is at his end and is desperate for a sale. Al Pacino is the top seller at the agency, who knows how to work people. Ed Harris is another worker contemplating robbery to steal leads, which would help him sell houses and not lose his job. Kevin Spacey is the office manager and is always caught in the crossfire of the troubled workers. This is a great movie with superb casting. The movie is purely dialogue, so if you're a brainless action fan, you might not want to check it out.

reviews.review_title: tense drama about working life for the downtrodden prols
reviews.content: A film about working in an office? how good could it be? as so often the most basic of concepts allows good acting  and great scripts to do the real work of the film, outstanding performances by Kevin Spacey, De niro, Alec Baldwin, but for me the absolute clincher is the brilliant Jack Lemon who sweats desperation and desolation from every pore, there is no happy ending to  this  film,  its  about how hard life is,how working with assholes realy  sucks, how making ends meet is all  that  really  counts, and how no one cares if your  wife is critically  ill in  hospital  and  you  cant make  the  medical  bills,the fact its too real for comfort doesnt make it any less brilliant or noteworthy, perhaps some people dont want to watch a film  that makes them feel  theyve done a hard day at the office, im just awstruck by Jack Lemon who made me forget he was a movie star and had me living the life of a desperate man who despite his best efforts could grasp only failure and impotence when he most wanted dignity and respect.

reviews.review_title: Never again will a salesman set foot inside my house
reviews.content: I loved the film, and gave it 9.  My wife hated it and gave it a 4.  So rarely are we divergent, although we both agree that the acting was outstanding!The actors bring the characters to life and you'll hate most of them, and feel really sorry for some others.  Jack Lemmon's performance soars high in this film.The film adaption of the play works this time ( I find that it rarely does) and shows how far people in commission sales will go to make a deal.  The lies are incredible.The double cross concerning the robbery, and the poor man trying to cancel his deal(see the film and you'll understand), are other examples of this.Finally, if swearing bothers you then you'd better not see this film.  It gets really bad in some places.

reviews.review_title: Top actors in cheap and boring movie
reviews.content: Can't say awful if there are : Al, Jack, Ed , Alec ... Without these guys would be clear ZERO. Production and scenography are like in 40s or 50s. I have seen this movie because of 7,9 @ IMDb. Those are reviews for big names not for movie. Boring. Don't waste your time. If a movie had $2 millions in first week, But total gross is $10 million you can figure out what about is there. I am fan of Mr. Lemmon. So this one supposed to be last bigger movie before he became old and grumpy man. He had couple TV movies . Short Cuts is much better movie but Jack got smaller role. So again,don't waste your time with Glengery Glen Gross. Don't watch any other instead of this one . But if you like to see good actors and performance in bad movie than go ahead.

This is a great way to show that a movie cannot only be a theater replay. I can easily see that on a theater scene it would really be interesting to see the characters conflicting with each other, defending every bit of themselves to get their commission if they can make the sale. One can immediately extrapolate to the selling of time sharing.
But ... this is a movie and all the talking and talking gets tiring and boring. Talking is acceptable when dealing with critical subjects (take for example "Conspiracy").
With this Glen Glen Ross we quickly understand the desperation of these sales people. Over two hours of this does not improve in any way the movie nor the performance of the actors.

reviews.review_title: This movie got me through college
reviews.content: And we probably drove our Sales professor NUTS demanding to watch this film during class. Of course we were never able to, but that didn't stop us from quoting it incessantly. I have never seen a film in which the entire script is so incredibly 'quoteable'. This movie definitely deserves a spot on the IMDb top 250. There have been so many references to this film in popular culture, from movies like Boiler Room, and cartoons like the Simpsons, and songs from bands like the Bloodhound Gang. If you watch the special features, you will see college students trying to act out the role of Alec Baldwin, but of course they fail miserably. Nobody could have pulled that off like Baldwin did...But Pacino's performance this entire movie was just simply awesome. Besides Scent of a Woman, I don't think there is a finer performance by the greatest actor EVER, than Glengarry Glen Ross.

I think you missed the overall theme here, so i'll briefly touch on it. Glengarry Glenross gives us a fundamental understanding and insight to where capitalist society has led the western world.The false ideology of material possessions as an escapist reality and money being the driver to all ends. The shallow soulless of the hard hitting boss, who's only concern is too squeeze every dollar possible from the employee's rip off sales, which struggle to make ends meet. This movie is brilliant and accurately depicts capitalism's cut throat - dog eat dog society at its very worst.And this naive faith requires necessary illusion, and emotionally potent oversimplifications, which are provided by the myth-maker to keep the ordinary person on course.

I bought this movie because Alec Baldwin (one of my favorite actors) is in it. I'd never seen it before--wasn't interested when it first came out in theatres, had never even seen the play on stage--but I'd heard Baldwin was brilliant in it, so I bought it.Now I'm kicking myself for never having seen it on the big screen. And I've seen it at least a dozen times since buying it.The story, if you've read any reviews, you already know: Four guys in a real estate office (Jack Lemmon, Alan Arkin, Ed Harris, and Al Pacino) are in a sales contest from "Mitch and Murray", the big bosses from downtown. As the slick-suited real estate millionaire sent to motivate the sales force (Baldwin, in a role written expressly for the film) explains, "First prize is a Cadillac.[...]Second prize is a set of steak knives. Third prize is you're fired." With such motivation complete, Office Manager Williamson (Kevin Spacey, in his first big role) hands out the night's allotment sales leads, and they're pure drek...driving the men to various stages of desperation to ensure they don't fall off the sales board.That's the story. What makes this movie work is the outstanding performances. Pacino as office hot-shot Ricky Roma got the film's only Oscar nod for acting, but the late, great Jack Lemmon's performance as Shelley "The Machine" Levine would have been a better choice. Levine hasn't had a sale in months, and has lost his edge; his scene bargaining with Williamson for a better lead capsulizes Levine's frustration and fears perfectly. Just to watch Lemmon, a wondrous actor, bring every nuance of this character to life is fascinating; it is truly one of the best performances of Lemmon's career, and one of the most underrated.As for the reason I bought this in the first place, Alec Baldwin? He's magnificent. You'll forget he's only in one scene; his character's threats and emotional manipulation swirl through every scene in the film. His profanity-laced motivational speech is searing; you can feel every man in the room cringe as he verbally emasculates them in the name of generating more sales for the unseen Mitch and Murray. And the film's most quotable lines come from him: "Put that coffee down! Coffee is for closers." "What's my name? F--k you, that's my name! You know why? Because you drove a Hyundai to get here, and I drove a $80,000 BMW. THAT'S my name." "A-B-C--Always Be Closing. Always Be Closing. ALWAYS BE CLOSING!"Enough talking. See the movie.

reviews.review_title: The ultimate ensemble of today's finest actors
reviews.content: When I ran into Al Pacino in the streets of New York the other day, and wanted to say something memorable to him, the first thing that came to mind was "'Glengarry Glen Ross' is one of my favorite movies!" (Later on I kicked myself for not praising a film closer to his heart, the outstanding documentary "Looking for Richard").Pacino is just one reason this film is among the best showcases of superior acting we have. It was Pacino who was nominated for a Supporting Actor Oscar, but the most vibrantly desperate actor in this film full of end-of-their-rope flunkies is Jack Lemmon, never better than here, as a true Willy Loman type driven to contemplate serious crimes by his desire to move up the sales ladder at cost-cutting real estate brokerage. He must fend off Pacino, an intense Ed Harris and a cowering Alan Arkin. The winner gets a car, the runner up a set of steak knives. "Third place is your fired," shouts Alec Baldwin, in his most intense screen performance, as part of a brilliant diatribe in which he eviscerates and emasculates the underachieving salesmen.Add Kevin Spacey and David Pryce to this marvelous cast, who get to speak some of the best lines David Mamet ever committed to paper, and you've got an intensely satisfying tour-de-force that's constantly riveting, despite the fact that the locale rarely shifts from the office and a nearby bar. Some movies written by Mamet are stultifying, since all the parts must perfectly blend for an audience to appreciate a filmed play. ("American Buffalo," despite the presence of Dustin Hoffman and Dennis Franz, is one of the worst sleep-inducers out there).But "Glengarry Glen Ross" is not for a moment dull, so colorful are the ideas of alienation and desperation, and so verdant is the dialogue, chock-full of perfectly intoned f-words. Baldwin's 15-minute monologue -- his only scene -- is the stand-out sequence, but Pacino also does a so-smooth-it's-chilling monologue with Pryce, the sweating potential customer wooed by Pacino's Ricky Roma, the current sales leader. Spacey, in one of his first prominent roles, plays a rule-enforcing office manager who absorbs insults like a battered sponge; Harris and Arkin sweat and kvetch aggressively and passively, respectively; and Lemmon is simply transcendent as he stammers toward his inevitable fate.The ensemble effect is simply smoldering. Go rent "Glengarry Glen Ross."

reviews.review_title: With a cast like this, how could they possibly fail?
reviews.content: "Glengarry Glen Ross" put me very much in mind of Arthur Miller's 'Death of a Salesman", in that it gives a marvellously accurate portrayal of the struggles of the working man, this time in the field of real estate sales. A small group of salesman, who have struggled to close any deals recently are given an ultimatum: close your next few deals of else lose your job. For a little added incentive, the man who makes the most sales will win a Cadillac.  Simple enough storyline, you might think but the magnificent ensemble acting is a joy to behold and makes the film truly great.  Al Pacino, as always, stands out as hotshot salesman Roma and the supporting players are just as impressive, including Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey and a particularly fiery Ed Harris.  Even Alec Baldwin turns up in a memorable cameo early on.  However, for me, the real star of the show was the late Jack Lemmon who played the frustrated loser to perfection and really made you feel pity for his character. An extraordinary achievement, "Glengarry Glen Ross" is one of the best films I have seen recently and all involved deserve credit for making it so hugely enjoyable.  Great stuff.

reviews.review_title: Excellent film about everyday life in the working world.
reviews.content: I had put off watching this film for a long time.  I have always seen David Mamet as an excellent screenwriter and director, and I look forward to seeing what he has done for the upcoming "Hannibal".  However, this film didn't seem to be one that would hold my interest.After finally viewing it, nothing could be further from the truth.  This is another of Mamet's excellent efforts.  I have always found Mamet's characters to be his strong point, and this is no exception.  His representation of the average working man is right on par.  This movie centers mainly on the characters, and not on outside events which they cannot control.  Each of the main characters in this film are responsible for their own actions, and they each decide their fate.  An excellent character study.Jack Lemmon shines in his role, as do Al Pacino and Kevin Spacey.  (In fact, Al Pacino was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.) Of course, we can't expect anything else from these actors, as all have shown themselves to be highly regarded in dramatic roles.  Ed Harris makes a good showing, and Alec Baldwin is surprisingly effective as well.As I have mentioned in other reviews, I often like to be entertained while having to think about a film at the same time.  This film allows for this. However, while this is an excellent Mamet film, it's not his best.  For one of his best in my opinion, have a look at "Homicide", but don't let young children watch it because of the excessive (but still not overdone) coarse language.My Rating:  8/10

I hadn't heard much about this movie before watching it but since it had an all-star cast, I figured it couldn't be too bad. I was wrong because it turned out to be excellent. In fact I found myself not wanting for it to end so soon. The movie is heavily conversation based but the script is so good that it easily carries the movie way beyond any need for a lot of action or suspense. Kevin Spacey delivers his usual style and Pacino, along with Jack Lemmon really shine. Alec Baldwin delivers a great performance as well with his opening scene. Ed Harris is the angriest of the lot but he has some of the most difficult lines yet delivers them smoothly. Just by watching this movie, you begin to understand what good actors really are. This is one film where I can safely say that my time was well spent watching.

reviews.review_title: The best acting ensemble in recent memory
reviews.content: This is a film that challenges your beliefs in the working class system - the do or die spirit that this country has based itself on for many years. Al Pacino.  Kevin Spacey.  Ed Harris.  Alan Arkin.  Alec Baldwin. Jonathan Pryce.  What a great cast.  And Jack Lemmon proves why he truly is one of the Great Ones.Alec Baldwin has probably the best 4 minutes in his acting repertoire.  To me, Baldwin is a great character actor who needs to get himself some really challenging roles, and not try to be a movie star so much.  But lines like "See this watch?  This watch cost more than your car!" and "Coffee's for closers only." are given with malice and loathing.Al Pacino is terrific as usual, and Ed Harris takes griping to a new level. But Jack Lemmon's performance, as a man really on the end of his rope, is breathtaking.  This man should have gotten an Oscar for this, no doubt about it.  I'd like to think that Ving Rhames saw this movie just before he gave Mr. Lemmon that Golden Globe a year or so back.Finally, props have to be given to Kevin Spacey, who, like a spider, studies the web that is his office, looks for the first one to be trapped in it, and sucks them dry.  A cold and calculating performance.Check this one out.  You won't get actors like this together again for a long time.  What a movie.

This movie is quite simply one of the best and most overlooked movies of the 20th Century. Powerful, accurate and marvelously acted it will take it's place as a great American Classic Movie in the afterlife of video. Do not miss this movie.

The theatre in this film is poetic. Backdrop and environment was irrelevant as it was all about the marvellous play between the cast members. Baldwins speech is one of the finest monologues in cinematic history. Lemmon, Pacino and Harris all brilliant.The social comment of the film is the most important thing about it -- the dollar drives everything, including self worth. Results are everything, and the only thing that matters. The means of achieving results are irrelevant, and if this means pitting humans off against each other to achieve outcomes that is ok. And finally, the consequences of creating such a culture is irrelevant.Thank goodness in 2023 we are conscious that culture matters, and that outcomes need to consider people beyond dollar alone.Is all the profanity necessary? No. But the point of it is thats just noise used to accentuate the stress of the environment. Its contextual.Shocked at the low review so I read some of the 1 stars and the best explanation I have for them is: you either like theatre or you dont!

reviews.review_title: Tremendous movie, Jack Lemmon is absolutely the best!
reviews.content: *I will try to avoid Spoilers, rent it!*There is no sexno violence.no CGI, car chases or exploding buildings. The only two women in the movie are seen for about ½ a second in a hat check room and putting two unappetizing donuts on a table, that's it. What the movie does have are half-dozen GREAT actors, working in perfect sync, and one of the greatest scripts ever written.Glengarry Glen Ross is about the stomach-churning world of hard sales, ruthless predators and their prey. This movie is about fear and survival on an almost primitive level and these actors deliver.boy do they deliver! This stable of actors portrays perfectly the cameo of the salesman with all of the associated despair, uncertainty and FEAR. For these salesmen, furnaces-stokers in a boiler room, when times are bad, they are very, very bad, and when times are good, they are not much better. 'What have you done for me lately' is the operative phrase delivered by the company lackey Sales Manager John Williamson, who is parenthetically verbally abused by all his salesmen. Jack Lemmon gives an all-world performance as an aging former top-performing salesman that has lost his edge and is rapidly burying himself in to the heap of has-beens. Ed Harris plays the very essence of a typical salesman, always bitching and never quite realizing his potential, mostly because of his own soured attitude. Alan Arkin as George is the most eviscerated salesman, having lost all of his confidence and the ability to close the deal. Finally, Al Pacino is the most successful and competent of the bunch, a swaggering bullshit machine that gives s the performance that should have won him the Oscar that year. The Salesmen are caught in a vicious Catch-22. The leads are tepid and stale and they cannot close them. Ironically, the often-dissed Sales Manager will not let loose of the Glengarry leads (genuine leads that they COULD close) until this rag-tag bunch demonstrates that then can close the unclosable ones. The anguish, anger and fear are ratcheted up a few notches by a "motivational" speech given by Blake (Alex Baldwin) at an impromptu Sales Meeting. Baldwin gives a brilliant performance and anyone who has been in Sales KNOWS and recognizes this type of speech. Motivation by extreme intimidation and threats, not unlike the "motivational" speech given by Gunnery Sgt. Hartman in Full Metal Jacket. Berating the Salesmen in the most inhuman fashion, Blake lowers the boom, telling them that the 1st price for the Sales Contest is a new Cadillac, 2nd prize is a cheap set of steak knives, and the 3rd prize? YOU'RE FIRED!Mamet is one of the finest writers of our time and the dialogue is crisp and filled with vitriol. The "fuck you!"' is spat out vehemently and often as the Salesmen lash out at a situation that grows more and more intolerable. There is not much of a plot, but not much of one is needed, as the character development is intense and spellbinding. The dialogue is breathtaking as the men struggle for survival with animal like desperation and intensity, not unlike starving predators on the Serengeti Plain, looking for a kill. Shelly Levene's performance and plight are awesome and heartbreaking, as he will try any tact, legal, moral or otherwise, to make a sale. His Sales Manager is about as much help as a anvil in a life jacket, refusing to do anything to help his men do what they desperately need to do....Sell, Sell, Sell!The DVD set contains some great extras, including a wonderful 30-minute tribute to Jack Lemmon, one of the greatest of the greats. We'll miss him and miss performances like he gave in Glengarry Glenn Ross.10.0/10.0 Top Pick!

This cinematic success is indeed that. A film of words. The play itself was not as dialogue heavy as this adaptation and that is the genius of Mamet. He has condensed a perfect piece of spoken theatre into an even better piece of modern cinema. Sure enough it is under the guidance of another director but this is Mamet. The man writes characters, action and tension as it appears on screen. That,however, is not what makes the film as great as it is. Oh no! What pushes this film to the level of landmark which is held upon is the outstanding cast and their breathtaking performances. This should be remembered as the film where Spacey found himself, Pacino re-discovered his passion, and Alec Bladwin silenced everyone who thought he was nothing. As his charcter says in the film. F*** You, Thats My Name!' Cinema as cinema was designed to be. A success.

This is one of the few movies that really kept me watching & interested in what was going to happen next. The acting & story are superb. I am only surprised that not too many other people that I know have seen this movie. Besides Amadeus this is one of my favorite movies & really impressed me.

reviews.review_title: This film is an underrated classic...
reviews.content: I have been meaning to watch this film for years and finally have got around to it in 2003...it is devastating, sad portrayal of the life of a salesman. All of the performances are riveting...I never liked Alec Baldwin, and maybe it is because he plays roles like this one so well; he is totally despicable! Jack Lemmon is phenomenal as always (wouldn't this make a great double feature with "Save the Tiger"...are you listening TCM?) Alan Arkin is another underrated treasure and Spacey and Harris are also great. Never a dull moment...

"Glengarry Glenrose" is based on a Pulitzer-winner play, that's why I had been expecting a very good film adaptation, before I rented the DVD. Unfortunately, it was kind of a disappointment to me.The film has a great cast, full of well-known and talented actors such as; AL PACINO, K. Spacey, J. Lemmon and A. Baldwin with a short performance. But no matter how hard they try, it couldn't help this film.I have no problem with the film set. I think, a film is suppose to entertain me as it belongs to the entertainment business. But this one fails to do that.Also,when I heard some people say that the film, has a great deal of meaningful words, mostly spoken by Alec Baldwin's character, I was surprised. Because, he abuses and curses again and again, almost every second, he participates in the film.Well, the film is not really my cup of tea, but if you're only interested in Jack Lemmon's good acting, you should give it a chance.

The concept is great. The real estate agents of a firm are about to get fired by their new boss. Only the one selling the most will get to stay on.You think you are in for a treat. Some of the actors are good, some should be really good. There are reviews praising this.What you do get is actors you thought were good screaming a four letter word starting with F at each other for the length of the film, incompetently huding that there is only plot for a few minutes.It's like an inside joke on the viewer. Do you join the jokers and praise the movie or do you admit the truth, that this is a truly awful movie?My recommendation: Avoid this movie!

reviews.review_title: You don't sell a guy one car, you sell a guy five cars over fifteen years.
reviews.content: "I know what I'll do.  I'll rob everybody blind and go to Argentina because no one's ever thought of this before.""Is there an absolute morality?  Maybe.  And, then what?  If you think there is, go ahead, be that thing.  Bad people go to hell, I don't think so, you think that, act that way.  Hell exists on Earth?  Yes.  I won't live in it. That's me."I had to post again about this movie.  It's beyond words!  I love it through and through.  I've memorized most of the dialogue.  It helps when you have a friend who has done this too, so you can reinact scenes when you are bored. :)  So what is wrong with this world?  Why is there no special edition DVD?"Gentlemen.  You heard the man.""What is this in aid of?""As of tonight...""No what is this?  Excuse me!""Excuse me.  What it's in aid of is that Mitch and Murray...""F*ck Mitch and Murray!  F*ck em!  I'm doing my job I gotta put up with this childishness!?""Those are the rules.  I'm paid to run the office.  You don't like the rules, Dave?  There's the door!!"That was to illustrate some of Mamet's ingenious use of symmetric dialogue. "Yes.  The cops.  No."  My favorite scene is where George presses Dave on whether he talked to Jerry Graff.  You'll have to watch this a few times to really appreciate it.  "What did I say?  What did he say?  What did he say? He'd buy em!""F*ck you, that's my name!  You know why Mister?  Because you drove a Hundai to get here tonight, I drove an $80,000 BMW.  That's my name.  And your name is you're wanting, because you can't play in a mans game, you can't close them, then go home and tell your wife your troubles.  Because only one thing counts in this life!  Get them to sign on the line which is dotted!"

reviews.review_title: This kind of movie doesn't need a plot.
reviews.content: Admittedly, this film does not have the most labrynthine story line that's every been created, but David Mamet -- one of the great writers of this quarter of the century -- has written one of the most interesting, depressing, hilarious and thought-provoking screenplays of this decade. Based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning 1984 stage play, "Glengarry Glen Ross" excels in it's added scenes (including Alec Baldwin's best performance, albeit 4 minutes and sans the "I am God" whisper) and incredible dialogue. If you don't think it's going anywhere, maybe you aren't paying attention. Even without the swearing, the tension that the dialogue creates gives us more of an insight of what's going on than who-broke-into-the-office? would. And even if the dialogue doesn't grab you, how can you not be excited by 6 of film's best actors in arguably the best performance each has done. Pacino is a fireplug whose arrogance you actually grow to love.  Arkin is the only redeeming character.  Lemmon is alternately annoyingly-brazen and pathetic.  Spacey is the louse that we've all met somewhere and Ed Harris is magnificent with jealous rage.  And don't forget Jonathan Pryce (from "Brazil" and the Infiniti commercials) playing a guy who's too smitten with Pacino to say no to him.
