Foley's direction is terrific, with little touches like the Wayne Shorter soundtrack, the chugging subway every time a character goes on a rage, the gloom of the rain, all adding up to one hell of a depressing and exhilarating film.  You may feel a little uncomfortable watching it, but you're supposed to.

reviews.review_title: This movie should be called The Color of Money
reviews.content: No women,No kids,no smelling.Everybody is full of fury and fear,the one who closed a deal can say anything to others' faces.That's businessmen's life,that's what the movie about.The script is amazing,the actor team is dream team.If you are one of the company people,watch it.

reviews.review_title: This does not deserve anything close to a 7.8, DON'T WATCH THIS!
reviews.content: When I was described this movie by my uncle, I expected something miraculous. The only part of this I find remotely entertaining was the acting, which was good, unlike anything else in this movie. That's why I gave it a 2 instead of what it just about managed to avoid, a 1. Would this movie be anywhere if it did not include Al Pacino? I doubt it.The big investigation and mystery was 'Who broke into the the office', and 'Who stole the list of people who want to buy houses'... Can it get any more boring? I won't tell you who it was, but I really think jamming forks into your eyes would be a lot more interesting, but either would put you unconscious.Even The Simpsons made fun of it with Gill. I'm not sure if they think that the obsessive use of bad language adds to the excitement or suspense of it, but I really think that it doesn't. Al Pacino is a great actor... I mean Godfather II, Amazing... But he hit a low that I thought no one person could reach. Anyone involved with the making of this movie should be shot. I have never seen the play, so I will not comment on it, but it couldn't possibly be worse than the movie. So if you want to subject yourself to such torture, watch the unrated by me-play.It isn't the no.1 worst movie, let's leave that with Superman Returns. So instead of watching this, watch The Truman Show... That is the No.1 best movie, and is rated .1 out of 10 better than this terrible, dull movie which is rated completely wrong. DON'T WATCH GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS.

Absolutely ASTOUNDING!!! This motion picture is just Unfreakinbelievable!One of the most powerful, gripping, knock-out movies you will ever see, GuARantEED!I mean even from the first scene, it presents itself so true, real and raw that you'll get completely pulled in and stuck!And the characters, OH MY GOD, where do I start? Each one of them have been displayed so strong and believable that you won't believe that it's a movie. You'll think that this is who they really are and this is actually happening to them.It was so full-blown that I actually thought it was in 3-D for a minute! That's how hard they come at you!Hats off to Pacino, Lemmon, Harris, Baldwin and Spacey...they were TOO outstanding, none of them could've played their roles any better than they did!They only downside was, that I was having so much fun that I didn't want it to end. So it didn't quite go out with the BANG I was expecting. But all in all, a bloody GREAT film!

reviews.review_title: a word on the production design
reviews.content: I agree with the many words of praise already expressed here: thescreenplay and acting are brilliant. But I want to comment onsomething that surprisingly has not been metioned yet and that isthe production design. I saw this movie for the first time in 2003. I know that it was madein 1992 but does it really take place in 1992? It's hard to tell. Itseems like the producers want us to think we're in the 30s or 40s,with the minimalist sets, the lighting, the music. The entireatmosphere. Even the opening titles. Is he purposefully drawing parallels between real estate in the1990s and earlier in the century? I guess even 1992 seems dated. Nowadays these salesmenwould have cell phones and internet connections.

reviews.review_title: An excellent film and a well written play but...
reviews.content: I think this is an interesting and intelligent script and the acting in the movie is superb. I think the atmosphere is well thought out and the character motivation works. All the pieces appear to come together in the plot...but... the fowl language is extreme.I do not object to the language because it is profane, but because it goes overboard. People under pressure do act irrationally and they do lash out, but this is extreme. I don't know of any work environment where people refer to each other as "c***suckers" either to each other's faces or with such frequency. No boss would tolerate his subordinates to talk him with such blatant disrespect. I also don't believe that level of cursing would occur because it is unprofessional. However, the company executive (Alec Baldwin) coming over and acting the way he did, that I believe.Mamet is an excellent playwright, but he goes overboard in this case. I still highly recommend this movie and the interesting human interactions that occur, but you should keep in mind that this is a bit extreme. If he modified the dialogue a little, I wouldn't have any real complaints.

reviews.review_title: If you have ever sold anything, see this movie
reviews.content: David Mamet has really captured the pressure of selling.  You can change the product, but anyone who has ever made a living on straight commission sales will relate to this movie.  The cast is incredible and everyone acts out their parts extremely well.  However, Alec Baldwin and Al Pacino really capture their characters.  This movie alone made me a David Mamet fan.

This film is so macho it could star Arnie.The language by modern standards is totally shocking.As a piece of its time, reflecting that time... it is brilliant.I mean. It's not an easy watch if you have sensitive ears for 'what is appropriate' but I struggle to imagine this sort of dialect and just pure male-driven environments did not exist.It is a good film. Perhaps having 'spacey' in it aptly summarises it.He has been derided and his career destroyed, yet the films he has appeared in have often been great. And he is that 'black sheep'... there's been plenty of those throughout history.

reviews.review_title: Never give a star an even break
reviews.content: This movie reminds me of the Prince's new clothes. The problem with stars like Pacino is they need a military dictator to keep them in line. Mamet was too lenient with this cast and as a result we get something rarely seen in American films - ham acting. Goodness - you would think Pacino was doing Lear and Lemmon  gives a poor and over-egged performance partly because he was basically past it. I cannot see what all the fuss is concerning Mamet. He is a good craftsman but where, pray, is his so-called original and exciting talent ? As far as I can see he is a poor American version of Pinter. No doubt his knowing style over content post-post-modernism is the best our particularly lackluster generation can achieve, but those who fete him could do well to imbibe pre-Star Wars culture and get some perspective. Pacino and Lemmon are some of my favourite actors and they have done some fabulous work. It is a shame everyone here made a fool of themselves and a woeful sign of the times that this stagey dinosaur is so highly regarded.

This is the Great American Dream as it has seldom been shown: stark, vindictive, cruel. A company wishes to get rich by selling parcels of land to speculators. A team of salesmen are assembled to make the sales. An unknown group of buyers (the leads) are out there for the salesmen to lock onto and talk into buying the parcels. Are the parcels of any value? We do not know, it is not important. What we do know is that the company has an incentive scheme to encourage more and more sales. The person with most sales in a given period gets a reward. But it isn't enough. The "boys downtown" are unhappy with the level of sales, a "cleaner" is sent in motivate the salesmen. It is a new motivation: the "closers" of contracts get their names on the board, a chance to win "first prize, a Cadillac Eldorado, second prize, a set of steak knifes, third prize, you're fired." Who is the motivator? A new kid on the block (Alec Baldwin) with a watch that cost more than the salesmen's cars, who drove to the meeting in a $80,000 BMW, and who earned $970,000 last year. And the salesmen? One of them was Shelley Levene (an outstanding Jack Lemmon). We gather that he needs money desperately, his daughter is in hospital, there are bills to pay. And he "hits" the script running - a man so deep into despair, his situation so hopeless that you can almost touch it, and his attempts to disguise this, to remain upbeat, above all to sell, sell, sell. This was a cruel film. The company wants to get rich and doesn't care what depths the salesmen go to, the salesmen want to make a living, and we assume that buyers buy because they see this as some get rich quick scheme. Greed, greed, greed. And then there's Shelley Levene who cannot speak to his daughter because the phone company disconnected her phone because the bill wasn't paid. And he needs the money! If it wasn't a film you would try and make contact so you could give it to him. It was that kind of film. It was very uncomfortable viewing.

reviews.review_title: Do you know what the shot is?
reviews.content: I see you're checking out Glengary Glen Ross, you've got a good eye. This compact, economical yet powerful little vehicle punches way above its class. Pacino's legendary portrayal of Ricky Roma elevates slick salesmanship to an art form. Baldwin's motivational sales conference rivals Henry V's St. Crispin's Day speech. In fact, the entire cast makes it rain with stellar, career performances. But the Cadillac prize goes to Mr. Lemon's sacred personification of Shelley "The Machine" Levene. It was solemn, effing solemn. The tears in his eyes at the end still gets me. Only a true master could close a performance like that.Mamet's writing is gold, the old stuff. The educational value alone is priceless, let alone the immortal monologue, commiserations, tell offs, colloquies, smooth talks and gut splitting one-liners. GGR is as much a documentary on the hard knock life of real working people as it is an ensemble character film. Mamet's beleaguered salesforce survives on its wits and its minerals alone. Their struggles, ambitions, fears, envies and responsibilities could only have been written by someone with a bit of hard knock life experience to draw from. Experience today's company writers in hollywood are utterly lacking. GGR's 2 hr struggle session of hard-boiled, atavistic street philosophy yields far more enlightenment and edification found in current day media and academic echo chambers. This little peach should be required viewing for graduating high school students heading out to the workforce.And remember - you never open your mouth till you know what the shot is.

reviews.review_title: A "boiler room" drama, with no heroes.
reviews.content: This is a movie where all the main characters are neither heroes nor victims. They are villains in one way or another. And the biggest villain of all is probably the Company itself. I'm not sure if David Mamet had the intention to juxtapose a sub-plot, which will be the treatment of the agency to its work force. Once the individual performance reaches its peak, and starts declining, the boss finds him no longer indispensable and treats him like a disposable money machine, reflecting the dark side of capitalism.Dave Moss (Ed Harris) said it as a subliminal introduction: "they don't give us the leads, they don't give us the support, they don't give us ... " And that is reflected, first from Alec Baldwin's monologue, and then, by the boss who does not advice his staff that there are customers with dubious reputation, and they should be avoided.This movie is not far from reality. Many salesmen who work in the "boiler room" often end up burnt out, divorced, and wasted. A great film.

This is, by far, the best screenplay that Mamet has created. It is adapted from his play and it is amazing. Every single performance deserves a standing ovation (even in a movie theatre). It has a stage-like feel about it that actually works. The confrontation scene between Pacino and Spacey ("YOU ARE A CHILD") makes you squirm. The final scene between Lemmon and Spacey (Lemmon: My Daughter. Spacey: F**k you.) is gut-wrenching. "Will you go to lunch. Will you? Will you GO TO LUNCH!" still echoes in my mind. Awesome, amazing film. Bravo, Mr. Mamet.

reviews.review_title: Movie was Depressing. Thankfully, Not Realistic. Typical Leftist Hollywood Capitalism Bashing
reviews.content: Firstly, people don't talk profanely like this, using he F word in every other sentence. Secondly, people don't rant at co-workers like this. If they did, nobody would work there. There is no such thing as friendly normal conversation. So, the movie is unrealistic. Thankfully.It's just the typical pessimistic atheist Hollywood view. No wonder atheists lead all belief in suicide. This movie is so depressing. The darkness, the pouring rain, the vile talk. It paints capitalism as completely cutthroat, when in reality, capitalism gives the best results of any economic system. Also,good salesmen aren't like the ones portrayed in this movie. They're honest, good people, looking out for others. That's what makes customers trust them.I was not a better person for having watched this movie.

An excellent sales motivating movie, the best of its kind. Baldwins' performance in this movie is Masterful. He is a die-hard salesman that knows what it takes to close the sale.A,B,C and A,I,D,AAlways, Always... Be ClosingAttention, Interest, Detail, Action.Attention, Do I have you Attention.Interest, Are you Interested?Decision, Have you made you Decision.Action, Sign on the line, which is dotted.A movie for anybody that is in sales. A movie has a cast you would not believe all of the top players. Baldwin, Harris, Pacino, Spacey, Arkin.If you think you know sales, watch this movie, and you might learn something... 10/10

This is a story how the stresses of work really can rip at a mans soul. This is the world of cold-calling real estate sales. 5 middle-aged men, in close confines, trapped in a sleazy terrain, day after day, they are hooked on abuse, perpetually bitching and tearing each other apart.It is sad, but the movie is gripping because the acting performances are truly extra-ordinary. You can select any one these actors -Spacey, Lemon, Baldwin, Pacino- and adulate over their intense performnaces. Any movie would be elevated by just one great performance, this one has four, plus, there's more. Alan Arkin, Johnathon Pryce, Ed Harris, they also bring in great performancesJack Lemmon's performance was nuanced, his voice and face portrayed the fear and sadness underneath a phony exterior, one of the greatest performances I've seen. A lot of actors have great performances based on intensity, but Lemmon here did it on a great range of emotions.The abuse and despair will turn off some people, but I think the story is relevant to everyone who feels the accumulated stresses of a tight work environment, and the sadness of having some career that somehow, before you could see it coming, becomes an abuse trap with no way out.

Superb acting and cast undermined by terrible acting. Jack Lemmon and Al Pacino carried the movie. Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris did the expected. A lot could have been achieved but it is a lost opportunity. Aesthetically inferior props were employed, which could have been improved upon.

I guess that just about sums it up.  Having seen this film, which is a barely opened out version of the stage play - I'd really like to see the stage play.I'm sure it would work much better in a small studio theatre - the sort of space where you can reach out and touch the actors - than in a large theatre or on the cinema screen.That said, there are some great performances in this film.  Every time Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino or Alec Baldwin are on screen it's riveting.  But they're stage performances, not film performances.

This film is what I would call "dialog intensive".  Excellent cast, excellent direction, excellent camera and lighting.  If you're a salesperson, this film is a must for you.  While you might not be in this same situation, you (being in sales) can certainly relate.  We've all met the saleperson who "thinks" he has the biggest brass on the block.

reviews.review_title: You may get a headache... but it's worth it!
reviews.content: Oh what a magnificent film! If only every movie was half as good as this one, then going to the Cinema would be akin to a religious experience!The script was intelligent, the Direction superb, the ensemble of Movieland's finest male thespians make this one of the greatest films I've ever seen. Feel yourself get drawn into the claustrophobic, climactical ambience of their interplay; but don't buy any Real Estate from them! 9/10

The main reason anyone would watch "Glengarry Glen Ross" nowadays is the simply dazzling cast line-up, there can be few films which boast such an array of U. S. male A-listers.And why wouldn't those guys leap at the chance to participate in a theatrical, character-driven piece with lashings of dialogue to play with?And indeed why wouldn't people queue up to watch them? I remember some of the hubbub which surrounded this film when it was first screened back in the early 90's.And there's the rub - it was made in the early 90's, when yuppies were a thing, and while one can read some social conscience into this piece, it is nonetheless firmly focused on greedy, grubby capitalism at its worst. A world in which a man's worth is measured by how much he paid for his wrist watch, and even the guy who opens his mouth to protest goes quiet when attention is drawn to his own humble timepiece, indicating a sharing of these values.Something about it reminded me of "His Girl Friday" - another film which looked great on paper but in practice turned into a joyless couple of hours of shouting inspired by the American Dream of cold, hard dollars.I'm sorry, but it's just not entertaining or enjoyable to a normal, balanced European - unless perhaps you lump yourself with Yeats when he wrote "we who seven years ago talked of honour and of truth, shriek with pleasure if we show the weasel's twist, the weasel's tooth".What a shame something more enduring, inspiring, uplifting or simply enjoyable could not have been made with such a tremendous cast. I don't think I could bring myself to sit through it again.

reviews.review_title: Pretty good for a movie with no explosions
reviews.content: Alex Baldwin reminded me of my father, I cried for 4 days after watching this movie

reviews.review_title: all-star cast, razor sharp performances. four stars.****
reviews.content: An intense character study, focusing on the lives of salesmen, brilliantly illustrating the fine line they walk between success and abject failure. This would have been a good film with less talented actors, as the David Mamet screenplay was superb. The treat is, with this film, the cast is unparalelled. Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alan Arkin, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey, and a smaller but no less striking performance from Alec Baldwin, raise the story to it's highest form. Sales may be the specific lifestyle examined here, but the issues at the heart of this outstanding film, are universal. Respect, dignity, the notion that success is a fleeting dream to be lived only by those who would eschew all ethics in order to achieve it.  The cutthroat nature of man is exposed, and for all it's ugliness, we must accept that it does not only exist in the high pressure world of salesmen. A sobering look at the world in which we all work, whatever our chosen profession, dignity and respect are in short supply. If you ever appreciated "Death of a Salesman", you will thoroughly enjoy this film. Highly Recommended. Four Stars out of a possible four.****

This is an excellent 'film'.  I place that in quotes because, since the picture was based of David Mamet's play, it is less of a 'film' than it is a play put on the big screen.  Where this picture excels is in its dialogue (the film is essentially, entirely dialogue) and its performances.  Al Pacino is charismatic and exciting.  Jack Lemmon is utterly wonderful, believably downbeat yet electrified and invigerated during his sales pitches.  Basically, every one of this picture's main characters is excellent.  The angry Ed Harris has a lot of power, Kevin Spacey is superb as the slimey, despised "child" boss with brains if not experience and Alan Alda is low-key and as skillful as ever.  The story is very small in terms of where it takes the viewer (quite literally the street, the office, a bar, a some doorsteps) but the broadness of the characters and the skill on show more than make the picture enjoyable.Its not action packed in the traditional sense, but watching such a fine cast work their magic is more than enough reason to watch it.8/10

reviews.review_title: Is this supposed to be drama?
reviews.content: I read about this movie on IMDb and persuaded my wife to watch it with me. Such GREAT actors - yes! And excellent acting - so true! But as mentioned by another reviewer, a great deal of gratuitous swearing. No matter, I would endure that to see the great drama portrayed by great actors.But as the play wore on, I lost any affection for the characters, largely because of their swearing. Only Kevin Spacey was 'nice' and went home to spend time with the family.Lo and behold, the climax and denouement arrive (don't blink, amidst all the shouting and swearing you might not notice it) and the whole issue turns on a fact blurted out during yet another tirade of swearing.Mr foul-mouth gets his come-uppance, Mr nice guy wins, and does it all without swearing or being nasty, and still gets to go home to his family.I'm all in approval of Nice Guys finishing first, but is that it???? Is that all David Mamet, the playwright, can make out of this????How much better is this than the old Western formula of Black Hat=Bad Guy, you always miss, White Hat=Good Guy, whose gun always hits the target and who always gets the girl? Not much better, for my money.To sum up, GREAT actors wasted on a dramatic yawn. Three out of ten.

A rip-roaring and fast-paced script that takes place over a short period of time in a real-estate sales office.The acting is top-notch as the crisp dialogue is non-stop.The over emphasized egos and over-the-top verbal abuse might turn off some viewers,but it's certainly hard to neglect the overall impact you'll get from this "in your face" office drama.Pretty solid.8/10.

This movie isn't a lot of fun to watch, but it is an interesting study of personalities.  It can teach you a lot about people. The acting is excellent, the characters are realistic, and the movie may stay with you, even years later.

reviews.review_title: This movie helps take a load off.
reviews.content: This one keeps your eyes and ears glued to the screen for the duration of it.  What's interesting is that the movie packaging gives one the impression that you're about to watch a drama with heavy organ music and all the rest of it.  I wasn't expecting an in your face comedy/dialogue machine that doesn't stop.  I would say the best performance comes from Jack Lemmon. They are all superb though.

reviews.review_title: This movie helps take a load off.
reviews.content: This one keeps your eyes and ears glued to the screen for the duration of it.  What's interesting is that the movie packaging gives one the impression that you're about to watch a drama with heavy orgam music and all the rest of it.  I wasn't expecting an in your face comedy/dialogue machine that doesn't stop.  I would say the best performance comes from Jack Lemmon. They are all superb though.

Intense drama that will keep you riveted until the end credits crawl. Written and adapted from his Pulitzer Prize-winning play by David Mamet, which means the dialog is spicy, fast-paced and extremely profane. This film is an excellent character study on how the mind of a salesman works, and it is so true to life, its scary. Fantastic performances from the entire cast. Check out Kevin Spacey as the harried office manager who has to protect the good Glengarry leads, to Alec Baldwin as the sales manager from "downtown", who initiates a sales conference that is little more than an exercise in abuse. From Jack Lemmon as Shelley "the machine" Levene the old pro who's lost his stuff, to Al Pacino as Ricky Roma, the flavor of the month, who is well on his way to winning the Cadillac Eldorado. This is some of the best acting you will ever see, and its definitely worth the price of admission. This film should be prerequisite viewing for all sales reps."Get them to sign on the line that is dotted!"

I loved it, my wife hated it. I thought it was perfect, she couldn't understand a thing that was going on. It's not that it was a Mars and Venus thing, it was that I'm a salesman and she's a teacher. If you are in sales, you identify with every little thing that goes on, and understand the weight and emotion behind the dialogue. If you know what it is to only make money when you perform, you understand the desperation that drives the characters. If you aren't a part of that world, you probably won't enjoy the movie as much, and if you're like my wife, it might even irritate you a bit. So, it's kind of a niche-specific movie, but those who can identify with it will love it. Bottom line: A must see for anyone in sales!

This was the funniest movie I ever seen. The first time I saw the movie I was in stitches. Alec Baldwin fires in with a comical 10 min. speech at the beginning of the movie. "Put that coffee down!!". The look on Lemmon's face was priceless. Then there was the scene where Ed Harris threw a temper tantrum at Al Pacino. That's just built in comedy right there. He walked out the office yelling, "f**k the lot of you, f**k you all. It was great. Spacey's character was a real a**hole. He had some great lines in there too. "Will you go to lunch, go to lunch, WILL YOU GO TO LUNCH!!" LOL, it was out of control. Finally, the dude that stole the show was Pacino. The scene where he tells off Spacey's character was the greatest scene in the movie. Everybody told off Spacey in that movie but Pacino walked away with it. "You never open your mouth until you know what the shot is, YOU F****N' CHILD!" or "what you're hired for is to help us, not to F**K US UP!!" That s**t was the craziest s**t in the world LOL LOL LOL. Pacino deserved that nomination that year along with Scent of a Woman. That is in my top 10 favorite movies of all time.

From the opening titles to the closing titles this film is very gripping. The cast are superb, Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon are the cream of the crop, in this tale of salesman.  David Mamet has again created an excellent script with the actors use to their advantage.  Foley does a very good job of keeping the word-heavy film moving along but not at the expense of cutting the actors off in mid flow - each scene seems to run to it's natural conclusion.

reviews.review_title: One of the best ensemble films ever
reviews.content: Fabulous cast gives a collective virtuoso acting performance in this adaptation of David Mamet's Pulitzer winning play...I promise you, you will NEVER see an acting clinic like this in any single movie! Baldwin, Lemon, and Pacino should have retired after this one-my eyeballs are still seared from their performances!

reviews.review_title: Give me my god damn leads.
reviews.content: I really want to count how many times "leads" is said in this mothaf0cking film. They used "f-ck" 138 times, and I wouldn't be surprised if leads is in the same sort of bracket. Funny thing to open a review with, sure, but they used some words a hell of a lot. The dialogue is really fantastic though, and the repetition of some words just seems to add to that. Of course they keep ranting about "leads" -- their entire lives are defined by the damn things. The acting is also really good, and I'm disappointed Baldwin only had one scene (which was by far my favorite one). All in all, it really got under the skin of the problems faced by these salesmen, from a useless and annoying boss to customers who just aren't interested. The desperation caused by threats of job losses is really sold here, which is a really relevant theme at the moment (and probably always is). It wasn't really perfect for me though... I sometimes got annoyed with how a character would go from a huge loudmouth to mute, almost as if they were waiting for the next (admittedly entertaining) rant to reach its climax. It also had a plot twist I didn't see coming, which was nice.My rating for it may actually go up an entire point at some point, depending on if I ever get the notion to rewatch it. Right now, I don't think I'd want to see it again outside of the Baldwin scene.

reviews.review_title: doesn't get any better than this...
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is an absolutely incredible film,  nothing about this film is bad, starting with the best title sequence since Carlito's Way, it is a tour de force for everyone concerned.Alec Baldwin has a searing four minute slot that seems to hang over the entire film (possibly the only man in the world who actually has a set of brass balls, even if he does keep them in his briefcase), Al Pacino is at his best, never overacting for a minute, and never giving the ott "I am Al Pacino" performance that he has a tendency to do. Jack Lemmon is also outstanding as the desperate, rundown Sheldon Levene.The supporting cast (if you can class Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris as supporting cast) never falter for a minute, giving a depth to the whole film that modern movies often miss. EVERY character in this movie is complete and you feel like you know them all by the end.However, the part that captured me most was the overall look of the film, almost entirely in strong blue and red lighting that changes and moves with the sound and rhythm of the passing trains that dominate many of the scenes.This is possibly my absolute favourite movie of all time, and one I come back to time and again.

Being a big David Mamet fan, I always liked the play of "Glengarry, Glen Ross" and I was a touch sceptical about the film, but on finding out the amazing cast, I suddenly brightened up!Seeing Jack Lemmon in probably his best acting role of his life, along with Al Pacino, Kevin Spacey and Jonathan Pryce who are all very fine actors just makes the film so special to watch because the acting is so strong that you could mistake the film for real life - almost one of these fly-on-the-wall documentaries.But it is Lemmon who steals the show with some superb method acting and something that takes a lot to equal."Glengarry, Glen Ross" is a superb film, especially if you feel life is getting you down - rent it, buy it - just see it!

reviews.review_title: Better than not bad, worth your time.
reviews.content: This movie was not bad.  It was a play made into a screenplay and it felt like a play.  Which is not a bad thing.  The acting was not bad at all, it was good acting.  The story was not bad.  And the way the actors handled the story, was good.  Very good.  It is worth watching for that reason alone. The way in which the story was acted is the one thing that pushes me to grade this movie as better than "not bad".I didn't know who was cast in the movie when I sat down to watch it.  So as each new huge actor walked into the movie I was surprised, and amused.  It was as if they all got together to so some hard blue collar work.  I mean, like factory workers putting together a special team of the best in the union to do some solid production, these actors went to work and put out a quality product.  I don't know how long they worked on filming this movie, but I bet it was done quickly without any problems.  If someone asked me for a good title to check out, I don't think this one would immediately pop into mind.  But I think it is a good movie, and I do think it is worth your time to watch this team go to work.

reviews.review_title: lemmon , pacino at the top of their game
reviews.content: somehow this film got by me over the years, with the current Broadway revival reminding me i had missed it, i rented the video. i am very glad i did. even in a uniformly brilliant ensemble cast , jack lemmon and al pacino manage to stand out. i have seen virtually all of pacino's other films , and all of lemmon's work from 1970 or so on (save for "alex & the gypsy", which is not on video). i consider this film their greatest performances. they were both a bit over the top in their Oscar gigs, "scent of a woman" and "save the tiger". here , lemmon is able to make you care about a character who is the embodiment of the typical annoying salesman we have all been subjected to at one time or another. pacino manages to be utterly hilarious while staying within the context of a drama. if a film has excellent acting , yet is not entertaining , i point this out to friends and in my online reviews. this film has both incredible performances and holds your interest right to the end. the director acquits himself very well , but the one negative comment i feel i must make is that the "boom mike" or its moving shadow is very visible in some scenes.

Jack Lemmon Alan Arkin Kevin Spacey Ed Harris Alec Baldwin and Al PacinoThat should be enough right there to make any film outstanding... some of the greatest actors of 2 ages of cinema... and yet it fell flat... The set up is that it is an exploration of the machinations behind the scenes of a real estate sales firm. Now right there I can sense a starting point for some serious moral conflicts, the lying, deceit, double crossing, double talking, and flat out inhumanity of the salesmen against their clients, and also against each other... And yet there was very little of that... Then came the *spoilers* robbery plot... a 10 minute discussion Moss and Aaronow, only to have Levine get in on it in the end, sure it was a nice little surprise, but where was the development of his character to that point? The phone calls, I guess, were supposed to accomplish that, and yet I had to watch it twice to figure out that his daughter was in the hospital and he needed money for something... that should have been more fleshed out. Then Moss's character, high impact from the start, stealing whatever scene he is in, and there's nothing with him...Lastly, was Roma... his deal with Lingk had everything, the intro, the sell, the gradual luring in of Lingk, Roma slowly attaching one claw after another onto Lingk until he falls hook line and sinker, only to have a crisis of conscience, which opens the door for Roma's double talking, lying, word-twisting, misdirection, sell his mother to avoid losing the sale situation, and what... it's crammed right into the middle of the police investigation sequence... It should have become the only thing going on on the screen, but no, it shared the screen with the po-po... and thus its impact was lost.All in all, it had a lot of potential. If they had opened up the film, explored Moss and Levine's characters more, and then put Roma's situation front and center when it was happening, the film could have been truly great... and yet it wasn't. Boiler Room, while about the same in quality, showcased the evilness of the sales industry much better. GGR had slightly better writing and performances, BR had better plot development.

I was blown away by the incredible acting in this movie.  Even Baldwin's performance was outstanding, and one of the most memorable cameos of all time.  I felt like I was watching a play, and the plot unfolded as such. Imagine Pacino, Spacey, and Lemmon trying to outdo each other.  This is a film you have to see if you're a movie buff.

I bet a lot of the people who hated "My Dinner With Andre" would love this film: they're both nothing but guys talking, and yet "Andre" is intellectual/philosophy, and "Glengarry" is completely UN-intellectual-- cursing, intense acting, memorable characters (Lemon's "Shelly Levene" is the obvious inspiration for the Simpson's "Gil" the hapless salesman), and not much else. What I find most amazing (besides the acting, which is nearly flawless throughout) is how much of the dialogue is really trite and meaningless: cursing, shop-talk, complaining, boasting, avoiding the subject, and YET it is still so engrossing-- a testament to the talented actors who breathe life into it. Pacino's final scene with Pryce is perhaps my favorite-- he is desperately trying to keep Pryce on the hook, to the point of playing dumb, and makes Pryce's character look like an idiot.I find NONE of the characters at all admirable; they all have a layer of slime on them, even Lemon's Shel "The Machine" Levene, who has a certain humanity to him (desprately trying to help his sick daughter) becomes nothing more than a greasy salesman/con man once he picks up the phone (note how his tone of voice immediately changes-- no wonder people hate salesmen so much).My favorite line is one most people won't notice or remember (most people focus on Baldwin's haranguing or Pacino's curse-fest)-- towards the end, Arkin picks up the phone, mutter's "God, I hate this job" and dial's up a potential customer-- priceless, that says it all."The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation."-- Thoreau (although in this case, they're not so quiet about it).

You'd think more people would have heard of this splendid movie, considering the high-profile of so many of the actors in the film, not to mention David Mamet.  This movie is very highly recommended for any fan of great acting, writing, and movie-making.  When viewed as an allegory of modern times, this seemingly simple story is frightening in its implications of moral inversion and the spiritual death of the salesman.  But make no mistake; above all, Glengarry Glen Ross is consistently entertaining and brutally accurate, as those who have worked in sales will tell you.  See this movie right away.

reviews.review_title: Glengarry Glen Ross (1992) [Directed by James Foley]
reviews.content: Sure, David Mamet's screen adaptation of his own Pulitzer-winning play is extremely well-written, but let's face it: Glengarry Glen Ross is nothing but a showcase for great performances. But then again, what's wrong with that? Especially when the performers involved are this talented (e.g. Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino, Kevin Spacey, and Jack Lemmon -- and yes, I did write Jack Lemmon twice). Afterall, there's nothing quite like watching Kevin Spacey ask Ed Harris to go to lunch... six times. In actuality, however, almost every single performance in this film -- INCLUDING Alec Baldwin, if you can believe it -- is Oscar-caliber. And at the end of the day, that's the only thing that makes it possible for such an ordinary concept to become such an extraordinary film. The story of Glengarry is rather bland: four real estate businessmen have to improve their sales or find a new job, and in order to accomplish this, one of them breaks into his office building and heists the "golden leads" his boss refuses to give out. Sure, there are a few surprising twists and turns, but the real treat of the movie is the chemistry between the characters. In an interview, director James Foley stated that when Alec Baldwin arrived on the set, the other lead actors treated him -- and I quote -- "like s**t," making his performance (which basically consists of yelling at the four realtors and telling them to "f**k off") even more realistic. Al Pacino -- who earned the only Oscar nomination for the film -- is equally phenomenal, but as I hinted earlier, the true star here is Jack Lemmon (and I'm not just saying that because he's six feet under). Jack has always been one of my favorite actors, and to watch him play such a different role -- which would later be spoofed on The Simpsons as a down-on-his-luck businessman named Gil -- was a sheer treat. The other thing that I really loved about Glengarry was the mood: film-noir has always been my favorite genre, and it really takes over the first act of this film, made evident through the constant rain, the dark bars, and the desperate characters. Overall, Glengarry Glen Ross is a thoroughly satisfying drama worth being watched more than once.Grade: A

This movie is good, but could be much much much better. THe cast is excellent, and they all play their roles well. the plot however, leaves something to be desired. as an avid al pacino fan, i readily watched this film expecting the usual al pacino elements--drama peppered with some of pacino's amazing humor. however, there was very little drama and very little humor. the plot is too simple and at times the movie drags on. the writers should have added some action in the way of some violence, extortion, etc... after all this was in some ways a money laundering plot....however it lacked any elements that go along with money: violence and sex. in fact, there is no female character in the whole film. the writers could have let the thief get away for a while, enjoy his spoils...and then finally let him get caught. all in all, the movie is well acted but definitely in my opinion, incomplete.

If you don't like swearing this isn't the movie for you. But, how this is not rated higher on IMdB I don't know because Glenngarry is quite simply a masterpiece of film making. You are literally transported into the lives of ordinary down trodden and down on their luck (mostly) salesman in a testosterone-fest of dysfunctional office life. The production work with such a low budget is beautiful, the acting is incredible, the script sublime and the plot so simple but so plugged-in to sales culture that it has you one minute laughing and next gripping the chair. Bravo!

There are several points to keep in mind when you are watching this movie:Everyone in the office (with the possible exception of Pacino) is a poor salesman. They are having trouble making ends meet, and with good reason - they have themselves to blame! Approximately half the movie is spent with someone moaning about their poor leads. If they were any good they would suck it up and get to work.I'm surprised that they get any sales at all when they have such a negative attitude in the office.Another thing to note is that this movie depicts old-school, high pressure sales. This movie continues to perpetuate the myth that in order to do well at sales you must be a good talker. You notice that the salesmen are speaking most of the time, instead of the client in every situation in this movie. Perhaps if they were to ask the prospects some questions and listen to them attentively, they might actually find out what the prospect needs. Then they might have a clue how to sell them!Lastly, these salesmen all are shown lying to prospects. If you are going to have any long term success in sales you are shooting yourself in the foot by lying! It always comes back to haunt you.Watch Boiler Room instead.

Well written characters make this an excellent movie. The acting and casting in the film was perfect. It shows a realistic, but sometimes grim look at the sales world. I think anybody who has been in sales would enjoy this movie.

In my world, I would almost characterize this film as a "sleeper". I am always surprised at how few people I know have seen this movie, given how incredible it is and the fact that there are take-offs of GGR moments and characters found in so many TV shows. Those in the know usually put this film in their top 25.Obviously, this is no "action movie" that drags in the unwashed masses. Instead, the popularity is due to the characters and the acting. This, in spite of the solid story that provides a framework. This dark tale is sort of depressing if you're in sales! The performance of Jack Lemmon in this movie literally brings a tear to my eye. He was so incredible that I immediately started digging up and watching (or re-watching) every movie with him in it. What a genius he was.As for the others, there is no debate that this star-studded cast gave performances that would be expected of actors with their significant credentials. That said, I do part company with many of my fellow reviewers. Kevin Spacey and Ed Harris (and of course Jack Lemmon) were convincing in their roles, and their characters made sense. I did not feel the same about the others.One of my all-time favorites, Al Pacino, undoubtedly brought his own flavor to the Ricky Roma character, and it didn't work for me. He was simply too, well, "weird" in sort of a "Scent of a Woman" way, and his bizarre vocal inflections and body movements were an unwelcome distraction.Alan Arkin's character, George, (as opposed to his portrayal of it) was not believable. He came across as so dependent and mentally challenged that success in sales, or any field, would be unlikely and he would have starved to death long ago.Alec Baldwin is in the same boat, in that while he powerfully played a character that was already established in the writing and the play, his character was not believable. I don't see how "Mitch and Murray" would have let their operation get to the point it was and then send this pit bull in there. Or maybe, they were just bad enough managers to have done that, which I guess WOULD make sense. In any case, it is over the top. That said, it was very important to establish early in the story that one COULD be wildly successful in that business, so you would have a context for the other characters.Some have commented about the film's geographical setting, and it is ambiguous enough that it is almost distracting. People seem to believe that the setting was New York. After all, it was filmed there. I was certain that it was set in Chicago and that the outside shot with NYPD-colored police cars was an uncharacteristic affront to a viewer's intelligence. Not only does every city mentioned exist around the Chicago area (as well as NYC - with the exception of "Batavia" which is a suburb of Chicago but hundreds of miles from NYC), but I have a hard time believing that when people in NYC need to get away, they "go to Wisconsin", as Dave Moss said he was going to. I think that debate is settled right there. They were just too lazy to truck a few Chicago Police units to Brooklyn.

reviews.review_title: Allstar cast that swears like sailors
reviews.content: I've heard about this movie for years and then when I finally saw it.....disappointment. It's like a Quinten Tarantino film...without all the violence. I turned it off 3/4 of the way through it. Just came across as a fine cast with great performances by Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Jack Lemmon, Al Pacino and Kevin Spacey, but the language was just way too much and distracted too much from the story. An agency full of realtors that have to break all the rules to keep their jobs is a bad start as it is. I think it's dream of actors sometimes to find a roll where they can talk like sailors and get it out of their system. It's so melodramatic that it's not funny and you wonder just how much more vulgar these guys can get.

reviews.review_title: Why did Hollywood stop making film like this???
reviews.content: It took me by surprise how this one is rated under 8. With the most amazing cast one could ask for in a movie (no argument there), GGR simply can be considered one of the best movie out there for at least another few decades. It took me twice the running time to really catch on with the film's plot, I was watching it first time pretty "absentminded-ly" but it caught my attention half way through that I had decided to go back and watch again from the beginning. I have to say this is rare since usually by now I would have turned it off and left it somewhere in dirt and might or might not come back to give it another try ages later which lead us back to the point I am trying to make: it's really really good!!! And pay attention to Alec Baldwin damn he's hot as a J@ck@$$, I can't believe I missed it the first round. I am not an expert myself to write a full length review with all the fancy words but I highly recommend it to everybody to give it a try. This is one heck of a movie that doesn't require steamy cleavage or luxury cars and impressive explosions (yeah i'm talking' about u Mr. Bond) to create the WOW factor. It's one of those that you either love it or hate it (seeing it was rated below 8 probably helps proving my case), plus in my experience with friends of mine, it might be a bit too "masculine" for female audiences since I have not met one with the same gender that enjoys it but hey I am a girl and I LOVE IT.

reviews.review_title: One of *the* best films in cinema
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is to me one of cinemas' greatest films ever made. Supera acting and script, to me this film is more of a comedy than a drama. The language is brilliantly written, makes me laugh everytime I watch the film.  Not to be watched by people who are easily offended, because there is a lot of language.

I had to watch this film for my most recent English class and it was one of the most boring movies I've ever seen. It was hard to follow and felt like nothing happened the whole time. There wasn't a single person of color or woman character in the entire movie. I just watched a sad group of old white men talk about nothing for two hours.

reviews.review_title: Gil's gotta get a break... "Papa's needs a new pair of shoes..."
reviews.content: Anyone notice how Matt Groening based the character Gil in The Simpsons on Jack Lemmon's character in this movie? Just goes to show that David Mamet hit the nail on the head with this character...Andy Scholes.

The rhythm and texture of the dialogue is great, and the performances are magnetic. But even so, the story and characters are shallow and largely uninteresting.Apart from a couple of unique scenes (one where Alec Baldwin steals the show), this film is mostly a 5 minute argument on repeat:"I can't sell our product because I'm given terrible leads."
"They're not terrible leads, you're a terrible salesman."
"You can't talk to me like that, you piece of garbage!"
"Oh, did I offend you, you terrible salesman?"
"F--- you!"I can't recommend this film because it's monotone and lacks substance; but I'm glad I saw it for the skilful execution of dialogue.

reviews.review_title: One of the most realistic selling scenario!
reviews.content: The movie is one of the most concise, power-packed performance given by the cast in about 100 min. The tagline, "A Story For Everyone Who Works For A Living", is very apt.Al Pacino is at his very best delivering a true story on the part of a salesperson and so has Jack Lemmon and Kevin Spacey.Its engrossing and the viewer fails to get off the screen for even a single inch of time. It connects with every salesperson in a way that he knows best. Getting nominated for the Best Supporting Actor, Al Pacino has delivered with excellence. Direction is nicely achieved. Language is REAL throughout and represents the very same scenario which every salesperson finds in his everyday job floor. Alec Baldwin's performance though short lived has a long lasting impact throughout the motion picture.The message is very well received. Go ahead and DO YOURSELF A FAVOR, watch it!

It's a movie starring a whole slew of great actors that include Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey, and a small memorable bit by Alec Baldwin. All the actors have great performances tied very nicely into a terrible plot. I'm guessing it's for that reason that I've never heard much about this film. It goes to show that if you put together a bunch of great actors with a bad story, a good movie it does not make.My rating is 2 stars it would have been one had it not been for Alec Baldwins performance. He was very cool and funny. For that it gets an extra star.You may skip this next paragraph if you so choose. As it is meaningless =to my official review. Movies under five stars do not deserve ten lines but rules are rules.Nothing good happens in this movie and through out my life I've been accused of only liking films with happy endings. well, I'm sticking true to form for this one. This sure isn't a movie with an invalid Barbara Stanwyck.

reviews.review_title: A Superb Cast, A Superb Script, A Superb reflection of the working man's struggle to survive!
reviews.content: I was in an American History class, when my lecturer told us we were watching a film based on a play from a great American playwrite.  I'd never heard of the film, and very few have with its awkward title.  So my expectations were none-existent.  What I saw was 8 fantastic actors at their best.  Lemmon, is splendid and irritating as the out of luck salesman who cannot catch a break, Arkin, again out of luck, plays the nervous salesman who is easily lead by Harris' character, the angry salesman who thinks he deserves more.  Spacey, as the office boss is at his usual high standard as he refuses to cut his staff any slack.  Pacino, well what can be said about this man, his deliverance of lines makes any films he's in, addictive. Pryce, as Pacino's prey is also perfect.  And Baldwin, never has he been given the opportunity to express his talent in such a way.  His motivational speech is enthralling and proves just how good David Mamet is. Arguably one of the greatest scripts I've witnessed and proof that you dont need special FX to create a thoroughly entertaining hour and a half's worth of movie making! A well deserved 10/10

reviews.review_title: With Jack Lemmon's passing, time to see this one, again
reviews.content: To get a sense of what film has lost with Jack Lemmon's passing, as well as what is possible in acting, I suggest seeing this brilliant actor's movie, "Save the Tiger," and "Some Like it Hot" in a series.  The rapidly deteriorating world of Harry Stoner is turned, in a sense, inside out by Lemmon in this film.  Is Lemmon Glengarry Glen Ross's central actor? Perhaps not, but Lemmon's characterization of Shelley Levene is surely central to the film's power, terror, and madness.  Lemmon's Levene is a volcano pushing the other brilliant actors into some of their best performances.It is astonishing to me what Lemmon was able to draw out of Stoner and Levene turning, in his extraordinary talent, miserable, small men into lugubrious everymen which, at once, we justifiably revile and pity.  Harry Stoner, Shelley Levene, and Willy Loman, the "other side" of post-World War II striving.And, of course, every cycle of tragedy needs its comedy ... for me, in the Lemmon oeuvre, its "Some Like it Hot."  But then, "nobody's perfect."

reviews.review_title: Easily one of the most overlooked films of the 90's.
reviews.content: First and foremost, Glengarry Glen Ross is one of the most wonderfully acted pieces of it's time, making it easily one of the most overlooked films of the 90's.  Start from the top and work your way down; there is not a singular average performance in this movie.  Lemmon, Pacino, Harris, Spacey and Arkin are all brilliant and the support of actors like Baldwin and Pryce are icing on the cake.  After seeing this film for the first time, I was left to wonder how only Pacino was Oscar nominated (He was also nominated - and won - that year for "Scent of a Woman").  If nothing else veteran Jack Lemmon deserved a nod himself, perhaps in one of Oscar's biggest acting snubs of that decade.  To sum up this movie's legacy:  Any aspiring young actor need only pop in a copy of Glengarry Glen Ross into the VCR to be immediately transfered into the best of Acting 101.

reviews.review_title: One of my top Five of all Time!
reviews.content: What can I say - there are films that are good, some that are truly memorable, and just a few rare ones that stay with you for ever- this is one of those truly rare ones. I will never tire of watching Mr. Lemmon and Mr. Pacino give such performances- they become their characters in a way that is phenomenal even for the likes of them! The supporting actors are great too but they can only glow in the background compared to the dazzling incandescence that is produced by Jack and Al. Absolutely excellent all round, and David Mamet- wow, what a script!

Very few movies can be seen over and over again even though it has a low budget, like reservoir dogs. Why? Because of the great dialogues. There are a lot of lines in this movie which are most memorable, most of them in a patronizing way (eg: 'Put that coffee down!! Coffee is for closers only.... your name is Levene?? And you call yourself a salesman you S.o.B.??'). This makes the movie more of a comedy than drama.In the opening scene Alec Baldwin makes clear that 'only one thing counts in this life: get them to sign their name on the line which is dotted!'. That is where this movie is about: closing (in a time of recession). Glengary glen ross makes you wonder whether a life as a salesman is a privilege or a disaster. Next to Alec Baldwin there are many famous actors playing an important role: Kevin Spacey, as an ass-kissing manager, Al Pacino as the salesman with the smooth-talk, Alec Baldwin as the harsh-super-salesman, and many more.The language which is used is very bad, therefore I would recommend this movie only to people who aren't offended easily.

If you are an adult who enjoys movies and has the maturity to deal with some stern language, you must see this movie.One of the most astounding ensemble casts ever assembled, in a script dripping with brilliance.  The movie executes.The bleak, mean city streets, awash in acid rain and disillusioned deception, the gritty bitter scrabbling for a dime and some dignity.... And some dressings-down that will sear into your memory with a deep sense of gratitude that it wasn't you on the receiving end.Is there any movie moment more poignant than the end of the scene between Lemmon and Altman?  I have lived on both sides of this nightmare. Humanity is captured here, with more facets polished than you will find almost anywhere else.

reviews.review_title: Superb acting in a movie that feels very "stagey"
reviews.content: No doubt about it, this movie has some of the best acting of late.  The film suffers, however, because it feels very "stagey"--it seems like a play on film.  It could have been opened up so much, with great texture and layering, while keeping everything wonderful about the play.  It's not even 90 minutes and set mostly on the same soundstage--so much more could have been done.  The ending, also, while strong in the play, really feels weak here--there's just no real sense of cloture.  Overall, the director clearly doesn't know how to use the camera, editing, or a soundtrack to enhance a film and engage the audience.I'm also perplexed why Pacino was nominated for an Oscar and not Jack Lemmon, when it should have been the other way around.Don't miss this film if you want to see some superb acting--Lemmon, Pacino, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey, and Alan Arken are terrific.  Spacey's role is underused by the director, which is unfortunate.

I rented this the other day after not seeing it in a few years.  It still holds up very well.  Yes, 'The Paper' and 'Jerry Maguire' are good movies also but I dont think there's much comparison with the exception of all the movies being about relationships at work (then so is Clerks, Men At Work, etc).  With the recent passing of Jack Lemmon, I feel this is one of his underrated works (the profanities surely doomed any widespread appreciation).  He shows all the desperation of a salesman on the decline better than anyone I've ever seen.  Pacino has a sense of dynamics that also ranks with his best work (the scene where he is selling the Lingk guy at the Chinese restaurant is one of his finest performances).  Alec Baldwin has an explosive cameo that may only be bested by Robert Duvall's Col. Kilgore in Apocalypse Now (yes, he has THAT much of an impact).  You also get to see Kevin Spacey in an early work that has all of his coldness in tact. Someone talked about this being a "TV-movie" and I have to wonder when we will hear the word "f**k" some 100+ times along with "c***sucker" on network TV. This film is intense with a good plot to work with.  Every salesmen I've ever talked to says this film is the real deal.  Highly recommended.

This movie is for the intellect, the intelligent movie watchers, driven by character and raw talent. No special effects, CGI or blow-ups. This is as natural as it ever gets.The dialogue and script is brilliant. The casts is seasoned and the flow is natural. I have seen this movie twice a day in the last week. I truly enjoyed movies with strong dialogue that leaves an opening for the viewers to inject their own views.One of the best movies I have seen in a long time and this kind of movie is very difficult to come by.Looking for the blue ray.

Alright here is my breakdown. I watch the entire film hypnotized by the great acting by Lemmon, Pacino and Harris. My mouth dropped when I saw the subway and then the credits. I am thinking-- what a drop off ending. Why do movies do this? I have been to plays and a resolution has been resolved. A movie if is it to be a good one must have a resolution immediately following the climax. GGGR does not, why? It would have been so fulfilling after sitting and enjoying a 100 minutes of heated emotional tension and end it without knowing what happens. It is another sign of "Hey how do you end this?" Well, you have Jack's character go to jail or cut a deal and you have the rest of the crew make some type of decision based on the robbery. It is not a good one but it is an ending. Pleasantville also did not know how to end and I sure hope that these writers or directors figure this out or they will lose out those "summer dollars."

Superb movie. A cast of the finest in the biz doing what they do best. An in-your-face look into the life of a salesman. Terrific dialogue and flawless acting really make you feel as if you're in that shitty little office about to get sniped at for not closing. Al Pacino is a standout and Alec Baldwin's cameo crystallizes the hard-edge theme of the movie. Not for the faint of heart, and not for the timid. This movie is a must see for anyone who has ever thought they had a hard day at the office. Lessons to be learned are prevalent throughout. It's hard to say if another cast this brilliant will ever be assembled again, though I highly doubt it. You don't wanna see this movie? "Fuck you! hit the bricks pal"

Everyone should watch this film. It's a once in a generation masterpiece. There are some magicians who can make people sitting around a table talking and eating twenty times more interesting than a car chase, space battle, or jumping between skyscrapers.Tarantino, being one. David Mamet is another. Incredible performances, particularly from Ed Harris and Jack Lemmon. All so well done. The heart of a salesman, the rigor of the job, it's all so well done.The cinematography is excellent. A must watch.

Yes folks, I actually worked in an office not unlike GGR, in Phoenix, Az. True, we didn't use the language thrown around in David Mamet's excellent play, and film, the rest was there. And after working in that kind of enviornment I can saftely say that GGR was true to it's premise. A lot of comments on these boards seem to come from people not familiar with this kind of environment or situation but believe me it does exist. The desperation and sweaty knowledge that you have to meet "that" daily, weekly, monthy quota can leave one panicky and exhausted. I only worked under that kind pressure for a little while, until my "real" job opened, but it was an experience, perhaps that's why I appreciate the tremendous acting done by these "pros." A lady friend was quite adamant bout there not being women in this play and after I explained to her that what was happening on the screen was quite real and that women would "never" put up with the abuse offered she relented and saw the light, as it were. Al Pacino is my very favorite actor outpacing even the great Marlon Brando, in my book, also, Ed Harris and the rest were every bit up to par with Pacino, even the obnoxious Jack Lemon. Mr Lemon was great in his comedies but when he turned to "acting" he gave me a pain. All in all Glengary Glen Ross is a roller coaster of fine acting based on real situations. Four Stars.

Before it was a movie, Glengarry Glen Ross was a play.  Like the play, the movie uses only seven or eight different sets, and the dialogue from the movie is identical, as far as I can tell, to the dialogue from the play. So it's basically a play that's been filmed.  Glengarry Glen Ross is a stunning play, and I think it adapts in a fairly straightforward manner to be a stunning movie, but my own bias, as a writer, is toward those films that have strong dialogue and show a powerful use of language.  Those of the more conventional Hollywood "show-me-don't-tell-me" persuasion may find it somewhat tedious.  But those who have an ear for the spoken word would be hard-pressed to find a better-written movie with better actors turning in better performances.  (Plus, if you're a Simpsons fan, you need to watch Glengarry Glen Ross so you can understand the origin of Gil, the pathetic salesman... :)

Glengarry Glen Ross certainly works better as a theater play but it is rescued by an excellent cast that delivers memorable performances and makes this one a must-see. It's hard to say who is the best among these great character actors, but Jack Lemmon is certainly the scene-stealer with his portrayal of a desperate but still persistent salesman on the brink of losing his job after a poor sales record. In one of his final roles, dear Jack is still the everyman we knew and loved but this time he brings a never-before-seen edge to his character. Kevin Spacey is superb for once more in a relatively small but powerful turn, as is Jonathan Pryce, while Ed Harris delivers one more energetic performance. Al Pacino is unbelievably loud - that's something he does pretty often in his films, but the catch is that he was nominated for an Oscar for this particular portrayal of the top-of-his-class salesman, untouched by the desperation and decay that surrounds him. The honorable mention goes to Alec Baldwin - much louder than Al Pacino, but seriously overrated. David Mamet's script is alarmingly accurate and realistic. A must-see.

reviews.review_title: TV Movie Hokum At It's Blandest
reviews.content: I read the reviews of this movie on this site and thought I MUST see it - but how dissapointed I was. Compared to the far superior 'The Paper' this film pales into insignificance and made-for-tv hokum. I would ask that anybody reading this review does NOT go and buy or rent the movie and get something like 'The Paper' or 'Jerry Macguire' for a real insight into working life!!

reviews.review_title: we should really get an espresso machine
reviews.content: This film is an important study of working men, and the grind of a tough business. Al pacino delivers a subtle charming performance as ricky roma. Jack lemmon in his last great film takes u with him into his depression ed harris, alan arkin, alec baldwin and inparticular kevin spacey all excel in there roles considering spacey hadnt done much previous his performance is great as the reluctant to help boss. All in all a top notch film and remember coffees for closers.

reviews.review_title: What a waste of a good cast....
reviews.content: After hearing rave reviews of this movie for the last couple of years, I finally rented it.  After almost two hours of absolutely nothing, other than a good line or two from Al Pacino, it was over.  No plot, no story, no climax, no ending.  I just didn't get it.  This film starts very strong with a great five minute performance from Alec Baldwin.  He makes you believe you have just sat down to witness true perfection.  Needless to say, that is all we see of Mr. Baldwin and everything that follows is a vast pool of nothingness.  Leaving me confused as to why some of my favorite actors would struggle to pull off such a poorly written, pointless, waste of time.

reviews.review_title: The Best Cast in any Movie!
reviews.content: Glengary GlenRoss is a truly great film. It show's the life of the real-estate salesmen. It is the only movie I have ever seen that has such a great cast. Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey, Alic Bawldwin, and Ed Harris! All of them gave awesome performances.One of my favorite things about this movie is the great dialog that the writer put into it. Pacino had some of the best lines in the whole movie! Jack Lemmon was really good in the movie too. Although Alic Bawldwin was in the movie for only about 15 minuets, he was still great. This movie was originally based on David Mamets play, and they did a great job of turing it into a movie.

reviews.review_title: perfection can be achieved on a small scale .
reviews.content: Mini reveiw for this movie : Foul-mouthed real estate salezmen get angry . A must see 10 !I usually rezerve such a hi skore for bigger moviez, such az T2 or Star Wars. But this movie iz just so intense that it makes up for all the special effects just thru the powerful acting uv everywun in it . Its like the story wuz made specifically to test the actorz ability . If they didnt measure up , it would fail . It would be funny to do a remake with the memberz uv Bay Watch !

reviews.review_title: A study of the personalities behind the suits.
reviews.content: That Glengarry Glen Ross is a profound (at times, profane) piece of work, is beyond doubt. This movie, based on David Mamet's celebrated play, follows the characters, through their daily grind of selling real estate, and pays witness to the fair and foul techniques, which, evolved through to the Eighties, previously the most fruitful techniques.The rhythm and atmosphere of the film, retains much of that of the play and our characters, for all their striking differences, are conjoined by the shared compulsion to "make the deal".This drive becomes incredibly exaggerated over the 18-or-so hours around which the plot revolves, as they have all been given a do-or-die ultimatum by their employer, with the top sellers being awarded the questionable prize of keeping their jobs.The harshness of this scenario and the way it draws the weaknesses and personality traits out of the respective combatants, demonstrates the futility and the tragedy of the working man betrayed. Its resonance is distinct and poignant to any individual, who has ever had their employment threatened.In true Darwinian style, the strong ultimately survive and the old and weak fall by the wayside, but not before we are offered a staggering insight into the selfish and uncaring cesspool that is the selling game.Quality of acting is undoubtedly the strongest element of the movie, with Lemmon, Pacino, Spacey, Harris and Arkin all at, or near, their best. The intensity they generate is remarkable.
"This movie is..." "Is?" "I mean, it has..." "It has?" "Great, great..." "Dialogue!" "Yes! Yes, great dialogue!"
This is one of my all-time favorite movies. Such a great cast with a top notch plot and acting at its finest. Highly recommended viewing.

reviews.review_title: This film is very dependent on your frame of mind.
reviews.content: It should be a given that the performances in this film would be outstanding.  If I look at this film simply as a character study, it was magnificent.  Unfortunately, I don't think that a simple character study makes a film successful.  If film was judged simply on its ability to create a interesting character study, we would see these actors in every movie, and rightfully so.  I felt that the rest of the film was very secondary.  The dialogue was repetitive and masturbatory.  It seemed that it was simply meant to glorify these six wonderful actors. I thought the concept was mildly interesting, a study of men in a desperate situation, but it could have been developed in the length of an NBC sitcom.  The rest of the dialogue was simply meant to make the actors look good. In that respect, it was very successful. If you enjoy this film, check out "The Big Kahuna".  It is a very similar study with fewer characters and more humor.  What a bonus, it has Kevin Spacey too!

reviews.review_title: F*** every 44 seconds is TOO MUCH!
reviews.content: Good movie BUT I always hate it when the director or writer insists on using f*** so much. A few times is OK but every 44 seconds?!?! It doesn't add to the entertainment value, IMO.

Spoilers herein.I've seen this play acted out once before, and I own a copy of it at my house, but I still enjoy the movie more than I ever could the play.  You see, the two are essentially the same, only the film has one extra character (Alec Baldwin's 'Blake')and a few extra scenes; however, I believe that the film is superior to the play (which the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 1984) in several regards.The scene with Baldwin (in his best performance) truly adds a great deal of weight and importance to the drama these men are facing, where their jobs are all on the line.  Plus, the music really adds to the lightning fast pace already created by the dialogue.  The direction is tight; the acting is incredible; the script is first-rate.There are, on the other hand, people who would not enjoy this movie.  It's extremely masculine and extremely profane (females are generally regarded as "broads" or other such derogatory terms, and over 130 f-words are spoken). If this sounds like it wouldn't be your cup of tea, look elsewhere.As I've said before, though, this movie's real power is in the dialogue and in the acting.  Pacino is at his brash best, Lemmon plays a horrible man yet does so with a twinge of sympathy, Harris gives one of his best performances to date, as does Baldwin, and Kevin Spacey shows us shades of the future with one of his first appearances in film.  My favorite character, though, is definitely the one portrayed by Alan Arkin.  I've never cared much for his work before, but this is absolutely brilliant.So stop reading this.  Go rent the movie.

I have a tattoo of the business man on the high wire.. so I obviously love this film. People can hate this film.. but to me.. it's acting 101. Jack Lemmon himself had said it was the greatest cast he had worked with in his career.. which for those of you who don't know.. was legendary. The screenplay for the film is as good.. if not better.. than the script for the pulitzer prize winning play. Alec Baldwin's performance is some of the finest cinema of the 20th century.. and c'mon.. you and I both know Alec Baldwin is an average actor.. at best. So I think it's speaks volumes for Foley and Mamet's meticulous attention to direction and screen writing respectively. There will always be people who don't like this film.. but it happens. Always Be Closing.

reviews.review_title: Glengarry Glen Ross takes a trip down Devils Garden Road
reviews.content: I watched this movie while on a sales road trip. From the opening of the movie, where the salespeople complain bitterly about the poor quality of the leads, to the sales manager from "downtown" tearing apart the losers on the team, this movie was my life for five long years.Glengarry Glen Ross was a worthless collection of real estate, but no matter what you sell, you come across the same types of salespeople.. the burned out old-timers like Jack Lemmon, the can-do-no-wrong hotshots like Al Pacino, the terminal complainers like Alan Arkin, and the constant cheaters like Ed Harris.Shortly after I attended an awards weekend for the top 5% of salespeople in my region (I was a hotshot and had the brass balls to go with it), I saw Glengarry Glen Ross at a matinée between sales meetings. The movie, combined with recently closing a prospect who lived on a street named "Devils Garden Road" (I am not making this up!), convinced me I was through with the amoral, stretching the truth life of the salesman.You can see the loss of the soul in the characters in this movie. The business of sales will eventually destroy your soul, just as it did to Willy Loman or Shelly "The Machine" Levine. You have to choose between success and your soul if you go into sales.Having said all that, Alec Baldwin's 10 minute masterpiece of a sales motivation speech is the epitome of what sales is all about. "Put the coffee down..coffee is for closers..." A MASTERPIECE performance. Coffee IS only for closers, and 3rd place-you're fired is the American Way. Produce or get out. I'd rather be a salesman with no soul than some government bureaucrat any day.

it's been a while since i've seen such a great cast work together on a movie,every single one of them is sensational. of course i doubt that a lot of people have seen this movie, but it is worth while (pacino-lemmon-baldwin-harris-arkin)and you add (spacey-price).you cannot get more intense than this. althought for some viewers maybe the "F" word is said once too many i still think that this one ranks among the best ones.

While the subject is poignant and worthwhile this film is simply a shining example of a triumph in the field of allowing your talent to shine in all facets. If it's SEVERAL acting performances your after to make a movie then it gets no better than this. If you pay attention then you can do nothing but vote 10 of 10 across the board. also see: 12 Angry Men (1997) - a little more on the script side but same difference.

The movie is worth seeing for the acting alone. Jack Lemmon was especially good, although I will have to admit it is the best acting I have ever seen by any actor named Baldwin. He was fantastic. It made me think about my own life, I could see myself in almost every character. Anyone who has ever sold anything needs to experience this film.

reviews.review_title: Top 10 best movies ever hands down
reviews.content: Stellar dream-team performance. The cast sets a super high bar, and doesn't fail to deliver way above it. Every single actor in the movie is on some "performance of a lifetime" level, but personally I've found Jack Lemmon's performance to be the most moving I've witnessed in my whole lifetime. The movie is, in my humble opinion, the blueprint of how a play should be adapted for cinema/television. The direction is flawless, elegantly transparent, with the camera silently following the intense action on set.Some people here in the reviews have complaints about the strong language used in the dialogues. Well, that's a non-exagerated transposition of reality in sales department, whether we like it or not.

Once again, David Mamet has proved to me that he is one of the masters at dialogue. Nearly every scene in this film is a token of how dialogue should be written and spoken. The film is based on the same-name play written by Mamet and, not surprisingly, this film is adapted by him. It is even filmed in an atmosphere that reeks of the stage, but that is not important. What is important is how easily it can be transferred from the stage to the screen. The story mostly takes place in a real-estate office located somewhere downtown, close to where the trains pass by. But the plot is not nearly as important as the aforementioned scenes between the actors. You see, the movie basically has no plot and the whole film takes place within 24 hours. The characters are real-estate salesmen/conmen/sad-sacks. Every moment in their lives seems to revolve around making that all important sale.
