They constantly lie and cheat to get the sale so that they won't be dumped on the street by their bosses, who are tiring of their employees slow accumulation of sales. And since nearly every one of the characters is currently in a slump, they become desperate. It doesn't help matters that the tips they receive for prospective buyers are either out of date, or filled with the addresses of crazy folks who just like talking to salesmen, but have no intention of buying from them. This desperation leads to more than one of the employees planning and conceiving a burglary of the office, as well as stealing the better tips and selling them to a man who is willing to pay ten large. Of course, each and every one of the salesmen are suspect and the police take the time to interview each and every one of them. The guilty parties won't be named here, as it doesn't matter. The plot is nothing more than a sounding board for great dialogue by one of the greatest casts in the history of cinema.

reviews.review_title: How a play should be adapted to the silver screen
reviews.content: This is how a play could (should) be adapted to film: Excellent: Very few scenes, intense and brilliant acting, a meaningful dialog - yes, this could be dramatized for radio (come on BBC7) and be just as exciting as the film version.The film version is so intensively exciting mainly because it's a damn good story, and because of the brilliant cast.The style of this film - the few scenes, tender cutting, and thus the theater-feeling - makes me think of another masterpieces as Cat On A Hot Tin Roof. This film also has the intensity of even the best of todays car-chase-all-the-time movies.To the viewers: See it! And to BBC: Dramatize it for radio!

A pretty good movie, with superb performances by Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon. Ed Harris over-does it a bit, though.  The only reproach I can put my finger on is that the director did not make a sufficient effort in transforming the play into a proper movie.  You get the impression throughout the movie that you are watching a play.

reviews.review_title: Glengarry sets the standard for dialogue
reviews.content: Glengarry Glen Ross is another example of David Mamet's brilliant writing. Although it is always difficult to translate work from the stage to the screen because of the limitations to creativity of a live environment, Glengarry Glen Ross does an excellent job of retaining the dialogue's intensity and the performances are terrific.  Alec Baldwin's turn is especially memorable and understated for him.  Pacino's overplayed bravado fits the part so well that Kevin Spacey went into a deep depression after the daily abuse dealt to him on the set by Pacino's Roma and Lemmon's Levine.  Full of quoteable dialogue, it is a must for any movie buff.  "So what are you going to do about it.  What are you going to do about it . . . a**hole."

Going into my first viewing of this acclaimed film, I thought it had a number of things going for it. First the cast, and what a bloody good cast!! Al Pacino, Ed Harris, Lemmon, Spacey and a number of other familiar players. The director James Foley is also a talent, although he is better known now for such thrillers as 96's "Fear". And finally, Mamet's play, which I have not seen, is said to be pretty dam good.The first major obstacle that faces the audience is the type of film it ends up being. It is not really aimed at the teen or younger age group, as its a very "talky" film. There is no laughs or violence, just some great dialogue and tight direction.And as for the cast, this is where the movie excels. Pacino is overpowering as Ricky, Lemmon is so good as an annoying salesman, and Alec Baldwin in little more than a cameo role easily gives the film's best performance. All in all, a well acted suspenseful drama

reviews.review_title: Mamet adaptation provides one of the best films of the '90s.
reviews.content:
`Glengarry Glen Ross' is a glimpse into the madness of what happens when men are put into absurdly desperate situations -- through the eyes of dog-eat-dog salesmen. With a stellar cast, David Mamet, in producing his finest screenplay to date, provides us a `Death of a Salesman' for the 90s.
A day in the life of a group of underachieving real estate salesmen proves particularly challenging as they are forced, through a `sales contest,' to either earn more revenue or be fired. In the ensuing hours we witness how each man handles adversity when faced with dire consequences. The tension builds when a robbery is committed at the office  and everyone is a prime suspect. The ensuing investigation and the characters' individual response to the heightened tension create a dynamic inspection of the very ethos of man.The acting is simply superb. Alec Baldwin's role as the crass sales motivator is arguably his finest 12 minutes on film.  Kevin Spacey, in his first meaningful film role, hones his craft as the conniving, bureaucratic office manager. And Al Pacino's over-the-top portrayal of the hot salesman ranks among the finest of his career. The scenes between Ed Harris and Alan Arkin showcase some of the best dialogue ever written for the screen.The real engine of the film is, indeed, the writing. Mamet's use of language, frank description of office politics, greed, desperation and competition provides one final look back at a period of time notorious for these elements. Essential viewing. Foley directs.

reviews.review_title: check it out, play it loud
reviews.content: this film dramatizes the harsh reality that some men burden who have no other skill to build on.  legal hustling.  lying, schmoozing, cheating. the characters in this film will do anything, anything to accomplish their goal to close a deal.  i think this film is depressing in that regard.  these men have all failed at making real lives for themselves, so they do the next best thing:  make quick, easy money.  mamet shows no remorse for the quick buck.  he demonstrates what men will do to get it.  this film is a small chamber drama, and what a drama it is.  james foley seems to just let his actors go buck wild, because their performances seem to showcase each actor's best emotion (pacino-flashy, in-your-face; harris-angry; lemmon-sad, washed-up; arkin-aggravated, spastic; spacey-enigmatic; baldwin-dramatic, with a splash of comedic joy).  it is, quite obviously, a filmed play, given it is set in the office 80% of the time, but it is so vibrant.  it is not an action movie, but you gotta crank it up and get into it.  please, new line, a platinum series dvd.

An incredible script (pulitzer prize winning), incredible cast, and incredible acting. This is the standard all movies should strive to reach. I remember thinking when I first saw this: These are all known actors except the one. Who is that guy playing the office manager? It's an appearance by Kevin Spacey before he became famous. If you haven't seen it, what are you waiting for?

A movie where 3 Academy Award winning men easily compensate for not having a female lead.  Never before has suberb acting ever been showcased by this many great actors.  I don't think there is a particular standout.  Alec Baldwin surprised me with his over-the-top performance.  Jack Lemmon and Kevin Spacey show why they're both two-time Oscar winners.  And if the Academy didn't frown on an actor winning two Oscars in the same year, Pacino would of easily walked away with Best Supporting Actor for this movie.
Required viewing for anyone who worked in mortgage banking during the housing bubble.

reviews.review_title: Superb script, acting, and theatre vibe to boot.
reviews.content: This movie relies on nothing but dialogue and acting and leaves action packed computer generated movies wondering why they blew their wad on data instead of fine actors.  Jack Lemmon is possibly the best actor ever--ever. He has an everyman quality that makes him golden. His character, Shelley "The Machine" Lavine, is a modernday Willy Loman.   Plus Pacino, Arkin, Spacey and Harris.  Someone needs to tell Pacino that they have these electronic devices called microphones and he needs not yell all the time.

reviews.review_title: Why isn't this movie on DVD?!
reviews.content: No film that I have ever seen expresses the path that the working man follows better than this one. Lemmon and Arkin are perfect as the salesman who's luck has turned towards the negative. You can literally see their will to live being sucked out of them with every blown sale and missed opportunity. Ed Harris is great as the angry salesman who is willing to do what it takes to save his own future. Kevin Spacey plays the tight -collared boss to a T, pushing people and not giving them the breaks they need. The two most quoted characters of any movie I know are those played by Pacino and Baldwin. Pacino always excels in parts where his anger and ability to create believable outbursts are showcased, as they are in this part. All that I can say about Baldwin is that this is definitely his best performance and the writing for his character is unbelievable. I can watch his 10 minute scene over and over again. This movie rules in every way possible. 10 out of 10. (I don't give that rating easily)
I put the DVD in the garbage where rubbish belongs.

Not a film for people who only like explosions and car chases, but a film for those with the intelligence to understand the underlying themes of this fantastic piece of work. A top-notch cast, probably the best assembled for any film  ever, give career best performances. Great to watch after a bad day at the office.

reviews.review_title: All great, Spacey not so great
reviews.content: I have read all the above comments, I agree that this is one of the greatest films I've seen in my young life...It is realistic, it keeps you interested the whole time, and the acting... The cast is just fantastic, and this is even more evident by the lack of special effects... Without these great actors, I believe the film would be just average...I will not repeat what the others have said, I only would like to disagree with some of the people above, on the issue of Spacey's performance:I am a big fan of Spacey, you have to see him in films like "Negotiator" or "Usual suspects". However, in this film, my impression is that his role is of secondary importance to the plot, and that might help explain why I was unimpressed by his performance. I'm not saying he didn't play his role well, just that his role didn't allow him to prove once again what a great actor he is... I don't understand why people were so impressed.Anyway, it's a great film, I'll give it9/10

reviews.review_title: This is the worst movie I have ever seen!!
reviews.content: A play or movie should introduce the characters and have the plot evolve followed by some conclusion and aftermath.  You are waiting the whole movie for something to happen and you realize, too late, that nothing is going to happen.  What a waste of actors, time, and money.  I am pretty easy to entertain but this movie is not remotely interesting.  And you wonder what the producers were thinking to film this turkey.  I am 55 years old and I swear this movie is the worst I have ever seen.  Any one that says they like it, doesn't know s**t from shinola.

Every single performance in this film is not merely good, but outstanding. I especially like Alec Baldwin's motivational speaker/axeman role, which delivers the funniest lines in an otherwise sobersided but suspenseful movie.  The action is tight and moves along fluidly.  The direction, lighting, music, etc., etc. is top-notch.  Summary: the best film of the 1990s and the most underappreciated one of the modern era. Check it out if you have at least half a brain, a modicum of concentration, and can bear a movie without an explosion every other frame.  Recommended especially for those who get a buzz off performances that show their characters enduring intriguing but frightening psychological and moral dilemmas.
So many classic one liners, career performances, lessons for life. They don't/can't make 'em like this anymore. Are you man enough to take this film?

Very tragic story

Wayyyy overrated, "brilliant script" lol wtf? Way too much pointless rambling trying to be passed off under the guise of some kind of pseudointellectual life wisdom half the guys stumble over their words and sound like they've smoked enough crack to kill an elephant. No character development, barely any plot like seriously what?
I absolutely loved this film. Superb acting (especially Jack Lemmon and Alec Baldwin). Superb script. I would of jumped at the chance to watch this on the stage with these actors.

This is as close to a flawless 10 out of 10 movie as you can get without being in a very reserved class of movie rarities to ever achieve this highest regard mark by myself.  "Ross" achieved a 9.5 out of 10 in my books because of so many top notch acting performances and some of the greatest lines in movie history.  Never boring and always pleasing, I can easily watch this movie once every two to three yrs.  Just watched again the other night and thoroughly enjoyed just like the 1st time!  Love it!!!
Terrible movie. I don't see what there is to like. Just a bunch of yelling and conversations that don't finish or have a point.

This David Mamet play translates well into a motion picture, largely, because the screenplay was written by Mamet and because of the Dynamic cast.   The film contains one of the most icon film scenes of the last half of the the 20th Century-courtesy of Alec Baldwin.  Jack Lemmon is very sympathetic as the aging salesman desperate to close some leads.  A young Kevin Spacey is memorable as the young office manager trying to manage his ambitions against the tide of crazed salespeople.  Ed Harris and Alan Arkin are very good in this as a scheming loser and his accomplice.   Al Pacino is almost hypnotic as a successful salesman with great complexity.  For Alec Baldwin this one of the most memorable of his career.   The dialogue is sharp.  The Direction is good but it is the performances that make this a great movie.  This one holds up.

Best acting I've ever seen.
Script was incredible.

I've seen this movie 25 times and never get tired of it.
Great adaptation of the play with powerhouse casting. All the actors are just great, and Jack Lemmon shines. Packed with though-provoking dialogs.

5 years ago-Filmed claustrophobically, the film truly feels more like a play than movie and is packed with six fine performances with the late Jack Lemmon outshining them all. However, the film suffers by telling more often than it does showing plot.

After reading the good reviews I thought I'd give it a watch, I'm in to my business films but I really found this boring, I nearly turned it off after half an hour but gave the whole film ago but it ended up being one of the worst movies I have seen in a while.
Genius.  The script & the cast.

Theres good reason to give this movie great reviews but I promise it goes well beyond the ABCs. There is a constant sense of urgency through the entire film, its nonstop. Just like life is, just like work. Survival. You can tell it was a stage play and they did a good job translating to film. Almost a noir vibe, has that fast talking suit wearing style. Worth a watch
It's fine. Nothing great, nothing bad.

The contrast between the claustrophobic interior of the office and the dark and rainy exterior of an unnamed city sets the stage for a taut psychological drama that will keep us glued to our seats right up to the gritty and embittered end. Calling to mind the general mood of 12 Angry Men, the film treats us to a blistering display of the raging, frustrated antics of several desperately harried real estate salesman as they mercilessly joust for position, success and ultimately respect. Lent a bemusing air of sophistication by a cool and dispassionate jazz score, the verbal outpourings of the ensemble cast reach heights that both stun and amuse, achieving the rare and impressive feat of intense melodrama that buoys the spirits instead of dampening them. We may have little affection for the sleazy and corrupt salesmen occupying center stage, but we marvel at the brutality of circumstances that might yield sympathy for even the most craven of con-artists. This sets up an engaging dynamic wherein we invest ourselves in the turbulent fortunes of scoundrels, ever delighting in the ongoing process of events regardless of eventual outcomes. A classic albeit mercilessly profane depiction of the failure of the American Dream in perfect microcosm.

Glengarry Glen Ross is a wonderfully entertaining movie to watch on a rainy day. The Quick wit and humor is engaging never leaving the viewer bored. Its a film you can watch again and again because of the many memorable moments that stick with you forever. Alec Baldwin's cameo is one of a kind while Jack Lemmon takes centerstage with his charming innovative sales pitches. Al Pacino, Kevin Spacey, Ed Harris, and Alan Arkin are all fantastic as desperate men trying to survive in the turbulent and sleazy world of real estate, as is Alex Baldwin in a brief but memorable role as a ‘motivator.'  Jack Lemmon received great praise for his performance, but really just plays the same stammering character that he played for the last twenty years of his career.  The real star of the film is David Mamet, whose phenomenal screenplay defines the characters and their motivations and regularly swings from touching to profanely intense in a matter of seconds. Lemmon in particular is an acting powerhouse, swinging from downtrodden but resilient, to self-satisfied and bravado-pumped, and ultimately to heartbreakingly defeated; Pacino, Harris, Spacey, and Pryce are each exceedingly well matched to the script as well. Raw, intense, beautifully drawn out.  I wanted to get more, it felt like two solid acts, but an entire third was missing.  I thought maybe we could get to the bottom of what this company really is, though we certainly can imagine along the way that they are crooks.  It would've been nice to see the police, after long enough exposure to this office, want to open an investigation on their business practices.

Alan Arkin does a wonderful job as the benign George, who amenably reiterates whatever Dave (Ed Harris) says.  We get a sense he's been at this job a long time, hasn't ever gotten ahead, doesn't have enough wisdom to converse with the younger Dave, but is almost willing to blindly follow him for lack of his own direction.

Jack Lemmon as Shelley and Al Pacino as Ricky Roma are the two standout performances, and we are treated to a great interaction between them after Shelley finally gets off a big sale.  The interaction ups the ante when Roma's client comes in, the nervous pushover James Lingk (Jonathan Pryce), Shelley and Roma playing a faux client/salesman con to sell Roma as a busy important man.  Roma is trying to push Lingk out of the office to keep him from withdrawing his sale - Roma is held onto the lie that Lingk's check hasn't been cashed yet, is secure, and can be returned.  Kevin Spacey's young and ignorant John Williamson comes in and screws the whole thing up, misreading the situation, informing Lingk that his check has been cashed and all is well.  What follows is Roma's verbal beatdown of Williamson, making up the raw intensity aforementioned.  

Everybody hates Williamson after he brings in the negatively charged motivational speaker Blake (Alec Baldwin) to threaten that the lowest earner will be fired.  Roma is the standard to meet, and he's got pull over Williamson.  His berating of Williamson is something everyone wants to see, especially since Williamson had been hard on the vet Shelley, giving him and everyone else poor leads.  

The plot develops when these top leads, which only Roma gets, become the target of everyone in the office, and since nobody will give them up, plans develop to steal them.  It starts with Dave trying to convince George to do it - they will sell them off to another company and make a profit for their efforts.  But even George is leery about this, second guessing it.  All we know is that the next day, the leads have been successfully stolen, and the police are investigating.  We suspect George based on the nervous way he acts, but he's nervous to begin with.  It's likely Dave is involved no matter what, the guy is always lit without a fill.  And then there's the way Shelley is acting, overly celebratory about his latest sale that gets him up on the board.

The scope is limited, but Foley handles it nicely.  I like the way this part of New York looks, has a studio backlot old Hollywood feel to it.  Blue light lands on several of the characters, Shelley in phone booths.  The Chinese restaurant, with it's red lining and open space, provides a hospitable habitat for these workers to relax and stretch.  I love the way the train passes in the rain as Shelley crosses the street, Dunkin' Donuts dull in the background.  We feel this is a deadbeat part of town, a perfect allusion to the lives of the people working in it.

If nothing else, you have to give Glengarry Glen Ross some credit because it does an amazing job of making the slimiest of salesmen into sympathetic characters. You somehow find yourself dying for a poor schmuck to get tricked into accepting a real estate deal that he probably can't afford and doesn't want in the first place, simply because we want to see the salesman get a win. The script gets some of the credit for that aspect, but I think even more of the credit has to go to the amazing cast of actors. Each one of these guys can pull off so much in their performances that you can simultaneously hate their actions and yet like them as people. I think the empathy is formed throughout the film, but it is amplified in the scene where Alec Baldwin outdoes himself with one of the most ridiculous and yet amazing speeches in movie history. This raises the stakes for the rest of the characters and does a great job of giving us a vision of who is the real bad guy. No matter how bad the other characters behave we understand because at least they aren't like Blake. Kevin Spacey was perfect as the manager who could be in over his head with all these salesmen that have more experience than him, and yet he holds his own and can give it back as easily as they dish the punishment out. Al Pacino, Alan Arkiin, Ed Harris, and Jonathan Pryce all crush their performances as well. I could just go on and on about every single person in the cast, but instead I'll just focus in on how totally awesome Jack Lemmon is in Glengarry Glen Ross. I don't have words for the perfection in his performance. In each conversation he shifts to the situation and perfectly shows us the quality of his sales skills, and yet we can always sense the underlying despair that drives him. There's not much else to talk about with this film because it is almost 100% character driven, and the plot is rather basic. I enjoyed the film, and can see why it is critically praised, I'd certainly recommend it to others for a good example of an acting tour-de-force.

What an endlessly witty film this is. With its ensemble cast of performances that range from heartbreaking to downright hilarious at times, I was constantly engaged by David Mamet's script in terms of not only dialogue but also character. Each person in this film has clearly defined edges, which is mostly done through the performances of each actor. Lemmon is a fast talking, slightly desperate sounding man with a family to feed, Pacino is incredibly smooth and appears to have not a care in the world while still maintaining an air of professionalism, the viewer believes he is good at his job despite being told time and again its just a lucky streak. James Foley's direction matches the wit of Mamet's screenplay, as his camera cuts between characters at a speed to rival the dialogue flying out of the actors mouths, which allows him to create immense amounts of tension in the viewer when all that is really happening is two men talking in an office. The way the film is shot is an asset to the movie as well, we are never given any glimpses of the characters home lives or homely settings, it is kept strictly businesslike, adding to the cutthroat atmosphere of the world they are trying so hard to stay in.

The words sell the whole thing, the endless monologues effortlessly setting up mcguffins and knocking them down at a moment's notice, subtle deviations from the ostentatious bravado of the compelling characters leading to major developments down the line. Glengarry Glen Ross has the look and feel of a stage play, perhaps unsurprisingly because that's exactly what it is. Most of the dialogue happens within one particular office space. There's no action sequences to speak of and certainly no special effects employed. Your attention is nonetheless held for the entire duration of the film by the mesmerizing performances of some of Hollywood's finest. To single out one would be unfair, each being perfectly observed characterizations of real estate salesmen struggling to hold onto both their jobs and dignity. 

Pacino as always proves eminently watchable putting in an energized, finely honed performance as smooth talking salesman of the month Ricky Roma. Baldwin is unexpectedly impressive as ruthless boardroom executive Blake, a corporate hatchet man sent in to cull the underachievers among the ranks. Spacey, Harris, Arkin and Lemmon are flawless, their interactions seamless and believable.

The script is superb, witty and sharp, and must rank as among the finest ever committed to celluloid. As you might be able to tell by now I can't speak highly enough of this movie. Demands more than a single viewing, in my opinion, always a good sign. Should be on everyone's bucket list of unmissable movie experiences.

The interaction between the characters and the actors is vital.  The film would not work otherwise.  It is those moments that drives the picture.

Coffee's for closers.  This is about a company of men that work in a real estate office, showcasing just how shady and underhanded the world of a sales can be.  Now this was always one of those films that I had always heard great things about, but never actually found the time to sit down and watch, until now.  To say this is star-studded would be an understatement; you look at the cast list, and you see nothing but heavyweights like Jonathan Pryce, Kevin Spacey, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Alec Baldwin, Jack Lemmon and Al Pacino.  They all manage to elevate an already tight script penned by David Mamet, whose writing really is the star here.  Abbreviated on paper, this is just 100 minutes of salesmen talking about leads, but when brought to life, it really is something special.  You can totally tell that this was a stage play previously, simply based on the parameters of how the story advances, but that is in no way a mark against it; some of the best stories can exist in both worlds, and you can always look at the classic 12 Angry Men if you need further proof.  It is a story that makes you feel disgusted about how sales work, but it is fascinating to get to know the character of Shelley Levene; Jack Lemmon plays him in such a way that you feel bad for him, all the while you're repulsed by his actions.  I would never want to be a salesman (or associate myself with one, for that matter) but Glengarry Glen Ross has a script that speaks for itself, and features dialogue with cadence and rhythm.

One line summary: Excellent acting illuminates this great story about the real estate business. 

--------------------------

    Shelley, Dave, Ricky, and George are real estate salesmen who are under the gun to sell more real estate.  They work at Consolidated Real Estate in Arizona.  Their line manager is John; those above John brought in Blake to put a fire under these four.  So the re-working of their work life consists of a contest.  In two weeks, whoever comes in first in sales get a Cadillac.  Who comes in second gets a set of steak knives.  The other two get fired.

    The common complaint is the availability of leads; that is, connections to a likely real estate sales that is worth a lot of money.  With Consolidated Real Estate, they get leads that are dubious and re-worked.  Shelley appeals directly to John for the premium leads, the 'Glengarry' leads.  He tries to construct a kickback scheme with John to get the Glengarry leads.

    Dave and George do a lot of complaining, then consider robbing the office to get the Glengarry leads directly, then sell then to a competitor.  Ricky schmoozes James at length, and closes a deal.

    The robbery does occur, and there is a great deal of consternation at the office.  The Detective is doing interviews.  Contracts and some of the leads have been stolen.  Ricky's deal with James got registered with the company and the bank, or at least that's what John tells Ricky.  Shelley comes in a little late and is so happy to have sold 8 units in a development.  Dave blows up and leaves after his interview with the Detective.  George gets interviewed next.  Ricky and Shelley swap war stories.

    James tries to get out of his deal with Ricky.  Ricky and Shelley try to fast talk him out of this.  Ricky manages some quality talking time while the Detective interviews Shelley.  John manages to torpedo the deal.  Ricky is not happy with John.  Nobody does anything but abuse John.

    Will the thief be discovered?  Will any of these four salesmen get their act together again?

------Scores------

    Cinematography: 10/10 No problems.  Nicely shot.

    Sound: 10/10 Well-miked actors; no problems understanding the dialog with the sound at a reasonable volume.  Music is not a factor here, and the dialog is everything.

    Acting: 10/10 Great performances: Ed Harris, Al Pacino, Alan Arkin, Jack Lemmon, Kevin Spacey, Alec Baldwin.  The fine story is made better by the excellent acting.

    Screenplay: 10/10 Mamet's story is riveting with these actors executing brilliantly.

This drama, adapted by David Mamet from his 1984 Pulitzer Prize- and Tony-winning play of the same name, and directed by James Foley was recommended to me by three of my RT friends with similar comments - watch it! I missed it in the cinemas in the 90's - I was building a new house and there was a gap of few years regarding movies. 

The film depicts two days in the lives of four real estate salesmen and how they become desperate when the corporate office sends a trainer to "motivate" them by announcing that, in one week, all except the top two salesmen will be fired. The film is notorious for its use of profanity, leading the cast to jokingly refer to the film as "Death of a Fuc*in' Salesman". The title of the film comes from the names of two of the real estate developments being peddled by the salesmen characters: Glengarry Highlands and Glen Ross Farms. The world premiere of Glengarry Glen Ross was held at the Venice Film Festival, where Jack Lemmon, one of the film's stars, was awarded the Volpi Cup for Best Actor. And I have to say his performance was a top act. I liked Al Pacino's work as well - he was nominated for an Academy Award and a Golden Globe for Best Supporting Actor for his work in the film.

But, I have to ask - what else was a top act in this movie except acting? Directing? What was top there? Which scene can you remember as outstanding? What about the screenplay? There was some suspense and drama, but at the end it was mostly "talk" - without the actual "walk"! The film's photography relied on low lighting and shadows with a blues, greens, and reds colour scheme for the first part of the film, while the second half was monochromatic blue-grey colour scheme - and that's it. I have nothing against simplicity, completely opposite, but there must be something outstanding that I could rate a movie 100%! It was a good movie to watch... and I saw it... once is enough. Maybe I've seen too many movies, and even if I enjoyed this one in general, there was no "special" effect on me! The film was not a commercial success, making only $10.7 million in North America, just below its $12.5 million budget.

It was a shame that Alec Baldwin had such a minor role as I think his character had extreme presence and its a mystery as to why he hardly featured. Worth a watch but don't be surprised to have a slight feeling of regret at the end, as to what could have been.

Glengarry Glen Ross directed by James Foley - from the Pulitzer Prize winning play of the same by adapted by David Mamet. Starring AL PACINO, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, Alan Arkin, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey. Film was premiered at Venice Film Festival, where Jack Lemmon received Volpi Cup award for Best Actor. Made with the budget of just $12.5 million - Al Pacino received Best Supporting Actor nominations at two different prestigious Academy Award, and Golden Globe. 

On a rainy-day events occur inside the office of real-estate -occupied by salesmen Jack Lemmon, Alan Arkin, Ed Harris, and upper-heads Kevin Spacey and AL PACINO. Kevin Spacey is the manager who runs the affair and makes sure to implement commands. Kevin also has to deal with worsening scenario after visiting downtown hotshot slick Alec Baldwin warns them (rather in threatening manner) to reach target of property-sale in time or else lose their job. Alec hands packet of leads (names of sure-purchasing-parties) to Kevin and for Pacino (not present in the screen, yet).

It is said, that movie was made just like stage-drama, even actors who were yet to appear in scene, voluntarily showed up during other actors' performances. The movie is famous for bringing on stage versatile actors of their times, all together - and important thing is that the movie contains powerful dialogues, from those who are quite experienced at doing so. Of all, only Al Pacino and Jack Lemmon appear to have honestly dedicated to bring justification to film's crucial subject. To me, Al Pacino's performance at near climax shook me up, during Pacino's confrontation with Kevin, taking marvelous use of dialogue-delivery and pace of timing. 

Oliver Stone's Wall-Street, like films introduced us to greed at top-level, and here we are seeing the ground-realities as suffered by ordinary fellas - neither of who are immunized to plague of deception and greed.

A group of aging real estate salesmen-sales leader Roma (Al Pacino), Levene (Jack Lemmon), Moss (Ed Harris), Aaranow (Alan Arkin)--are having trouble with closing deals, so young office manager Williamson (Kevin Spacey) has arranged for a meeting with self-involved higher-up (Alec Baldwin) to "motivate" the salesmen in solving their problems. The film acts as a canvas for the five stages of grief. Levene bargains for any opportunity that can feed his family, Moss spits on those higher in power for telling him that he cannot make a sale and is ready to fight back, Aaranow harshly doubts his ability to make a deal, and Roma simply continues with his business, worry-free. Glengarry Glen Ross maintains a lot of the strength that made the source material of the play terrific. Filmed and acted as if it is a stage production, Glengarry Glen Ross maintains the strength and drama of being a stage play and follows the appropriate style to do so. It has a few aspects which make it more technically valuable, but as a whole the approach that director James Foley takes to the material makes it seem largely like the play it is written as. It is filmed with simple cinematography techniques, shots which stand in one position and go on for an extensive period of time as they depict the conversations of the actors unfolding naturally as if the viewer is actually there to witness it. It gives the film a sense of realism and genuity which is where a lot of the effectiveness comes into play since there is little required aside from the acting and the natural material of the screenplay to create the drama. There are some slight moments involving a musical score, but they are not common as the drama in the film is consistently organic. Glengarry Glen Ross is strong because of its dramatic roots and due to the fact that its screenplay carries the material over easily to film thanks to the way that James Foley handles it as director. It is a prime example of a great film adaptation of a play, and it maintains a good style but never lets it get in the way of the more organically positive aspects of the material. Admittedly, Glengarry Glen Ross is not a film for everyone because it is a slow burning and simple story which is more relevant to its stage material than to being a film and so people looking for film more than simply a play could find it to be boring. There were many times that I felt this because it is difficult for me to be pleased by stage productions and I have a higher expectation for what films have to offer due to the fact that they offer increased potential and higher technical qualities, and since Glengarry Glen Ross stays so simplistic with its style I found that the affect of it was not as great as it could have been. To put it simply, Glengarry Glen Ross is a lot like a stage play filmed and put on screen as a feature film, and it maintains essentially all the aspects of a play, for better and for worse.
In terms of narrative, the other central flaw in Glengarry Glen Ross is the fact that it has so many characters. The most essential to the plot are Ricky Roma, Shelley "The Machine" Levene and John Williamson.  But as their stories are being told, there are so many others who come into play yet represent nothing but subplots in the story. There are only a select handful of characters in Glengarry Glen Ross, but the material gives them all very predominant roles in the film. They are all interesting to a certain extent and are well acted figures, but their actual relevance to the story proves to be nothing more than a distraction from the major premise at heart. So Glengarry Glen Ross remains a simple and small scaled film but has a surplus of characters to focus on. 
Still, Glengarry Glen Ross succeeds on the basis of the fact that its screenplay is full of well written language and complex plot dynamics, and the fact that Glengarry Glen Ross has a seriously talented cast lined up. The actors in Glengarry Glen Ross  are truly its most major benefit.
Al Pacino pulls off another essential performance in Glengarry Glen Ross. The thing about him this time is that subtlety is key to his character in the way that he maintains a lot of inner wisdom which he projects without having to shout it. He delivers his lines with a lean strength which all comes from within as it is clear that his performance has a lot of depth to it. He plays games with all of the characters and interacts with the others in such a strong way which has viewers constantly intruiged as to who he is and what he is hiding. Al Pacino's supporting performance in Glengarry Glen Ross shows a lot of his understated talents and it is a role which is like none he has ever played before. Al Pacino is the screen stealer in Glengarry Glen Ross because he speaks his words in a way which makes his character so interesting and interacts with the other cast members so powerfully, including one defining scene where he comes to blows with Kevin Spacey towards the end of the film. Glengarry Glen Ross gives Al Pacino a chance to act mostly through the simple technique of his line delivery, and it is no surprise that he comes off well.
Jack Lemmon is terrific in Glengarry Glen Ross because he is such a likeable figure. He is swift in his abilities at line delivery and technique for character acting, and he defies the manipulative archetype of the salesman figure by playing one who struggles so much but remains constantly determined to succeed and having the audience believe that he is avoiding use of tricky tactics to make it happen. He uses some shady techniques, but in comparison to the many others he is in competition in, Jack Lemmon is able to maintain a naturally likable persona due to how he plays with the character. He has audiences sympathizing for him a lot of the time, even when he plays games with the audience and only tells half-truths. And in that sense, he is able to cleverly trick audiences into liking the facade he puts on and the actual person that he is playing. Jack Lemmon conveys the struggles of being in business very well and constantly delivers his lines with a want to draw the audience in, and it works because he captivates the interest of viewers and gives a performance which has a lot of steady power to it.
Kevin Spacey gives an excellent performance as well. From early on in his career from before he earned such worldwide recognition, Kevin Spacey gives a firm and cold-hearted supporting performance in Glengarry Glen Ross which further conveys the harsh reality of business. He is swift and merciless into ensuring that things move along according to his vision, and so his character development is essential to the progression of the narrative.
Alec Baldwin doesn't get as much screen time as one might hope, but during his brief appearance he makes a memorable and effective impact. Ed Harris and Alan Arkin also deliver strong supporting performances.

So although Glengarry Glen Ross is a bit too much of a play to have the impact of a film, the strength of its screenplay and efforts of its incredible cast make it a difficult feature not to admire.

Glengarry Glen Ross is an absolute powerhouse, filled to the brim with fantastic performances, witty dialogue, and an intensity rarely seen in lesser films. From the personality-reflective directing, to the endlessly quotable lines, to the magnetic screen presence of every actor, this film is an ensemble gold standard. 
   
When the higher-ups send Blake (played to sheer, aggressive perfection by Alec Baldwin) down to their office for a motivational speech/verbal beat-down, the property salesmen at Mitch & Murray find themselves desperately looking to climb up their sales board, or lose their jobs. If they manage to sell they're current contracts, they'll be rewarded with the prestigious Glengarry leads. Each man takes to the news in a different way: Sheldon "The Machine" Levene (the ever-slick Jack Lemmon), an old hand, who hasn't had a big break in months, becomes quietly desperate, pulling every trick he has out, in an attempt to plea with his leads. Dave Moss (the ever-underrated Ed Harris), a brash, impulsive type, who leaves with the complacent, unassuming George Aaronow (Alan Arkin, the noticeable black sheep of the cast). While driving, Moss conspires to rob the office of the Glengarry leads, putting Aaronow in a tough position. Finally, there is Ricky Roma (the legend that is Al Pacino), a hot-shot that isn't present for the revelation, as he is too busy wooing a client with his put-on philosophies, and slick charm. On top of that fantastic foursome, there is there young manager, John Williamson (Kevin Spacey, before either of his Oscar wins), the smarmy superior, who has the Glengarry leads. As the night, and following morning progress, we are treated to the different character arcs, relations, and revelations. Various characters reveal more about themselves, and the situation, through the brilliant, biting screenplay.

Positives: So many. The film is dominated by five fantastic lead actors, each getting enough development, and moments to remain in the viewers minds, long after seeing the film. Al Pacino's portrayal of Ricky, as a slick, smooth salesman who can wrap any client around his finger, masks a desperation, that comes out when he finds himself in a corner. This multifaceted portrayal owes it's debt to the fantastic screenplay, and Pacino's absorption into the role. Then there is Moss. Ed Harris was one of the lesser well-known guys in the film, but he absolutely dominates every time he speaks. His brash, loudmouth persona serve to highlight the times where he can't walk the walk, or is unable to follow up a spur-of-the-moment comment, and ends up getting destroyed by the likes of Blake.  To contrast the big-mouthed Moss, we have the reserved, nervous Aaronow, who is unable to stand on his own two feet, and is taken in by Moss' smooth-talking. Arkin's portrayal of Aaronow is probably the least note-worthy performance in the film, but it is still an absolute masterclass, putting many actors today to shame. Moving onto the two supporting characters, we have Williamson, played by the at-the-time upcoming talent Kevin Spacey. Williamson is snide, bitter, and resentful of his employees, as they think themselves more experienced than him, after he left them behind for his current position. This bitterness comes out when he gets the Glengarry leads, and is able to milk the desperation of Sheldon, and the viewer can just feel the venom in their exchanges. Then there's Blake. Blake is an icon to many, both as a movie character, and as a business model. The rapidfire monologues, and searing verbal beatdown of the salesmen is as iconic as anything in cinema. Alec Baldwin is absolute perfection as Blake, playing him as a lecherous, unlikable character that has enough valid points (and intense charisma), to endear himself to the viewer. Finally, there is Jack Lemmon, as Sheldon "The Machine" Levene. I didn't expect it, but Lemmon just stole the show. His delivery, characterisation, from the voice, to the expressions, to the posture, everything was pitch-perfect. His desperation to save his job is nothing less than compelling, had me glued to every conversation he had, and certainly had me sympathising a lot more for him than any other character. With actors of this calibre, and a screenplay so brilliant to work off, anyone can see why it is so deserving of adoration.

Negatives: I actually find myself struggling to think of flaws. Having been based on a play, the film's narrative is a bit different from what you'd expect, and  there is a much more noticeable lack of scenes and locations, with conversations serving for what a separate scene would be used for in more typical fashion. This lack of action can probably be seen as a flaw, as there are probably many who wouldn't take time to admire the brilliant unfolding of the tale. On top of that, if I were to bring up one, tiny (tiny) flaw that I have (and I'm being totally subjective here), it's that we didn't see quite enough of each character in the 100 minute running time. Pacino's Ricky Roma only becomes a major character in the second half, (where he absolutely eats every bit of dialogue he has). If he had more of a presence in the first half, this film would have an even higher standing in my mind than it does  now. Also, Spacey's character, John Williamson, is not quite given enough development, in my eyes. He has a very obvious dislike for those in his office, but I never feel we are quite given enough of a reason for it (save for Roma and Levene throwing insults his way, which could have easily come about, even without a previous bitterness. I feel, if there had been a bit of exposition regarding his relationship with the rest of the cast, it might have made him a stronger character. George and Moss are somewhat the same, as they have smaller roles than Levene, but I still feel that they served there purpose in the film very well, and  have no need to be extended. Of course, this is just me being greedy. This film is still an absolute masterpiece, with superb direction, acting, and writing. If it were up to me, I would have the film go on that little bit longer, just so I could see the electricity of these characters, and these actors, that little bit more.

In closing, you don't need to have a keen knowledge of real-estate to get into Glengarry Glen Ross (I know I don't). If you are in any way a fan of good writing, good directing, and above all, phenomenal acting, then you owe it to yourself to see this movie. I f you even consider yourself a fan of cinema, then you won't be making the wrong choice in seeing Glengarry Glen Ross. It serves as a reminder that the world is cruel place, that people will do desperate things when sufficiently motivated, and that life can be as cut throat as any job or business. Again, if you consider yourself a fan of cinema, or you simply like seeing actors give a masterclass in their profession, Glengarry Glen Ross will not disappoint.

Final Grade: A

Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin head up this adaptation of an award-studded stage production. Naturally, given a cast so drenched with talent, the audience is going to want to see them flaunt their acting chops, and thankfully, that's the key to this entire production. Without a tight band of intense, versatile, believable characters at its core there's no chance a plot that revolves around sales calls and a bland office robbery would be anything more than a snoozer. But in this cast's hands, with this combination of sharp, passionate dialog and sleazy, self-serving lack of morality, it's totally entrancing. Like many play-to-film interpretations, there is a certain amount of stagnation in terms of the film's scenery. The vast majority of the action takes place in a sales office, with phone calls, police interviews and (de)motivational speakers providing the flavor. Those tame surroundings work in a variety of unusual ways, though: as a means to ground the story in reality, an exercise in diverting our attention solely to the acting, and a device to give the rare peeks outside the office's not-so-friendly confines an added dash of color. A master class in cadence and characterization, it's a deep, emphatic and intoxicating look at the gamut of techniques a desperate salesman can (and will) employ.

Adapted from a play by David Mamet, the film is so richly enthralled in its dialogue and the characters are perfectly cast. Alec Baldwin's speech has become on of the most famous dialogue pieces in cinematic history. Jack Lemmon is perfect as the loser salesman trying to survive. Al Pacino is at his best, as the smart-mouthed and incredibly eccentric main character who isn't even aware of the conflicts around him. Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, and Kevin Spacey are all fantastic. This ensemble cast has so much chemistry, that the fast and hilariously entertaining dialogue becomes so natural. They feel like real people, or real salesman trying to buy their way to safety from a failing company. The sequence where Ed Harris and Alan Arkin are talking about the importance of having good "leads," is one of the greatest scenes in movie history. The amount of takes it must have taken. If you watch this scene, you'll have a new found respect for those two actors. The film is really just about an inconvenience, and it doesn't unfold into a thriller or into dramatic cinema. It just feels the way something would happen in real life. And the conclusion or ending to this movie is just perfect. Every actor brings their all and the screenplay is brilliantly written by Mamet, who captures you with every word spoken on the screen. "Glengarry Glen Ross" is an unforgettable classic that's so good, it makes you want to write your own screenplay like Mamet.

You think the dynamic at your company is brutal? Try swimming with the sharks of Glengarry Glen Ross, a pitch-black, deeply profane case study in how quickly an office will disintegrate when a sales team is told that it's about to enter a competition, and everyone who winds up lower than second place is going to lose his job. The result, as you might expect, is a bile-drenched free-for-all, brilliantly scripted by David Mamet (adapting his own Tony- and Pulitzer-winning play) and brought to painful life by an ace cast that included Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, Kevin Spacey, Alan Arkin, and Al Pacino. Mamet could easily have coasted on this project, merely replicating the play's acidic dialogue. Instead, he added a pivotal new scene for a character not in the original, Blake, that raised the story's stakes even further, to create the best anti-sales pitch of the 90s

A smart, intelligent, and highly intellectual comedy, 'Glengarry Glen Ross' is filled with excellent performances, a sharp script, and a memorable score. A brilliant ensemble cast including Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, Ed Harris, and Kevin Spacey give incredible performances in their character-driven roles. David Mamet, who also wrote the play, has produced a fantastic script with fabulous one-liners and witty sarcasm. James Newton Howard's sleazy score matches the tone of this film. Everything presented here is the work of perfectionists doing what they do best. That's the reason 'Glengarry Glen Ross' works so well as a factual and poignant drama.

"Glengarry Glen Ross" is a work of considerable feat; a riveting drama and in-depth character study driven entirely by dialogue. There are no fancy tricks or crafty maneuvers to get around the matter-at-hand. The writer, David Mamet, does not avoid confrontation: he fills every single second with hard-edged dialogue, and the actors that speak these words are so natural and realistic in their delivery that you get the sense that you're looking at what really happens "behind the scenes."
Some of the finest acting you'll see in a movie anchors this thrilling adaptation of David Mamet's award-winning play.

Every time I watch this film I get goosebumps. All-star actors across the board giving some of the best work of their careers in 'Glengarry Glen Ross'. The screenplay by David Mamet based of his play is compelling from the moment the film starts to its jaw dropping finale. The dark atmosphere of that street drenched in rain depicts the characters drenched in their own egos, rage, and self-pity as they desperately hope to sell to their deadbeat customers. It's hard to choose who gives the best performance in this film, because all deserve huge amounts of praise; from Al Pacino's Ricky Roma, the leader on the board that uses his way of words to gain customers trust before getting their signature on the contract, to Jack Lemmon's Shelly "Machine" Levine, the oldest salesman in the firm who everyone else thinks has lost his thunder except himself. I like some of these men for obvious reasons, and hate others for obvious reasons, yet they all have one thing in common: the hate they share for their customers. And in suite, I hate the customers as well. And under the direction of Dave Foley, the camera glides with fluid precision during scenes, making me feel more at ease and comfortable with these men as they cheat, lie, and steal their ways into the corporate heart of real estate. 'Glengarry Glen Ross' is a genius display of greed and attitude, as well as one of my favorite films ever made.

"Always Be Closing." -a quote encouraging a group of real-estate salesmen to go out and do their best, no matter what they are given. "Glengarry Glen Ross" is an explosive drama, centered around the day in the life of four salesman who are faced with bad odds: close or be fired. Each salesman has his own unique personality, but the common thing all 4 have is their way of going about lying to the customer. It's a rather dishonest way to look at this particular field of work, but after a harsh lecture from the company's head (Mitch and Murray) the 4 salesman are given no choice but to use the "ancient" leads they are given, or do the unthinkable: rob the office of the new leads, the "Glengarry" leads where the potentilal clients are destined to make a close and the salesman is sure to strike it rich. Everyone knows the score, the heat is on, who's got what it takes?

"Glengarry Glen Ross" takes one of the most interesting approaches to life in the work force that I've seen so far, it's reminiscent of "12 Angry Men" in the sense that everyone is, well, angry. But the dialogue here is not only far and pedantic  it's exceedingly crude and has a brutal demeanor. Each character doesn't hesitate to share his thoughts and in a movie like this it is not uncommon to have one man screaming his lungs out to another. Every character is tense and the performances showcase it brilliantly. Not one actor in this movie is outclasses by anybody else or not one is even a tad bit monotonous. Al Pacino plays Richard Roma-the cocky young salesman who's a natural at what he does and is on a roll to winning himself a Cadillac El dorado. Jack Lemmon as Shelley Levene, the desperate veteran salesman with a sick daughter and the 'charm' to turn customers on or off--mostly off as we see in a scene as he tries to sell a man real-estate through a phone booth. Lemmon's character was probably my favorite if I had to pick one. He has both the elements of a poor helpless father we feel sorry for, and yet the uselessness of an old retired hermit. Ed Harris is the angry David Moss who has bad work ethic and doesn't know when to stop complaining. Harris' character for me was what really sold the film at first, he has the screen most of the time in the beginning and it's his big mouth that starts so much "what if" scenarios that ultimately get carried out by the end of the film. Kevin Spacey and Alec Baldwin play natural corporate jerks who you know you can relate to in the work force as guys that just seem to be there to make you feel like dirt.

The story is catching but not delivered in an easy way. The film moves fast and if you don't pay attention you'll get lost. David Mamet's brilliant dialogue and explosive performances helps keep the tempo of the movie up so that there's never a dull moment when any of these all-star celebrities are onscreen. And it truly is great to see such remarkable actors all onscreen working together. The chemistry certain actors such as Harris and Alan Arkin have together is impeccable. Also Lemmon and Pacino, they play off of each other. "Glengarry Glen Ross" is probably the best example of the greatest casting choices, where we know all the familiar star-studded faces, but we know they're not all there just to "look good." 

Based on the Pulitzer Prize winning play, I could definitely see how "Glengarry Glen Ross" worked onstage, and the transfer over to film is gritty and entertaining. To me the whole concept of vulgarity and angst is not just be "cool" by getting away with using such foul language, but to enhance the stress that I know EVERY working man has felt in his office at one time or another. Taking all those emotions literally, it makes for one intense negative trip that ultimately has a positive meaning. "Glengarry Glen Ross" is like Tarantino's "Reservoir Dogs" without the violence. With all the actors playing off of each other and the next move completely unpredictable it's a great movie to watch to remember that what we go through on a regular basis at work can be documented and depicted in an interesting, almost exaggerative way. But remember the policy Baldwin's character Blake heeds, "A, B, C...Always Be Closing..."

The amount of lies told in this picture must number near the hundreds, and that's sales to David Mamet, "it's a tough racket." The movie adapted from the hard-hitting play is cynical, profane and sinisterly funny and known as sort of an acting showcase because of the stellar cast. It's become a little dated, but it's still worth watching. I know just about every line of dialog. Maybe I shouldn't admit that. Jack Lemmon's Shelley Levine is a tragic character for the ages played with every ounce of dramatic tension Lemmon could muster; it was one of his last great roles. Pacino's Ricky Roma is hilarious and often over-the-top Pacino-style. A distinctly cynical but witty drama, that pokes fun at the world of professional sales, and features one of the best ensemble casts of the nineties.

James Foley takes a step up from directing Madonna videos to craft this entertaining drama that will speak to anyone who's ever had to work a job they've hated. Set in the office of a Chicago-based real estate agent, the film follows its floundering employees who are given an ultimatum of closing a deal or losing their job. It's a testosterone fuelled marketplace which sees some employees charm their way to success and others plummet to new lows in order to avoid the chopping block. 

In terms of the cast, things really couldn't get better. Jack Lemmon leads the team with a sympathetic turn as down-on-his-luck Shelley Levene. Once the biggest man in the office, recent years have seen him fall to the bottom of the heap, overtaken by younger and more ruthless salesmen. His performance is one of the film's best, as Lemmon really captures the audience's sympathy with his desperate portrayal. Alongside him Alan Arkin and Ed Harris play less likeable but equally troubled salesmen, and both bring their A-game to the roles. Similarly Kevin Spacey stars as their inept office manager, while Alec Baldwin puts in a great supporting performance despite only appearing in one scene throughout the whole movie. His monologue here is one of the most memorable I think I've ever witnessed. British actor Jonathan Pryce also stars as an unsuspecting buyer, targeted by a slick salespitch made by Ricky Roma; the office's top dog. 

Played brilliantly by Al Pacino, the Roma character is a foul-mouthed hothead who knows how to make a sale. Pacino brings a huge amount of life to the role, standing out from the entire cast and showing once again just what a commanding screen presence he is. In 1993 Pacino received Oscar nominations for his work both here and in Scent of a Woman. Of course the Academy went for his baity role in the latter, but in terms of the better performance, I found his work here to be less contrived and simply more entertaining. This is a performance any who consider themselves a Pacino fan should see.

It should be noted that the film is quite dialogue heavy, and that may put some viewers off. However personally I feel the well-written albeit wordy screenplay acts as one of the film's strengths, filled with witty exchanges and providing great material for the talented cast to play with. That being said certain scenes have a tendency to drag, and though the film is generally well paced and by no means overstays its welcome at just 96 minutes, there are still one or two occasions where Foley could have tightened things up.

On the whole however, this is a very worthy drama featuring a host of fine performances, making it easily one of my favourite films of its year.

This is a great movie in particular respects. I think it should be required viewing for business-school freshmen. Its two great strengths are its writing and its acting. The screenplay by David Mamet is excellent, full of long angry monologues and venomous back and forth dialogue. The movie has little plot, but it's fascinating just to listen to the characters talk and insult each other. The movie has an unbelievably good cast, with some of the very best actors in the business at the time: Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey, Alan Arkin, and Alec Baldwin, and they all actually get adequate screen time and development. Only Pacino got an Oscar nomination when the movie was released, but I really think Lemmon and possibly Baldwin should have gotten nominations as well. It's particularly astonishing to see Lemmon throwing around curse words like it's nothing if you're acquainted with his nice-guy image from his 1950s and 1960s movies, but he does it just so well here; plus, his character goes through the most interesting transformations over the movie. Baldwin only has one scene at the beginning of the film, but it's an excellent scene; he's essentially playing the serious version of the funny character he now plays on 30 Rock, but he was just as convincing here as he is now on the show. Pacino gets some great showy monologue moments, the kind he's always been best with. Harris and Arkin have slightly smaller roles, but their conversations are really good while they last. This might be one of the best all-male ensemble casts I've ever seen. The movie's direction, by James Foley, is quite good, showing some visual flair without overdoing it. The only real flaw in the movie is the godawful soundtrack, which is cheesy jazz that does not fit the tone of the movie at all, sometimes is so loud as to nearly drown out the excellent dialogue, and seems to float in and out of the movie randomly. If ever there was a movie that had no need for a soundtrack, it was this one, and yet it got an absolutely terrible and obnoxious one. Other than the soundtrack, though, it's hard for me to find fault with this compelling multi-character-study.

A film that is drives, lives, and courses through your veins, David Mamet brings his stage play to the silver screen and discusses the world of the salesman. Mamet's words are so intricate and beautiful, filthy and philandering, and yet they sparkle with their brilliance. Most of the film contains these long, convoluted rants from different characters that contain subtle context about their livelihood. Their dialogue is full of the candor and realism of being a salesman in the cutthroat business of selling real estate. Mamet creates characters that are full of expectation, remorse, screaming at one another and anyone to let themselves finally become heard. These words come out of the mouths of a cast that is more impressively assembled than any ever before, including Al Pacino, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, and Kevin Spacey. Each performance has its own breadth, no matter how unknown some of the actors were at the time (Kevin Spacey, I'm looking at you) and always feels desperate. Whether you're the iron willed pro who is closing in on the deal of the century or the warbling old man on his last leg against the crushing pain of unemployment and ruin, they each are wailing for someone to listen to their plight. Though these performances are amazing, it's Jack Lemmon who steals the show on more than one occasion as the chatterbox Shelley Levene. His rants are usually the longest, spiteful, most epithet filled pieces of Americana you have ever heard. He speaks on the state of salesman, his own problems, and time and again begs for understanding from his manager. Al Pacino is also impressive as the only closing salesman, pulling punches and scams in order to get to the yes. Everyone is always lying to their customers, but Pacino is suave and charismatic to boot. The film is set in 24 hours and doesn't move around many sets, but it encases many lives and the consequences of irrational behavior. A classic of American theater as well as film, this is one film that must be seen in your lifetime.
